DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Banking, Finance and Public Administration Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, I present the report of the committee entitled Review of the Reserve Bank of Australia's 1992-93 annual report, together with the minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is the first of what the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration intends to be a series of reviews of matters arising from the annual reports of the Reserve Bank of Australia. The committee chose this course of action in the belief that there needs to be a continued focus on a number of issues highlighted in the committee's previous banking reports, particularly in relation to the interests of consumers of banking services.

PARA.TAB: The committee sees a need for continuing parliamentary oversight of banking and financial services as a means of addressing broader policy issues, including the role and function of the Reserve Bank. An annual review of the RBA's annual report provides a valuable accountability mechanism where concerns arising from changes in banking and financial services can be discussed in a public forum outside the supervisory relationship between the RBA and the banks.

The committee examined a number of issues as part of the review. The most significant issue was bank interest rate margins. This issue was dealt with in previous banking reports by the committee. In response to a recommendation in A Pocket Full of Change, the Reserve Bank reported in its annual report on bank interest rate margins in order to provide more reliable information instead of relying on anecdotal evidence.

The committee was particularly concerned to determine where bank interest rate margins in Australia stood in comparison to those overseas. It was stressed by both the Reserve Bank and the Australian Bankers Association that making meaningful comparisons was very difficult and that comparisons currently available suffered from a number of shortcomings.

The significance of margins is not simply whether they are high by world standards. They also give an indication of the extent of competition in the industry. The RBA has now compiled data on a selection of banks that are comparable to Australian banks. This was reported in the RBA's 1993-94 annual report and will be examined by the committee in the review of that annual report. The committee examined the available data on international comparisons. This material indicated that Australia was in the middle of the pack as far as margins were concerned.

The committee also looked at profitability as a possible measure to assess whether the criticism levelled at the banks that they are recovering their past losses from customers is sustainable. The ABA expressed the view that levels of profitability are not out of line with those in other industries. It was also suggested that the reduction cited by the ABA may simply reflect the impact of the recession, bad debts and non-performing loans. The committee will look at this further.

Another area that will be examined by the committee in relation to the margins is the level of income derived from fees and charges. The report contains a table provided by the ABA which sets out non-interest income as a percentage of average total assets for OECD countries.

The committee did note that Australia was at the higher end of the range. This appears to be at odds with an initial reading of the RBA study which suggested that Australian banks derive a smaller than average share of their income from fees and charges than do banks in other countries. The committee will also pursue this matter.The committee is not convinced that current margins reflect a truly competitive banking environment. Unlike the Reserve Bank, the committee is not presently convinced that margins in Australia are in fact mid-field. Evidence suggests that there is scope for a reduction in margins.

In the time remaining to me, I will touch on a couple of the other issues examined in this review. The committee was pleased to see that the Council of Financial Supervisors is now established and operating effectively. The council has an important role, given the increasing significance that financial conglomerates are assuming in Australia's financial system. The committee will continue to monitor developments in this area.

The committee also continues to have a strong interest in consumer protection. The committee agrees with the RBA's view that the relationship between banks and their customers still leaves a lot to be desired. The code of banking practice is yet to be fully implemented and the committee is still concerned that the code does not apply to small business and the rural sector. This contrasts with codes operating in New Zealand, Ireland and the UK. Similarly, the operation of the banking industry ombudsman scheme is restricted by having an unrealistic financial limit and once again excludes small business and farmers.

The committee is convinced that the scheme provides a valuable alternative to litigation. I am sure that all honourable members are aware of the difficulties that many experience in resolving disputes with banks when confronted with expensive litigation. Changes to eligibility would assist in resolving the problems of many distressed customers.

The RBA has also been assessing the strong growth in the use of derivatives. The committee agrees with the RBA's view that derivatives will continue to be a focus of debate. We are particularly concerned about the risks involved in the use of derivatives by businesses, both large and small. We would not like to see customers with a lack of knowledge and understanding of the associated risks getting into difficulties which are similar to those which occurred with another risky product of the 1980s, the foreign currency loans. The legacy of that debacle, unfortunately, is still with us.

Finally, I would like to thank the secretariat in general but particularly acknowledge our adviser, George Stoyanoff, from the Australian National Audit Office. I thank the committee for its work in producing this report. I acknowledge the cooperation of the RBA and the ABA and commend the report to the House. I move:
That the House take note of the report.

—On behalf of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I present the committee's report entitled Home but not alone—A report on the home and community care program, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I present this report by the Standing Committee on Community Affairs into the home and community care program, entitled Home but not alone. The terms of reference for this inquiry were referred to the committee on 23 June by the then Minister for Health and Community Services, the Hon. Brian Howe. The inquiry was advertised in July 1993 and almost 400 submissions were received. We conducted 20 days of public hearings, generating over 3,000 pages of Hansard evidence. Inspections were held in Sydney, Nyampa Aboriginal community in New South Wales and at Broken Hill, where a public meeting was also held. A discussion/options paper was published in February this year and 3,000 copies were circulated. Well attended public forums were held in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Brisbane.

PARA.TAB: These statistics indicate that the committee sought to consult widely during this inquiry. Perhaps more importantly, they indicate that the community very much wanted to be involved. This involvement need not end with the tabling of the report. I am making myself available to address community meetings dealing with the report over the next few months. I believe it is very important that those in the community who want to respond to this report understand the thinking behind our proposals. A presentation is being held at Parliament House on Wednesday to which all members have been invited. I urge those who cannot come to send a staff member.

Home and community care is a complex topic, with substantial variations within and between states. While the committee has worked hard and long on this report, it would be foolish to believe that we have produced a perfect set of recommendations. The report strives to blend the competing interests and political considerations with practicality. We have recognised the need for change and I believe our proposals are desirable and achievable.

While there are over 80 recommendations covering the full scope of the HACC program, they can be summarised to the following: the program objectives and target group should focus on supporting in the community people of all ages with a functional disability and their carers; the establishment of a single access point to the HACC program, which we have titled the regional community assessment agency; responsibility for post-acute and palliative care being transferred from human and community services to health; the administrative restructuring of the HACC program to a regional basis, including budget holding; the introduction of mandatory quality standards and an independent complaints mechanism; the reconfiguring of consultative advisory bodies and functions on a regional, state and national basis; an increase in the cultural and language sensitivity of the program; improved linkages between HACC and other adjacent and intersecting programs and the recognition of the role of carers and volunteers.

There are three key structural changes proposed: namely, the shift of post-acute and palliative care, a single access point and the regionalisation of the program. In regard to the assessment process, we would propose the establishment of the regional community assessment agency, which would consist of a multidisciplinary team that would be responsible for the total region, with the state health regions as a starting point. I envisage that they would be distributed geographically but electronically interconnected so they could share information. These agencies would assume all of the functions of existing aged care assessment teams and would become the sole access point to HACC services. Duplication would be avoided by the agency being able to contract out its functions to other agencies, for example, to a community options project in a small town or to an existing disability assessment group.

More specialised staff such as interpreters could be contracted as needed to ensure cultural and language sensitivity. Agencies would use appropriately trained staff to conduct assessments. Hence a geriatrician would not assess for a home-delivered meal but whoever did would also assess the total environment, including the needs of the carer. The data collected from the very first contact would be available for future assessments.

Perhaps the most controversial role proposed for the assessment agency is of determining the needs of those being discharged from hospital who require home support. This goes to the very heart of the case mix early discharge issue. The committee formed the view that, while ever it is the sole responsibility of the hospitals to determine the home support needs of a patient, there will be a lack of community confidence in the move to earlier discharging of post-acute or terminally ill patients. The use of an experienced, professional and independent assessment agency specialised in the home support needs of people with functional disabilities will ensure that hospitals are not discharging patients early simply to save money. It will also assist hospitals to develop adequate discharge planning regimes.

The agencies could also help in the development and application of suitable DRGs or equivalent unit cost measures for the reimbursement of hospitals. Assessments would be reviewable and regional forums would be able to discuss the methods and criteria used by the assessment agency. This would ensure that suitable levels of openness and accountability are established. The agency, by not being a provider of services, would have no conflict of interest involved in carrying out its tasks. It is important, however, that the assessment conducted by the agency can be supplemented with a care plan that may be developed by a provider.

The advantages of such a proposal are substantial. To name just a few: regions would develop common assessment parameters; there would be a clear knowledge of professionally assessed need and shortfall; the barrier between the hospital and communities would be diminished; there would be a single HACC referral point in each region; regions would be able to professionally match and prioritise their resources with their needs; there would be no conflict of interest between assessment and provision of services; client ownership would be diminished; and assessment stress would be completely eliminated.

I turn now to post-acute and palliative care. While there was a great deal of anecdotal evidence suggesting that this no-growth area had actually grown, the lack of data collection meant the committee could not form an accurate conclusion. Similarly, it is difficult to accurately predict the impact and implications of early discharge from hospitals and the future role of casemix. There is, however, an overwhelming view in the HACC community that post-acute cases are increasingly consuming HACC resources and that the growing use of casemix will worsen the situation. There is also a widespread suspicion that early discharging from hospital is more in the interests of hospital budgets than the patients' wellbeing. The fact that some state governments asked for this no-growth restriction to be lifted was a confirmation of these fears for many people.

The committee recognises the need for continuity of care for existing HACC clients who require hospitalisation. This led to the recommendation that hospitals be required to maintain the same providers after discharge. We were also concerned to establish that the at-home care for a new or existing HACC client be accepted as part of the acute episode with no less status or shift in medical responsibility than the in-hospital care. We were told of case after case where patients, when being discharged, were given the very clear message that they were no longer the responsibility of the hospital or health sector. The committee's recommendation on assessment and post-acute and palliative care substantially addresses these issues as well as providing a more logical and cohesive structure.

The third aspect of the report is regionalisation, and the thrust of it is both sensible and timely. During the inquiry the massive variations between the size and scope of HACC providers was obvious. They range from small community options programs to massive state-wide organisations. Equally graphic was the chaotic nature of the health boundaries used by state and Commonwealth departments. The geographical variations between health, aged services and HACC mean that not only is data collection difficult but, where it is collected, it is often meaningless.

State governments have tended to regionalise their health services, with a high level of local autonomy. This demonstrates that such a method is viable. Given the effectiveness of the health boundaries and the nature of the health assets and transport systems, it is logical to use regional health boundaries as a starting point. This would mean that the Commonwealth boundaries for aged services covering nursing homes, hostels and community aged care programs as well as HACC would align with regional health areas. Minor adjustments may be needed to allow compatibility with census collection districts.

Having aligned the boundaries, established the regional community assessment agency, transferred post-acute and palliative care to Health, it is now essential to establish a regional budget holder, together with fully functional regional forums and an independent regional review and complaints mechanism. The regional budget holder could be a state department or group, a joint Commonwealth-state group or a jointly appointed community body. Whichever form is taken, it is critical that it be autonomous and not subject to political interference at either the state or federal level. This would mean that none of the normal HACC services would be funded on a state-wide basis. It would also allow regions to develop a wider basis for flexibility and delivery of services.

At this point I want to thank the members of the committee who took part in the inquiry, particularly many of the new parliamentarians. They have built up a great understanding of community care. The secretary of the committee, Mr Bjarne Nordin, warrants praise for his excellent management of both the politicians and our processes. Ms Lynette Sebo performed the sterling work which has become her trademark. Special appreciation is due to Ms Joy McLaughlin from the Department of Human Services and Health. Joy quickly adapted to the committee, and her knowledge and professionalism added greatly to the quality of the report. I thank her on behalf of the committee. We wish her well in her future career. Thanks are also due to those officials, organisations and individuals who made submissions and gave evidence. This particularly extends to representatives of ACOSS, ACOTA, FECCA and ACROD, who made up our public forum panels, and our facilitator, Mr David Efraemson.

In conclusion, it is certain that, with the ageing of our population and the increased move to independence, Australia needs an extensive and effective home and community care system. While there is overwhelming support for HACC, there is also overwhelming agreement that the program has substantial shortcomings. This report comprehensively responds to these shortcomings with fundamental and far-reaching proposals. They represent an opportunity for reform that must not be squandered. I urge all who read the report to involve themselves in this opportunity by responding in writing to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and the appropriate state minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the opposition contributors to the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs entitled Home but not alone—A report on the home and community care program, I wish to speak in favour of it. I apologise first for the deputy chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie), who would have spoken at this point and has taken a very real and personal interest in the matters about which we have been deliberating, as he is unable to be with us at precisely this time.

PARA.TAB: The HACC program has been important and is becoming increasingly important as we become a society with people who are in particular need of care to enable them to live in their own homes, a society where the number of people who are living to older ages is continuing to increase and a society where the cost of providing ongoing care in institutional environments is expensive and prohibitive. What came through to me in the course of the inquiry we undertook was the extent to which there have been quite significant variations in the various states of Australia in the way in which they have developed programs to meet their community needs. Very often that is a good thing because innovation is important, but the extent to which we have moved in quite different directions in a number of the states and the inadequacy of the information that enables us to effectively evaluate the success or otherwise of the various programs that have been undertaken does give one cause for concern.

Some of the recommendations that are contained in this report foreshadow moves in new directions but also require very careful evaluation and monitoring of those initiatives. I think this is an appropriate way to proceed because it will develop the strengths of the HACC program. It is not taking away from the state governments or their various agencies their ultimate responsibilities, but it is putting in place systems to enable effective monitoring of the way in which these needs are being addressed.

I want to draw attention to some matters raised in the report which are of concern to me. I am one who has been concerned about the ability of our communities to meet the needs of those people who suffer a range of functional disabilities. One of my concerns is that the HACC program, which ought to be able to assist not only the elderly but also those with functional disabilities, has had problems in the past in addressing those needs. There has been the view that disability ought to be dealt with separately.

There are recommendations in the report that we should increase the focus on addressing the needs of individuals of all ages with functional disabilities and the needs of their carers in order to support them and maintain their independence and quality of life within the community. I think it is important that the HACC objectives be amended to ensure that the needs of that target group are met.

I also mention the issue relating to the collection of data and the analysis of the reasons for underutilising services, particularly by NESB people—non-English speaking background people. This has been a difficulty that has afflicted this service which needs to be addressed overall. The problems of the inadequacy of data came through not only in relation to the way in which particular groups in the community were able to access services but also more broadly.

I also want to draw attention to the extent to which the committee looked at the issues relating to the way in which people who are discharged from hospitals might be better served, the need for more effective assistance in discharge planning and the development, with the new arrangements for casemix, of post-acute care support provisions. There are some very positive recommendations contained in the report which deal with that matter.

Finally, I want to commend those who are carefully reading this report to look at the recommendations of the committee which are designed to maintain the diversity of the current service provider types and provide for an overall approach on a regional basis to the provision of funds and support for programs which are properly assessed against how they address the needs that exist within the community. In paragraph 9.43 of the report there are some very imaginative proposals for pilot programs to further develop HACC which I believe can take us in more useful directions in the future.

I am very pleased to endorse the report and I commend those of my colleagues who spent so much time in developing this very useful document. I commend the staff of the committee for their role and the expert advice they made available to assist committee members in the development of this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having been a member of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs that carried out this inquiry, I would like to make a contribution to this debate. Most people in the electorates we represent will know there are an awful lot of government programs—state, federal and local—that support people at different levels in the community. Those programs can be very confusing at times, as I am sure any member here will agree.

PARA.TAB: The home and community care program was the bringing together of a number of programs that were funded by government. Probably the longest serving of these was Meals on Wheels. Everybody knows about Meals on Wheels, an organisation which takes food to people who cannot get out of their homes. There were a number of other programs as well, including the modification of homes for people with disabilities, home nursing and so on. The government is to be commended that in the 1980s it brought all these disparate programs together to form what is now HACC.

Nevertheless, in its lifetime HACC has also caused a lot of confusion amongst people in the electorate: those who receive the services and those who may be eligible for them, as well as their carers, GPs and so on. One of the aspects of this program was to make it more available and to make knowledge of the program more widely spread across the country.

We found, as we travelled around the country, that the way the program worked varied considerably from one place to another. In some states an established nursing service received most of the HACC funding and provided most of the services; in other states we found a lot of smaller groups that perhaps served only one small area or region or even a small town. So it has been very difficult to get all the information together and hear from all of those people on the effect of the service, how it was delivered to the clients and how the clients felt about it.

The program, as we all know, was designed to provide the services needed to keep people in their own homes so that they were not automatically institutionalised, as quite often they were in the past. We all know the value of nursing homes and hostels, but there is that gap in between. Most people in the frail aged and disabled groups prefer to stay in their own homes. We found a great need still existed there, although in some areas, of course, the service was adequate.

One area worth highlighting is that of carers. I will always remember, at the hearing at Springwood in my electorate, a woman, the mother of a disabled adult person, who came up to me during the break and said, `I've just discovered I'm a carer.' This was a great revelation to her. She took it as natural that, as the mother of a young person who had problems, she was looking after this person. But she discovered that she was actually worth something—she was not just a mum doing her duty—that she was a carer and worthy of consideration from the HACC program and various government services, and that her needs were as great as her daughter's needs. We all know people who care for those with dementia and disability and who make a lot of sacrifice on behalf of their friend or relative. But sometimes the carer's needs are forgotten. So looking after carers—caring for the carers, if you like—is an important part of the HACC program.

Respite is also an important part of the HACC program: respite for carers so that somebody else takes over their responsibility; and also respite for the people who are being cared for. What I think most people want out of this program—and I hope that this report will go a long way towards providing it—is continuity and consistency. Without the proper knowledge of what is available under the program, how it works and what is accessible, we cannot have that continuity and consistency.

This report goes a long way towards clarifying a lot of the issues that needed clarification and towards overcoming some of the duplication. When state and federal governments work together, there will always be those problems. I hope that the report will result in a better service being provided to those clients of HACC and their carers. So it gives me very great pleasure to commend the recommendations of the report to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence).

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about this very important report, Home but not alone—A report on the home and community care program, which deals with a very important subject. The fact that Australia is an ageing nation will cause difficulties in the future, as fewer and fewer people will be able to fund an ageing population. So it is very important that we start to focus on the needs of the home and community care program to ensure that it is targeted and is meeting the needs and the demands of the broader community.

PARA.TAB: I would like to thank the members, the chairman and the staff of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs. When particular subjects were being discussed, I would always ask what they would mean for rural and remote communities. It is very pleasing to see that a special section of the report is devoted to the needs of rural and remote communities. The differences in needs are highlighted in the report.

I thank those people in my electorate of Maranoa who presented submissions for consideration by the committee. A very wide cross-section of submissions were received by the committee. The committee did travel to remote and rural areas, and it is very important that, as a parliament, we focus on the needs of not only those who live in our closely settled capital cities or regions of Australia but also those who live in rural, remote and isolated areas, including Aboriginal communities.

Interestingly, department figures show that 54 per cent of the service outlets in Australia are in rural and remote Australia. In other words, a majority of these service outlets are in rural and remote Australia. So it is very important that our report covers the issue of the needs of those communities.

Paragraph 6.54 highlights a problem with the administration of the HACC program in the Pilbara region of Western Australia. The Department of Human Services and Health thought it probably needed only half of one administrative person to operate the two offices which cover the whole of the Pilbara region in Western Australia. We cannot blame the bureaucracy or the health department. I guess it is an issue that will be addressed.

Quite often when regulations are drawn up in a capital city, or here in Canberra, the needs and the size of the area are not always taken into consideration. In the case of the Pilbara region, 510,000 square kilometres of Western Australia had to be administered by half of one person. Obviously, that was not a sustainable situation, as the members of the committee realised. Another fact about the Pilbara—and this highlights the differences between capital cities and rural areas of Australia—is that Aborigines comprise 10 per cent of the entire population of the region.

The report certainly needs widespread circulation by members and senators. I hope the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) is able to act on some of the recommendations of this extremely important report. I was privileged to be part of that committee. I thank the staff and the chairman for the time devoted to the consideration of those issues affecting rural and remote communities which were so important to the constituents whom I represent here in parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in speaking to and supporting this report, Home but not alone—A report on the home and community care program. The home and community care inquiry was the first inquiry of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs which I have been involved in from beginning to end. The committee travelled to every state of Australia and to many regional centres, including Campbelltown in my electorate.

PARA.TAB: The HACC program is in the fortunate position of being not only a good social program providing better outcomes for consumers by enabling them to live at home but also a program which has economic benefits due to the relative cost of caring for people at home compared with caring for people in nursing homes and hostels. When the economic rationalists and the bean counters look around for savings in our social programs, as they are wont to do, they will see that HACC is actually saving the government money and is working.

One of the things I found most interesting about the evidence we received at the various public hearings was the discussion on the question of the administration of the program, that is, the respective roles of the Commonwealth, the states and local government. There has been much debate in recent years about the roles of different spheres of government in many of our programs in the health and community services area. I will not dwell too much on this, but it was significant, in my view, that nobody who gave evidence, other than the state governments themselves, supported a reduction in the Commonwealth's role. Certainly nobody supported the program being handed over to state governments. Could we blame them?

There was much discussion on the question of the role of local government. I believe that, while individual councils can and certainly do choose whether or not to be involved in direct service provision or auspicing of HACC projects, the potential strength of local governments is in their ability to be involved in planning and coordination of services at a regional level—that is, councils working together on a regional basis and being involved in planning and consultation around the provision of HACC services. This is what the peak councils representing local government were seeking during the inquiry and this is very much reflected in the recommendations contained in this report.

I mention one particular issue which came to light in New South Wales, particularly at Campbelltown and around my electorate—that is, the question of access to respite care for people with disabilities. This issue came up because there was a perception in the community that people with disabilities were being discriminated against, as opposed to frail aged people, in accessing respite care services. I am pleased to say that, because this issue was raised in the context of the inquiry, we were able to sort it out to a large extent. It certainly appears that there have been some misunderstandings and some misinterpretation of the guidelines by various government agencies, but I think we have managed to sort out that issue.

I would like to thank several people for their assistance to me in my work on this inquiry. I thank Mandy Moore, the HACC development officer from the New South Wales Local Government Association, and her predecessor in that role, Louise McDermott, both of whom provided valuable assistance and guidance to me throughout the inquiry. I would also like to thank the Macarthur HACC development officer, Louise Polikarpus, particularly for her valuable assistance in convening a public meeting at Picton in my electorate. I believe it was important to get as much consultation as possible on the options paper, so we convened a meeting to discuss that in April. That was very valuable.

I thank all of the HACC providers and consumers in my electorate for their input into this process. I mention Danielle Carriage, Gary Hudson, Lyn Bright and Helen Jones. Of course, there are many other people. I also join with previous speakers in thanking the committee secretariat, headed by Bjarne Nordin, and, in particular, Joy McLaughlin, who gave us tireless support and guidance throughout the inquiry.

This is a good report. It is a report that I hope the government will act upon and do so fairly soon. There has been a lot of speculation about the future of HACC and other government programs in the context of COAG and Commonwealth-state roles.

I believe we have put a lot of work into this report. It is not easy to come up with a report from a committee of 12 government and opposition members, but I think this report is well worth while and should be acted upon. I very much commend the report to the House.
Motion (by Mr Allan Morris) proposed:
That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House calls on the Government to establish a National Coal Authority to:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)oversee and coordinate negotiations between Australian coal exporters and overseas buyers, especially the Japanese, in order to achieve better pricing outcomes;
(2)develop a national role in the management and development of Australia's coal reserves and in the issue of new coal mining leases;
(3)investigate the effects of Japanese investment in the Australian coal industry on the negotiations for export tonnages and prices;

(4)advise the Government on measures which are appropriate at the national level to ensure that coal industry employees receive a more equitable return for their cooperation in industry restructuring, improved productivity and industrial stability; and
(5)monitor, and respond as necessary to, adverse developments in employment and investment levels in the coal mining industry.

To a very large extent this motion speaks for itself. It reflects widespread and growing concern on the part of many people in the community about the circumstances in which our coal industry operates and in which our coal is sold overseas. At one time that concern was largely confined to employees, mining unions, and people like myself and my colleagues who will be speaking to this motion and who represent coalmining constituencies.

PARA.TAB: That concern has become much more widespread. Organisations, impartial, unbiased objective people within the community, and academics are all now increasingly indicating their concern about what is happening in this industry. I appeal to those members of the opposition who are going to speak to this motion not to build straw men and not to misrepresent what this motion seeks to do.

Let me say, first of all, what it does not seek to do. It does not seek to establish a national coal marketing authority in the sense of a wheat marketing board or a wool marketing board. It in no way suggests that there should be a coal acquisition scheme or that the federal government should unilaterally take over the sale of Australian coal and negotiate itself all of those terms and conditions. I emphasise the first part of the motion, which says that a national coal authority should be established to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . oversee and coordinate negotiations between Australian coal exporters and overseas buyers . . .

That is what the motion seeks to do. Of course, there are other elements of the motion also concerned with the general management of Australia's coal resources and with some of the questions, issues and problems which need to be addressed there.

PARA.TAB: The Australian coal industry is Australia's major export industry. It earns for us every year about $7,500 million; it employs almost 30,000 people around Australia; and to a very large extent it supports coalmining communities which tend to be very widely dispersed and which are almost exclusively dependent upon that industry.

Australia is also the world's major coal exporter. We supply over 30 per cent of the world's seaborne trade. The fact that Australia's total coal reserves are a relatively small proportion of the world's coal reserves and the fact that we have only about 0.3 per cent of the world's people means that on a per capita basis Australia's coal reserves are very significant indeed.

About 60 per cent of our coal exports go to Japan, which, of course, establishes Japan as our major coal buyer. We are very dependent upon Japan for the purchase of steaming coal, which it uses to generate power, and for the purchase of Australian coal in the steel industry and for the viability of the Australian coal industry.

Let me emphasise that I am a strong supporter of the developing relations between Australia and Japan. I do not want this to be seen as a hatchet job by me or by anyone else on Japan—I am not a person who would perform such a task. I am a strong supporter of those developing relations. There is a natural partnership between Australia and Japan which is underscored by the special features of our national economies and by our proximity. But that relationship must be forged on the basis of an equal partnership, on the basis of mutual respect and a transparent honesty, and on an insistence that there will be an equitable sharing of the enormous benefits which can accrue, and which will accrue, as the trading relation between Australia and Japan develops and as our economies more closely integrate.

The claim is often made that the coal industry and coal sales overseas on the part of Australia have to face market realities. I agree with that. Market realities necessarily include demand and supply conditions. However, those market realities include not only conditions of supply and demand but also other elements. For example, they include the clear identified cartel buying arrangements of the Japanese.

Robert Humphris, the chair of the Australian Coal Association, just a few nights ago on Lateline, Kerry O'Brien's program, referred to these arrangements. He said that it is not a cartel; it is a collegiate system or arrangement. With respect to Robert Humphris, for whom I have a lot of personal regard, what the hell does that mean? It makes it sound almost like a fraternity. It is a cartel. It operates as a cartel. Let me say that it operates very successfully as a cartel.

Those market realities also include the uncoordinated, self-seeking approach of Australian coal exporters. It should no longer be tolerated. They compete against each other when they go to Japan. They go cap in hand to the Japanese coal buyers. They sacrifice price for volume. The overall effect of that is something I hope I will have a chance to develop during the 10 minutes available to me.

One other element of those market realities is the dominant position of the Japanese buyers. The world goes to them. First of all, they pick off one country after another. They pick the weak link. This year it happened to be Canada. So they picked off Canada, established price levels with Canada and then ensured that those price levels flowed on to other countries as well. As they deal with each country, they pick off the weakest seller. This year in Australia it happened to be BHP. They picked off BHP and those prices then flowed through.

After the coking coal buyers established the price benchmarks, those prices flowed through to steaming coal as well. I emphasise the point that while there may have been circumstance in the Japanese steel industry which justified a reduction in coking coal prices this year—but I do not declare that—there was no excuse for the reduction in steaming coal prices, but the prices flowed through. That is related to the general claim made that the prices reflect market realities, which are supply and demand. They do nothing of the kind. For example, Don Barnett, the Managing Director of the Macquarie University's Mineral and Energy Economics Centre, anticipated those changes in the steaming coal prices before they occurred. He said that the steaming coal prices will be set by Japanese culture, not market fundamentals, which insists that they not be seen to be coming to some sort of buying arrangement which is significantly dissimilar from that which was achieved by the coking coal buyers.

Those prices are not exclusively set by the market forces of supply and demand. If they were, how could anyone explain the fact that in 1991, for example, the prices in US dollars for US coal was $62 a tonne; for Canadian coal, $71 a tonne; and, for Australian coal, $55 a tonne? I know some people can say that there are differences in quality and distance, but they are not sufficient to explain those differentials. They are not sufficient at all.

All of the major productivity gains in the Australian coal industry since 1983 have been transferred by way of a subsidy to Japan through those coal prices. The price cuts, together with the benefits of the appreciating yen since 1983, particularly because Australian coal prices are written in terms of US dollars, have meant an effective transfer or subsidy of about $30,000 million from Australia to Japan since 1983. That is about 20 per cent of our total net overseas debt.

I am not suggesting, and I have never suggested, that that could have been avoided had we exercised closer surveillance and had we insisted Australian coal exporters go over there and coordinate their efforts, instead of going over to Japan as they do—and they cannot deny it—and compete against one another to our disadvantage. I never suggested that that could have been gained with more effective coordination and surveillance, but there is no question that a significant proportion of it could have. This year those reductions in prices cost us about $500 million. That continues year after year. That is the equivalent of a wage rise of about $500 a week for every employee in the coal mining industry.

There is no industry in Australia where our track record of management and the pursuit of national objectives has been more abysmal than it has in the coal industry. The destruction of forests, degradation of soil, salting of rivers and so on are all visible. They encourage public reaction. But the abandonment, the sterilisation and the destruction of our coal reserves are hidden from view. Our treatment of our national coal reserves is a national crime. It is profligate, exploitative and destructive, and it is criminal in relation to our national objectives. To allow the present position to prevail will represent an inexcusable abrogation of our national responsibilities. Something should be done by this national government—and the sooner the better. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—The important question is: just why is the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) moving this way? It is not because he thinks his national coal authority is going to happen. It is not because he thinks it is going to do any good. He is moving this way because he, representing a coalmining area, wants to look as though he is doing something—because the government is not doing anything. The significant thing is that he, as a private member, has been left to move a motion for the introduction of this piece of legislation. The government is not doing this.

PARA.TAB: This is an act of deception all round by the government, which pretends to be on the side of the coal workers but is not addressing the real problems of the industry, and by the member for Charlton, who says that he supports the workers but is really just supporting the union—which would no doubt receive numerous cushy positions if this national coal authority ever got going. One can imagine that we would have Neville Wran as the chairman of this authority and probably Malcolm Turnbull as deputy chairman—maybe at the annualised rate of $700,000; that is, of course, when they are through with saving the Australian National Line and through with bringing about all the other things that they do at the behest of this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't put you there.

—I have a perfectly good seat at the moment. Let us examine just how this system—which the member for Charlton is so upset about—works. Under the system that we have, coal exports have tripled since 1980. The Australian coal industry is now a $7 billion a year export industry. Australia is the world's largest coal exporter. Our Japanese market share is growing at 60 per cent a year, despite attempts by the Japanese to diversify into other suppliers. Not only this; the Australian coalminer is a prince amongst blue-collar workers. The Australian coalminer is, quite properly, one of the highest paid workers in industry. If that is a disaster, we could do with a few more.

PARA.TAB: Under the existing system, when the Canadians offered the Japanese a $5 a tonne price cut, we were able to resist that downward pressure and receive a much better comparative deal. The system works well because we are reasonable people to deal with. If the Japanese cartel is as evil as members opposite say, how is it that these evil, wicked, terrible, conspiratorial Japanese are actually giving us a higher price than just about any other price that we get from any other nation in the world?

The fact is that, if the member's national coal authority were established to coordinate selling, the first thing that it would try to do would be to artificially inflate the price. What would that mean? First, it would mean that the Japanese would look elsewhere for their coal, and our share of the Japanese market would fall. Second, it would mean that there would be much less incentive for greater efficiency amongst Australian coal producers.

Third, it would produce a boom-bust cycle in the industry. Prices would be kept artificially high—higher than the market could bear—until, sooner or later, the price could not bear this fixing and it would collapse, with resultant disaster to companies, communities, workers and, in the end, even to unions. Eventually this national coal authority would feel the need to coordinate production across the nation. It would start saying which mines were to expand and which mines were to contract. It would not be following market signals; it would be following political signals.

The clear lesson from attempts to manipulate industries through politics is that they always fail. Just imagine what would happen if there was this national coal authority: the mines owned by the coal workers union would expand indefinitely and the mines owned by everyone else would be forgotten. There would be less investment in industry because the miners would feel that they were not working for themselves but for the government. We would have another example of the wool marketing corporation. We would have the same situation in the coal industry that we had in wool, namely, an artificial expansion propped up by unreal prices; a non-viable industry followed by a huge and tremendous crash which would cause nothing but pain for everyone concerned, and producers saddled with vast debts and the taxpayer ultimately, potentially, liable for vast debts.

So what needs to happen is quite simple: we need to help this industry; we need to get this industry to work better but for the benefit of individual workers, shareholders and the whole Australian community, not just the mineworkers union. We need a stable, efficient and prosperous coal industry, and the last way to achieve that is by setting up yet another industry authority. Let us end the rorts, rackets and rip-offs which still occur. The coal industry is not as bad as it was. But it is only a few years ago when the American producer of a coal excavator was told that the model to be shipped to Australia had to have a bunk in the cabin for the off-duty operator.

In some mines not so long ago some workers did not so much bundy on and bundy off as sign the visitor's book. The simple truth is that the industry is improving. The surest way to stop those improvements is to have a national coal authority of the type that honourable members opposite are suggesting. In the coal industry we need to move away from this class conflict, the them and us attitude, this Japanese conspiracy, this cloth cap, fourth rate Leninism which honourable members opposite represent. We need to get away from `Dear comrade' letters flooding the industry and spreading ancient attitudes of class hatred.

We need to preserve the best attitudes of mining communities: the tradition, loyalty and mateship, but not this class conflict of the them and us attitude. The real problems of the coal industry are the difficulties that are stirred up by the union. The union is the cause of the problem, not the solution. The coal industry lost three days per worker in strike action in 1993 against an average of just one hour per worker in other industries. And it is the fault of your union!

The fact is that this proposal seeks to ruin the whole industry to help a few struggling mines. If an individual mine does need help there are better ways to do it than to set up a national coal authority. If an individual mine needs help, let us give it direct help—let us do something for an individual mine on a strictly limited, short-term basis so that that mine can put its house in order and improve its work practices or, if needs be, so that it can wind down gently. But the fact is we do not want to ruin the industry just to help a few struggling mines.

This government's real agenda is not helping individuals; it is helping unions. Since 1983 this government has given $66 million in direct grants to trade unions. In 1993, as well as $14 million in direct grants, it gave $10 million to the Trade Union Training Authority, and $5 million to help run union elections.

This government has handed out $10,000 to the Metal Workers Union for writers in residence and $12,000 to the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council for a writer in community. The real agenda of the honourable member for Charlton is not to help the industry or to set up this authority; he is just hoping that when the electors boot him out at the next election he will get a job as bore-in-residence for the United Mineworkers Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) in this important motion. It was great to hear the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), who represents that great coalmining area on the north shore of Sydney, telling the members who represent coal producing areas the problems with the coal industry. The honourable member for Warringah is a new member. I invite him to come to my area and make a speech, talk to the miners in my area or come down a pit with me or any of the other honourable members who represent similar coalmining groups, such as the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), and see it for himself. If he does, he would not come in here and make a speech like the one he just made.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member talked about the mineworkers being princes. The 11 entombed miners at Moura were most certainly princes of the industry; they were entombed forever. The 36 miners who have died in that pit over the last three years are certainly the princes of the industry.
I genuinely invite the honourable member for Warringah to come to my electorate. I or my colleagues the honourable member for Macarthur—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or me.
—And the honourable member for Charlton. We will arrange for him to go through some of the pits and talk to the people there about the coal industry.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members would be aware of a campaign by the United Mineworkers Union concerning coal prices. I totally support the campaign. It is not a new issue. In my maiden speech in the parliament in 1983, I drew attention to the situation in the coalmining industry. Indeed, since that time, things have not improved; in many respects, they have become worse. Thousands of jobs have been lost to the industry and the real price per tonne decreased because of dramatic commercial corruption in the industry.

There are a number of factors distorting the coal market, which, in the end, favours the buyers. There are collusive buying practices by Japanese cartels. These cartels set a ceiling price which flows through to other markets. If this practice were conducted in this country, it would breach the Trade Practices Act. If we do not accept this kind of practice in Australia, why should we accept it in the international market?

I listened to the honourable member opposite, who made much about the dread of these cartels. But his party supports the cartel of the sellers of beef, wheat and wool. We all know of the mess that the wool industry got into, but suddenly, when it comes to coal, it seems to be very logical.

The Japanese have the Australian buyers go to Tokyo. They stay in luxury hotels in Tokyo, all waiting for the telephone call. When the telephone call comes, they trot. The Japanese, dealing in a collective, always trade one off against the other. As the honourable member said, there is always a chink in that chain. After the first one breaks and gives way on price, there is a mad scramble for volume. It has happened year in and year out.

I have been in this place 11 years, but I have had an association with the coalmining industry for many more years than that. The story has always been the same. The buyers come back. When the local paper covers it, they say, `We did our very best. Prices went down slightly, but we have increased the volume.' More coal is now being exported at a lower price than ever before. Every Australian is paying the cost. There is an argument that coal is far too important to the economy of Australia to be left to these sellers, who have proven time and again that they are not up to the task.
Surely what the honourable member for Charlton is suggesting is in the national interest—that we bring some cohesion to this very important industry in Australia. It is costing each of us—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why isn't the government doing it?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The honourable member for Throsby is entitled to be heard in silence.

TALK.START.PARA: —And I do not need these North Shore coalminers prompting me and telling me what to say. Comrade, I know my speech, I know my industry and I know my coalminers, and I do not need help from blow-ins from the North Shore to tell me how to deliver it. (Time expired)
—Mr Deputy Speaker—
—Another coalminer—

—I am pleased that the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) recognises that I do have some very important coalmines in my electorate. I am conscious of their importance and I hope that the government is as well. When the government puts up excise on diesel fuel on coal lines such as the Moura to Gladstone line and collects from that simple train line $1.7 million per year in excise, then I have every reason to be concerned for the community of Moura and the miners who live there, whose future is put in jeopardy by that sort of charging.

PARA.TAB: In response to the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), I am not going down a negative valley, but I want to canvass some of these issues. When a motion such as this is before the House, it is a good time to take a searching look at where the industry might be going and how its development might impact on the national interest. Of course, each group in the community has a different perception of what constitutes national interest, and the scene becomes even more blurred when the discrete interests of one constituent group come into account.

This is no less so in the case of coal and, in particular, export coal, which is the focus of the suggested national coal authority. The fact that Australia is the largest exporter of coal—132 million tonnes of our total production of 180 million tonnes, or 70 per cent, goes overseas—makes the prospect of such an agency a matter of concern to all in the industry.

I take issue with the honourable member for Charlton when he said that the Australian industry is profligate. Energy sources are going to change over the next 20, 30 or 40 years. By the time coal supplies are exhausted, coal will probably not be used any more. If we have 8.7 per cent of the world's coal reserves and at this stage represent only 5.2 per cent of its production, we could hardly be called profligate.

I do not resile from the fact that I have a great deal of sympathy for the motivation behind the union's submission to the ACIC study—it argues a case not unlike those argued by my party in the past for the protection of Australian export industries—but I think honourable members on both sides of the House recognise that those days are fast fading and we have to take a more hard-nosed approach to what we do with our national resources.

Having said that, I have some misgivings as to the validity of the basic argument that something akin to one-desk selling will necessarily work in the coal industry. First of all, the argument flies in the face of the stated policies of both the government and the opposition for a more competitive and market oriented industry regime.

Central to the UMW's case is the suggestion that the current Japanese methods are both collusive and designed to force down prices. The fact that we supply that nation's needs to the extent of 70 per cent of its steaming coal and 50 per cent of its coking coal gives us strength as well as vulnerability. But if we were to sell through one authority or sales were authorised by one authority, one has to ask whether Japan would be as ready to be so reliant on us as its major supplier.

The UMW, in its submission, in conjunction with a matrix showing the contract structure of Nippon Steel in 1984—and I suggest that honourable members opposite look at that structure—asks: is this a set of transactions, or a coordinated purchasing strategy? I ask perhaps a third question: is it not a mechanism to ensure the availability and continuity of supply in every conceivable set of circumstances? In other words, is this not a Japanese industry covering its back?

I accept, however, that it demonstrates a high degree of market sophistication in purchasing, and in that respect I wonder whether Australia might not be better served by a mechanism for greater market intelligence than by an authority with stringent regulatory powers. I am encouraged by discussions I have had with John Maitland, and I believe that his trend is turning away from a regulatory body much closer to this idea of market intelligence. There is not sufficient time available for me to go into the matter of the second proposition other than to say that, if there were a regulatory body, would it not eventually come to the point of saying: who could open and not open mines; who would have to close mines; and who would have to limit production? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Horne Mr R.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to support the private member's motion of my colleague the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). When we talk about the Australian coal industry—I ask members opposite to take note of this—we are talking about the most efficient coal industry in the world. It sets the benchmark, it sets the standard for all coalmines and it provides the technology. Wherever in the world a coalmine will be set up, it will be with Australian technology.

PARA.TAB: You can come in here and talk about the days lost, but if you care to have a look at this graph provided on the Australian coal industry, you will see that, over the past decade, output has risen from 2,500 tonnes per worker per annum to 6,500 tonnes per worker per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of that is technology.

—I thought you represented coalminers and I thought you would have been proud to support this motion. Not only are we as a nation seen internationally as a source of high quality coal that can be provided regularly and reliably, we are seen as a nation that major trading partners—Japan, Korea and Taiwan—want to do business with.

PARA.TAB: During the recent parliamentary recess, I had the fortune to visit these three countries and that point was made consistently. When the China Steel steel mill in Taiwan was asked about where it would get the coal for its new blast furnace, it had no doubt that the coal would come from Australia. It did not want to go to South Africa or elsewhere; it wanted Australian coal because it knew it could guarantee the quality and the supply.

In my own part of the world, the Hunter Valley, like the honourable member for Charlton, we know the importance of the coal industry to the whole of the communities that thrive there. The state government in New South Wales takes $140 million a year in hauling coal down the Hunter Valley and, because that coal line is making a profit, it is up for sale. Where was the New South Wales government in the negotiations in the recent drop in coal price? Did it consider being asked to drop its freight rates? No. That is one of the reasons that we must consider a national tribunal where all the players in the mining game—everyone who works in the mining industry and who makes a profit out of the mining industry—must be included in the negotiations and must be prepared to shoulder some of the responsibility to make sure that this coal industry, this leader, continues to thrive and support as many communities as it does.

SPEECH.PARA: The criticism comes back that it is the unions requesting this. I ask all people in the House to seriously consider the contribution that mineworkers have made. We have heard from the honourable member for Throsby about coalminers who have lost their lives in his area. We are all only too aware of the recent tragedy in Moura, and I appreciate that that again was in the electorate of the honourable gentleman opposite. They are the sorts of things that coalminers and coalmining families live with all the time. Not representing any coalminers, you say that is par for the course; that coalminers know that when they take on the job. PARA.TAB: I ask that we seriously look at what coalminers have contributed. I have already pointed out the increase in productivity per coalminer over the past 10 years. But those opposite have come in here and in a very unobjective way have said that coalminers are some of the highest paid people in the world, or some of the highest paid people in Australia. But the contribution that they make to the export earnings of this country is one of the highest per capita. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is more than coincidence that the electorate of the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) produces exactly the same amount of coal as my electorate. This motion is before us because some weeks ago the ACTU and the mining union announced the release of an industry blueprint claiming that Australia's sovereignty had been jeopardised by the collusive pricing practices of the Japanese coal buyers, demanding greater control over local coalmining arrangements. The plan amounted to no more than a renewed effort to win popular support for union based regulation of the coal industry.

PARA.TAB: The union movement has failed to adjust to the tough reality of international competition, and only domestic reforms would secure the future of the coal export sector. The union proposals are a thinly disguised effort to virtually nationalise the local coal export industry. In fact, I believe that, if the coal authority goes ahead, it will wreck the $7.5 billion coal export industry, scare off investment and undermine Australia's reputation as a reliable supplier.

The wholehearted endorsement of the plan by ACTU president, Martin Ferguson, has cast a shadow over the micro-economic reform agenda. All commodity exporters face multiple competitors and tough dealing on the part of buyers. Only those coal producers who can secure local cost advantages and high levels of productivity will win out.

But the ACTU's support for a government sanctioned Australian coal cartel spells the end of the road for efforts to boost the efficiency of the coalmining sector. The impact of the peak union's endorsement of the coal plan could not be underestimated. If acted on, the ACTU's stance will see buyers rush to alternative suppliers and will ruin opportunities for local mines to take a foothold in Asia's emerging markets, particularly in steaming coal.

The motion proves that the federal government has recently shown signs of wilting in the face of pressure by unions to wind back reforms in the coal sector. Plans to merge the coal industry's antiquated industrial arrangements within the mainstream jurisdiction of the Australian industrial relations system now lacks a timetable of any definition whatsoever. Any delay on the reform agenda on these fronts will be to the long-term detriment of the coal industry as well as its work force.

If this government wants to do something for the coal industry, I suggest that it turns to its industrial relations reforms. If we are not achieving the right price and if we do not have the bargaining power that we should have as a major coal exporter and as the most efficient coal exporter and coal producer in the world, we must have reliable supply.

I have been flying from Queensland to Canberra for many years now. It always amazes me when I look out over Newcastle and see the ships standing offshore due to an industrial dispute. We can see the same thing in Gladstone and in a lot of our major ports. We must maintain the reputation we have as a reliable supplier. That is in the hands of the government. We will not achieve that by reregulating the industry and by setting up a marketing authority over the top of the reforms that have already been achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). I have been in the chamber for most of the day so far. I noticed earlier during the debate on committee reports that there was a shortage of opposition speakers. I thought that the opposition was perhaps having a shadow cabinet meeting or some other leadership meeting. The opposition was a bit short of speakers. We really know the opposition is getting desperate when it sends the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) in to talk about coalmining.

PARA.TAB: Not surprisingly, the honourable member's speech turned out to be another excuse to bash the trade union movement. If he is not talking about bashing the republic or constitutional matters, he has to bash the trade union movement. It was yet another excuse to have a go at the union movement.

Unlike the honourable member for Warringah, I have coalmines in my electorate and a number of workers who are members of the coalmining union. I am proud to say that I support the union's position on these issues. I do not suppose that there are too many coalminers in the electorate of Warringah.

Coal is the highest export earning industry in Australia. It is a particularly important industry on the south coast of New South Wales and, indeed, within my electorate. It employs a lot of people. We are losing at least $300 million a year in export earnings as a result of a reduction in prices. Whether that is caused by the Japanese or other foreign countries getting together and playing off our individual coalmining producers one against the other to reduce prices, that has to be a matter of concern. It is also a concern in the area of employment. The union estimates that we are losing one in 20 jobs every year because of price reductions in coalmining. I am concerned about that and ordinary Australians should be concerned about that.

We have to work together in the national interest and, as the union says in its literature, we have to play as a team; we have to become team players. The opposition should know—especially now—about becoming team players; we have heard a fair bit about that in the last few days. That is what the CFMEU is talking about. Australian industry and Australia generally should be a team player in the coal export industry.

Australia has a mixed economy. Unlike some parts of the world, we do not have a totally command economy, nor do we have a totally capitalist economy. We have competition where appropriate. A report which has just come out calls for more competition amongst public sector utilities. We also have government intervention where that is appropriate. When the national interest is at stake, when Australia's jobs and Australia's export earnings are at stake, what is wrong with having government intervention?

As outlined in the honourable member's motion, what is wrong with having a coal authority to oversee and coordinate negotiations between exporters and overseas buyers? What is wrong with developing a national role in the management and development of Australia's coal reserves, as called for in the motion? What is wrong with having a body to advise the government on measures which are appropriate at the national level to ensure that employees receive a more equitable return for their cooperation in industry restructuring?

Let us have a more efficient industry, but let us not sell out the national interests by allowing a totally deregulated situation to threaten our export dollars and our jobs. I have already said that the coalmining industry is losing at least $300 million a year in export earnings, depending on which estimate one goes along with. That is probably one of the minimum estimates that I have heard. As well as that, one in 20 jobs a year are disappearing.

For the sake of my constituents and the coal industry in my electorate—indeed, in New South Wales and Queensland, which is where most of the coal is—it is important to have this national coal authority. Let us have some commonsense on this issue, not union bashing and the usual nonsense we hear from the opposition. I certainly commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) mentioned the matter of cartels and collegiates—or colligates, that fancy word that Bob Humphris talked about on the Lateline program. In response to Kerry O'Brien, Mr Humphris said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, we've had collective negotiations from Australia . . . All the soft coking coal producers out of Newcastle in the early `80s got together. They were known collectively as the `gang of seven' and then I think they became the `gang of six' and the `gang of five', and they negotiated collectively. But I think any objective analysis of their negotiations over a period of years would show it was pretty well neutral.
That statement is from an acknowledged respected leader within the coal industry. This whole business about margins and appropriate prices bedevils us all in all ranges of commercial activity.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to note an issue dear to my heart when the report of the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration was introduced by its chairman. Committee members noted the margins that the banks were charging. They said that they were not satisfied with the evidence from the banks and, therefore, it was a matter of national concern. I agree that, if there is not a sufficient margin in the coal industry, it has to be a matter of national concern.

Then there is the other part of the equation known as market realities. The argument that persuades me most is the competition with other energy sources. It is interesting to note that coal prices have fallen less than have oil prices over the last 15 years. If we look at OPEC, one of the world's most famous cartels, we see that a whole range of mechanisms has occurred over a 15- or 20-year period and has forced down the price of oil. We want to be very careful that we are not thinking about Fortress Australia in this matter.

We should think about alternative energy sources. Australia supplies a lot of coal to Japan—60 per cent of its steaming coal imports. However, over time Japan could reduce its dependence on Australia's coal for power generation. I understand that coal goes into other industry purposes. Let us look at Japan's sources for electricity. Oil represents 32 per cent—cheaper than coal over a 15-year period—and nuclear energy, 24 per cent. I was interested to hear the MPI last week regarding the three mines policy. I do not suppose we will have a three coalmines policy, a three uranium mines policy, a three copper mines policy or a three farms policy. I am sure that the honourable member for Charlton would not advocate that.

I think we ought to look at market realities. Japan uses gas for 19 per cent of its electricity. Everyone acknowledges that in 50 years time gas will be huge. Our country has to get its act together. An issue that needs addressing by both the states and the Commonwealth is the way in which we get gas around this country and the way in which we export our gas. Japan uses coal for 14 per cent of its electricity and hydro for 11 per cent. That is Japan's electricity make-up. Japan also has some other options. It has the option to move away from Australian coal. It could use coal from Indonesia, South Africa or USA and use more oil, gas and nuclear energy.

Let us look quickly at the Japanese as not the enemy—the honourable member for Charlton tried to stress that he did not want to look at them as that—but certainly as tough business negotiators. Currently the Japanese have a 16 per cent interest in the 1992 production of Australian mines. They have an interest or ownership role in Australia's coalmines. The Japanese are involved right from the base as producers and importers. The point I want to make is that the Japanese have an interest from a profit perspective. I do not think anyone would suggest that coal producers are wandering around the world deliberately trying to sell coal as cheaply as they can. I think they will always try to maximise coal prices.

In conclusion, we need to demonstrate to our overseas customers that our coal industry is ready to become competitive, and we need to introduce greater efficiencies. We need to demonstrate our commitment to improve our coal industry. We do not need to give out signals that we are insecure, and we do not need to encourage the Australian coal industry to hide behind an authority which treats overseas markets as enemies.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.
