TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)condemns the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's proposal to alter the format of the evening news and the 7.30 Report for the following reasons:
(a)the 7.30 Report is a successful program in Western Australia;
(b)the proposal is likely to reduce substantially the Western Australian content of the 7.30 Report or its replacement program;
(c)any attempt to move news production to the eastern States would deprive Western Australian viewers of local news; and
(d)Western Australian interests are just as important to a national news service as those of other States;

(2)supports the retention of the existing 7 p.m. television news bulletin format with production in each State and a current affairs program which allows for the flexibility to insert locally produced Western Australian stories; and
(3)calls on the ABC Board to preserve the regional integrity of the ABC in each State.

I am an Australian nationalist and regard the future wellbeing of the federal structure of our nation as something that all of us should preserve and nurture against those who wish to subvert it through domination of its political, economic and cultural activities on the eastern seaboard as well as those who connive at the encouragement of secessionist sentiments in some of the outlying states. Its national broadcasting service has a critical role to play in strengthening the federation. Unfortunately, in recent times the ABC has become somewhat of a handmaiden to the interests of those who seek to centralise power and influence close to their geographic power base, which is of course in Sydney.

PARA.TAB: The trend in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation towards centralisation of its programming not only is antipathetic to the interests of a nation that balances national interest with the interests of the states but also flies in the face of modern cultural and social history. The move by the ABC to alter news and current affairs production is remarkable for its lack of vision and understanding of what Australian consumers really want.

David Hill has been criticised in many quarters for his ratings driven approach to programming, yet he and his management team are now in the process of making changes which will take the ABC news and current affairs programs further away from the people they are supposed to inform. At his National Press Club speech in July 1992, Mr Hill told his audience that the ABC `is now run more by Australians for Australians'. In some respects he may be right. There is clearly a higher level of Australian content on the ABC in prime time television than was the case in the past. But it is Mr Hill's view of what is Australian that is in question as far as the question of `Australians running the ABC is concerned'.

In its charter, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has as its function `to provide broadcasting programs and television that contribute to a sense of national identity and inform and entertain, and reflect the cultural diversity of, the Australian community'. What Mr Hill tends to reflect in his approach to the obligations imposed on the ABC by its charter is a view of the nation that is heavily concentrated in the south-eastern seaboard. It is the same view that is exposed time and time again in the policies and approach of the federal Labor government and of his mates in the ALP, specifically in the New South Wales Right—the Graham Richardson view of the world, which is shared by his successor, Little Richo, the Chief Government Whip.

When I first came to the House of Representatives, I was astounded at the almost total absence of news from my home state on the local and national media. There is little to no real concept of the events in the western third of our continent on the part of those who are responsible for the compilation and dissemination of news stories. The press gallery's view of the world, for instance, is almost obsessed with the daily goings-on in the national capital—and even that is more or less limited to Parliament House and its environs.

This lack of understanding of the importance of regional events in the social, political and economic life of the nation is most obvious when you look at the use of the word `national' as a prefix for a news service for our national broadcaster. How easy it is to merely look on the rest of the nation's affairs from Sydney or Melbourne and conclude that nothing of much interest occurs elsewhere.

As the coalition spokesman on communications, Senator Alston, put it in a recent interview with the PM program, the ABC has a charter obligation `to reflect the cultural diversity of the Australian community', and there are community concerns that `it is not measuring up to its charter obligations'. I mentioned earlier that the ABC's trend towards centralised programming flies in the face of modern social and cultural history.

Many honourable members will be aware of the works of Alvin Toffler—Future Shock, The Third Wave and Power Shift. As early as 1970, Alvin Toffler was examining the trend towards splintering or demassification of the media. He explored the future trajectory of media programming and delivery and concluded that the trend was more towards the plural than the Orwellian vision of 1984 with its unceasing propaganda screeching from the ever present telescreen in every household. `Interactive', in Orwell's nightmare view of the world, was limited to the Thought Police watching citizens via the telescreen and regularly stamping on any manifestations of independent or non-conformist behaviour.

Toffler's prophecies in this case have turned out to be closer to reality than those of most of his contemporaries. Media, print and electronic, is becoming more and more Balkanised as subculture after subculture demands entertainment and information that reflect their own lifestyles and view of the world. The sweeping anticommunist movements that triumphed in the 1980s in eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union were stimulated and fed by the fingers of sound and vision coming from the pluralist West. The fax machine, video recorder and personal computer became the new weapons of freedom and self-determination as citizens of formerly repressive and collectivist societies clamoured for change.

In Romania, for example, it is ironic that Dallas, a program that the Ceaucescu regime hoped to use to pacify its people, became a striking symbol of the West to a materially deprived population. In the West, cable TV and the newer services available in the information highway are demonstrating that consumers want their thing, not a monolithic service provided from one source. The trend is towards fractionalisation of messages, not centralisation as in the case of the ABC's proposal. Tasmanians, Queenslanders, South Australians and Western Australians are more aware of their regional identity and are demanding services that provide the information and entertainment relevant to their lifestyles and location. A one source national news system is an anachronism—it is just not relevant to the needs of a modern, dynamic, pluralist and multicultural Australia.
It is interesting to note that the ABC's code of conduct, as of 17 March last year, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The presentation or portrayal of people in a way which is likely to encourage denigration of or discrimination against any person or section of the community on account of race, ethnicity, nationality, sex, age, physical or mental disability, occupational status, sexual preference or the holding of any religious, cultural or political belief will be avoided.
There is no mention of a person's place of residence, as though this is almost irrelevant to the culture of a nation.

PARA.TAB: Mr Hill, the Managing Director of ABC, and Phil Chubb, the national 7.30 Report editor, have proposed that news and current affairs programming be changed, nationalised and sourced from Sydney. Mr Hill's plan to restructure the news and 7.30 Report format would have the states of Australia broadcasting a 6.30 p.m. local news and current affairs program, effectively halving local content, followed by a national news bulletin at 7 p.m. Mr Hill and Mr Chubb would have us believe that the national program will provide for coverage of state events to make up for this diminished local coverage.

There has been much said of the amount of money each Australian contributes towards their ABC. In the main, Australians do not begrudge that expenditure, but they do want value for money. They do want relevance. They want a service that is relevant to their thing. For their money, they want quality, innovative, informative and groundbreaking programs that otherwise would not be seen on normal commercial stations. But for their news, they want clear, concise information about the area in which they live as well as the wider community and the nation. They do not want yet another `infotainment' program passed off as news and current affairs, like they get on the commercial stations.

Mr Hill's proposed changes for the ABC are not new. They are a tired old re-run which the Australian people have rejected twice before. An article in the West Australian written by the journalist Leroy Betti states:

SPEECH.PARA: ABC Managing Director David Hill has used failing ratings to defend planned changes to television news and current affairs.
But where are those falling ratings? In Sydney, and in Melbourne to a lesser extent. But in Perth? In far off Western Australia? Mr Betti says:
But in WA, the program has maintained slightly more than 16 per cent of the metropolitan audience.

He goes on to say that on the day the changes were announced the 7.30 Report rated at 20 out of 21 for each quarter of an hour. Are those falling ratings, Mr Hill? Certainly not. As I mentioned earlier, these proposed changes are an anachronism. They are not bringing the ABC into the forefront of modern news and current affairs delivery; they are harking back to the past. It is absolutely critical for the residents of my state to feel that they are part of a modern dynamic federation in Australia that is served by a national broadcasting system. They want to have a current affairs and news service which includes items, stories and matters of interest and importance to their region, to their area. Some of them say that the ABC is politically biased. Some of them say that the 7.30 Report is biased. (Time expired)

Those opposite have a hide to come into this House and pretend to defend the ABC. In Fightback, they put forward proposals to cut funding to the ABC by $50 million per year. That would have meant dramatic cuts to the level of Australian content. It would have meant the virtual closure of all news and current affairs production facilities in the ABC outside the Sydney-Melbourne-Canberra triangle. That is their policy. They should not come into the House and pretend to be strong defenders of the ABC when they went to the last election promising massive cuts to the funding of the ABC and maintaining a policy which effectively meant that there would need to be advertising on the ABC to make up for funding shortfalls. They have no credibility when it comes to a discussion as to what we in this country require from the ABC so that people in this country, wherever they live, will get a genuine national, state and regional influence in their news and current affairs programs.

The 7 p.m. news in Brisbane and throughout Queensland has that balance. But the ABC will relegate state and regional news and current affairs, take it out of the 7 p.m. timeslot and put it into the 6.30 p.m. timeslot, which is a time that is not wanted by viewers. That would be the equivalent of saying to people in Queensland, `Why not read the Sydney Morning Herald and the Sydney Daily Telegraph Mirror every day?' They do not read it every day because it has no regional influence in it. It has no state based news.

The ABC is essentially saying, `We will not give you that in your 7 p.m. news bulletin. We will relegate it to a timeslot which you don't want to watch.' These proposals emanating from Mr Hill will destroy what are essentially popular programs in Queensland, Western Australia and many other regional areas of this country.

The ABC will simply cease to be a national broadcaster under these proposals because it will not reflect the genuine regional and state diversity of this country. People will not watch their news bulletins to get what they want. It would be like Queenslanders reading the Sydney Daily Telegraph Mirror and the Sydney Morning Herald when trying to get a perspective on the Queensland state government. It is simply absurd for the ABC to pretend that these proposals are in the long-term interests of the national broadcaster or that its interests in being a national broadcaster are served by them in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I think that this debate has been significant. SPEECH.PARA: calls on the ABC Board to preserve the regional integrity of the ABC in each State.

He attempted to make out that the ABC board is proposing these changes. That is not only untrue; it is a ridiculous proposition. In fact, at the conclusion of his speech, the honourable member for Perth supported that particular paragraph.

PARA.TAB: The only doubt expressed during the speeches of government members was in the speech of the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd). To be honest with honourable members, I really could not understand exactly what he was getting at. I note that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), who is at the table, agreed with me that it was not the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) who made an allegation against the ABC. I think it was a previous speaker who made the statement. It certainly was incorrect for the honourable member for Leichhardt to cast that aspersion.

The important point about this motion is that in Western Australia, and for that matter in South Australia, Tasmania and Queensland, there is considerable concern about the centralisation of the news and current affairs programming of the ABC. That concern is not some sort of idle speculation; that concern comes from reflection on the immediate history of the ABC, because we have already seen this occur in the past. There is a sense of deja vu about this; we have been there before and we have already seen this type of proposal fail.

In my view, the ABC's management is interested in centralising the control of the news content that emanates from its productions. I think that that is very dangerous in a pluralist federal system of government. Interests all around the nation differ and have to be represented by a truly national broadcaster in the programs it broadcasts to the population. The honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) agrees with that proposition. In his heart, he knows that his own constituents are deeply concerned about these changes and, despite the confection all through his speech, he was agreeing with the sentiments of this motion 100 per cent.

The other point raised by the honourable member for Leichhardt was that somehow we were trying to interfere with or influence the ABC's broadcasting content. Nothing is further from the truth. But there is an obligation on us as members of this House and as members of the Australian parliament to ensure that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation fulfils its charter obligations. As acknowledged by the honourable member for Perth and the honourable member for Lilley, that involves community service obligations that require the national broadcaster to take into consideration cultural differences within our community.

Unfortunately, in modern-day parlance, cultural means multicultural, ethnic or something else. But it also means—and it is something that is integral to this nation—the interests of all the states and territories of our great nation. Therefore, in order for the ABC to fulfil its charter obligations, it must reject the proposal of the ABC management and refuse to change the format, not necessarily the time format but the format of the programming and the excision of local content from a program that is going to replace the 7.30 Report.

The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) made a very important point, and that was that, with the time differences, there are obviously going to be problems with the end of a news program in Sydney and the breaking of fresh news at the time the program goes to air in Western Australia. We do not believe for one minute that, if a story broke around the country, it would somehow be included in the Western Australian news two hours later. That is our fear. That was our fear in 1990 when these sorts of proposals were first mooted and it is our fear now. We demand that the ABC board reject any proposal that is going to excise Western Australian content from the national news or from the 7.30 Report or its replacement.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not appropriate for any of us to boast, but it is entirely appropriate to congratulate the Australian athletes who won a total of 182 medals, including 87 gold. This is the most won by any nation in the history of the Commonwealth Games. By any measure, the performance was nothing short of extraordinary. We congratulate them on their success and, in doing so, we recognise that success does not come easily. We appreciate the work and dedication of the athletes, the team managers and the management of the whole Australian contribution to the games in securing such an outcome. On behalf of the government and the people of Australia, I congratulate them all.

PARA.TAB: I think the success of the Australians in Victoria is a reflection of the health of Australian society at large. These medals were won across a very wide range of sports, from swimming to shooting, from lawn bowls to weight-lifting, from gymnastics to track and field, et cetera. It is a reflection of the confidence of Australians in their ability to succeed in the world. I might say that it is a reflection of the pleasure they take in the challenge and in the competition. I think these games have also been a reflection of the values by which we want our country to live.

Australian athletes have competed fiercely but in a great spirit. I suspect it was the most multicultural team we have ever sent as well, and perhaps that is yet another lesson about the benefits to be gained from tolerance and openness to the world. Never has it been so clear that we are determined to solve this historic problem.

I think that is one of the several messages that can be carried from the games into the nation's ambitions for the remainder of the decade. —I inform the House that the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and Special Minister of State, Mr Gary Johns, is absent from question time and that the Minister for Industrial Relations will answer on his behalf.
—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister: will he inform the House of the action the government is taking to secure the release of Mr David Wilson?

I notice that over the weekend his father made an appeal to the government and to authorities in Cambodia on David's behalf. —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the minister outline the progress in the implementation of the government's policy of encouraging the Australian work force into enterprise bargaining? Are there any areas where the move into enterprise bargaining is being held back?

—I am pleased to inform the House that the spread of enterprise bargaining amongst workers in the federal system is showing encouraging progress. In total, some 2,400 enterprise agreements have now been registered in the federal system, covering 1.3 million employees; that is, 55 per cent of all federal award employees are now in the enterprise bargaining stream. As even the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has had to admit recently, the pace of bargaining in the federal system has increased since the enactment of the Industrial Relations Reform Act in March of this year.

PARA.TAB: Since that time there have been more than 600 new applications for certified agreements lodged with the commission and more than 320 of those certified agreements have already been approved. In addition, 34 formal applications for the new enterprise flexibility agreements have been lodged, of which 10 have been approved, including one covering 2,400 employees at Optus. Another 50 or so employers have notified their intention to pursue EFAs.

Overall, it is a very pleasing result and one that contrasts with the pitiful attempts to promote enterprise bargaining in many of the state jurisdictions. Amongst the states, only Queensland has more than 10 per cent of state award workers now under enterprise agreements. It is by no means coincidental that Queensland is the only state which has mirrored the federal legislation.

Meanwhile, south of the border in New South Wales—the state with the oldest enterprise bargaining legislation—only seven per cent coverage of state award workers has been achieved. There is some 55 per cent coverage in the federal jurisdiction. In Western Australia just six per cent coverage has been attained. In Tasmania, it is a paltry one per cent. South Australia has just enacted reforms similar to those of the other failed state models.

In Victoria, agreements in individual contracts remain a state secret. Yet the exodus of 400,000 people to the federal system is certainly no secret, nor are the desperate attempts of Minister Gude to stop his own Employee Relations Commission reinstating compulsory arbitration or the fact that up to 87 per cent of Victorian state employees remain under lapsed state awards.

These are the same people who like to give the federal government advice on workplace reform at gatherings such as MOLAC and COAG. The federal government has got some advice for them: look at the numbers, admit defeat, and follow Queensland in enacting legislation that is complementary with the federal model—legislation that guarantees award protection and guarantees the application of a no disadvantage test. Only then will employees under the state systems have the confidence to move into the bargaining stream.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister now concede failure in his efforts to deal with the problem of Australia's current account deficit, which reached $1.8 billion last month? Does the Prime Minister agree that this problem is only set to get worse, given rising international interest rates and the effect of rising imports of capital goods for investment?

—The answer to that question is certainly in the negative. Today's figures do show a widening of the current account deficit in seasonally adjusted terms to $1.8 billion from $1.5 billion over the month of June. This widening is largely attributable to an increase in the merchandise trade deficit, with imports up three per cent and exports down by three per cent in the month. It is, after all, only one month's figures. Even so, it is clear that the current account deficit has been widening in a trend sense over some recent months.
—The debt's getting bigger.
—Your donkey has asked the question. Why don't you just wait to hear the answer?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order!

—This should not be surprising because we have a really strong economy on our hands. What is more surprising—in fact, pleasantly surprising—is the degree to which the structural improvement that we have introduced into this economy has limited the rise in the current account deficit. In this sort of environment, particularly at a five per cent rate of growth, one would normally see imports tearing away and the current account deficit getting to the point where it starts to become a critical problem. What we are seeing this time is a limitation in the rise.

PARA.TAB: Let me give some examples. The current account deficit for 1993-94 as a whole was $16.4 billion, which was below the $18 billion forecast in the 1993-94 budget. This was achieved despite growth being much stronger. So the current account for the year—not the month—was below the budget forecast in the environment of an even stronger economy. The Treasury expects some increase in the deficit this year but, unlike some episodes in the past, the increase is expected to be limited, with a result in the current account deficit of about $18 billion over the year or about four per cent of GDP.

The question is: why should this be so? The answer is that we have a more competitive economy these days. There is much more competition than in the past, which is in part because of the government's efforts in knocking over the tariff wall and getting cheaper imports. In fact, we are now 30 per cent more competitive than we were a decade ago. We have been exporting our heads off for years. We can now import compete because of enhanced competition and low inflation. Exports of elaborately transformed manufactures were up strongly again last year by 16 per cent.

As I said, today's numbers confirm the strength of the economy. It is the same message that we saw in last week's investment figures. In the month of July, the growth in imports showed up in consumption, capital and intermediate goods. For the three months to July, compared with the same period a year earlier, imports of capital goods as a whole increased by 15.6 per cent. Importantly, the increase was across machinery and industrial equipment, up 17 per cent; ADP equipment, up 12.3 per cent; telecommunications equipment, up 19.8 per cent; and industrial transport equipment, up 35 per cent. These increases have an impact on the current account deficit, but they are there to underpin the continuing growth in the economy from investment which comes from the importation of this kind of capital equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you mention foreign debt?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has asked his question.

—The Leader of the Opposition has become rather quiet when it comes to investment. A week or so ago, he and the shadow Treasurer were out there trying to talk the economy down, saying that the investment in business was very gradual. Then he said that it was very disappointing. In fact, investment is up eight per cent in real terms in the June quarter to be 11 per cent higher than a year earlier and he still says that it is disappointing. Every time some good news comes out, he winces because he thinks that it is diametrically opposed to his interests out there doomsaying. As well as that, expectations for investment in 1994-95 were up strongly, supporting the budget forecasted growth for the year of around 15 per cent.

PARA.TAB: So what do we have? We have strong growth, a very discernible and strong pick-up in investment and a pick-up in equipment imports. Despite that growth, we have a limited rise in the current account deficit by virtue of the fact that the economy is so much more competitive. In fact, it is 30 per cent more competitive. They are the things that our friends in the coalition know that they could do nothing about. They could not deal with double digit inflation. They did not know what to do with the so-called real wage overhang. They left the tariff wall up for years. During the Fraser years, they lifted it higher. Now that we are seeing this performance in the economy, they are generally bewildered.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. What is the minister's response to the statement by the President of the Australian Medical Association, Dr Brendan Nelson, that the issue of land must be addressed if lasting improvements in Aboriginal health are to be achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lawrence The Hon C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Moreton for his question because it is a sentiment with which I agree wholeheartedly. It is a sentiment that the government has endorsed wholeheartedly too through its Mabo legislation. Just to inform the members of the House of Dr Brendan Nelson's sentiments, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: You certainly won't achieve an improvement to health if you are simply trying to throw doctors and penicillin at the problem.
We need to be looking at housing, education and employment programs for Aboriginal people and also land ownership which spiritually means a great deal to Aboriginal people.

That is a sentiment that intelligent Australians everywhere endorse. I was very pleased, therefore, when I read that, during the trip that the opposition leader took to central Australia, he was apparently persuaded of this point as well. I understand particularly that the doctor at Utopia explained to the Leader of the Opposition that secure access to land brought about significant health benefits. The doctor went on to say that the cost of medical evacuations and in-patient treatment at Utopia, where there is land ownership, was less than 50 per cent of other communities—a very tangible demonstration.

PARA.TAB: Following that weekend, the opposition leader—I am pleased to say this—in his regular column in the Adelaide Sunday Mail, wrote:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . I accept that land, and the special relationship between indigenous Australians and the land, is an integral and indispensable component of indigenous health and welfare.
I think that deserves to be repeated. I hope the opposition leader will take the opportunity to do so at some time.

PARA.TAB: It is now time that this rhetoric is matched by action. The challenge is before those in the opposition parties to actually agree to the legislation which will see the establishment of a land fund. Having failed to vote appropriately on the Mabo legislation, they now have the opportunity to take the decision in their party room tomorrow to ensure that they support the establishment of a land fund.

The Leader of the Opposition has apparently been convinced of the importance of land to Aboriginal people, both spiritually and in terms of their health and welfare. The time has come for some action. The rhetoric is not sufficient; we now need to see the colour of their money when it comes to the Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister. As the minister responsible for regional development, does he support calls for the maintenance of important public assets—which are natural monopolies according to the Left—such as regional airports, to be retained in the public sector or does he agree with the transport minister that such proposals are economic fantasia?

—I thank the Leader of the National Party for his question. Obviously, regional factors are extremely important in the government's approach to airports. The minister responsible for transport has emphasised that, and it is a fact that I agree with. We need to look at airport development, the maintenance of airports and their national and international significance. We also need to be aware of their importance in regional development. I can conclude quite happily that I agree with the Minister for Transport.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister assure the House that the government intends to continue to honour Australia's international treaty obligations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the great majority of Australians believe that we should honour these obligations. I think the great majority take pride in the fact that Australia is a truly liberal society in principle and in deed. I would like to quote a current Australian political leader, who said:

ANSWER.PARA: There are United Nations definitions of human rights which are objective standards which we adhere to and we have to adhere to, that other countries are required to adhere to as well, and should those be transgressed, it is appropriate for us to make representations about that.

That is very much the government's position. In no small way, our capacity and our right to have a say in what happens in the world, and particularly in our region, depend on our observance of these international treaties. In fact, our moral authority depends on it. It is no less important from the point of view of our own national cohesiveness. I am talking about our sense of belonging to a society which is tolerant and free and the pride we take in this.

PARA.TAB: I am talking about our sense of belonging to an advanced society, a progressive society, and a phobia-free, unprejudiced society; a society which is not afraid to acknowledge reality and difference; a society which is willing to apply to all Australians the same principles of tolerance and freedom. It is a very important test of a society to do these things. It is a test which we have passed over and over again in recent years.

This is a country which I think has thrown off the narrowness and prejudice which used to dog us, and which some governments, particularly state governments, sometimes catered to or even encouraged. The Commonwealth government will not be catering to it. The Commonwealth government will meet its obligations. I began by quoting an Australian political leader of recent times. Let me quote him again. It puts the government's view precisely:

ANSWER.PARA: Well, once you've signed a convention, I think I'm right in saying, in most cases under international law that is that. There is not much you can do about it.
Here is the same political leader again:

This is a fundamentally important issue. The issue of privacy is one of the most important that this country needs to address at any time. On this side of the House we are serious about privacy. We are serious about protecting the privacy of the individual.
Who said this? Who was it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Me.

—He has identified himself: the member for Mayo. The leader—or, to use his own words, `the most honest and open man you will ever meet'; this is what he said recently in an ABC interview—believes in our treaty obligations, except where they are politically inconvenient. This is the Leader of the Liberal Party, which swears on the bible of Bob Menzies that it places the rights of the individuals above the rights of the states—of course, unless the state is Tasmania. So here are those opposite on the 50th anniversary of the Liberal Party, 50 years on from 1944—and one thing that you would always say they said they believed in was the right of the individuals!

PARA.TAB: The person opposite says he is sufficiently honest to live by his own stated principles—but he is not sufficiently strong to stare down the states, particularly the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Groom, and the Premier of Western Australia. It seems to us that the federal Liberal Party is completely intimidated by its state counterparts. On the weekend, the Leader of the Opposition dismissed his shadow industry minister for supposedly breaching policy. But what was the so-called team position he was supposed to have breached on this?

TALK.START.PARA: —He acted with gay abandon.

—I do not think it was abandon. I think he was actually trying to articulate a policy in the absence of some leadership. Instead of the opposition leader seeking to petulantly make a point by dismissing him, he would have been better to give the lead and create some unity by developing a policy. The fundamental problem for the coalition, on this issue as on everything else, is that it is catastrophically and hatefully divided. It is irretrievably split. It is a party absolutely riven by hatred and infected with dispute.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145 on relevance. This question was specifically about whether the government would honour its international treaty obligations. For the last three minutes now the Prime Minister has not made one mention of that. I ask you to draw him back to the question.

—The Prime Minister was asked a question in the terms to which the honourable member has referred. But, as I have remarked, as have previous Speakers, ministers—and, indeed, the Prime Minister—may contrast that. I invite him to do so in his answer, but also to bring it to a close.

—All around the smoky, leather-padded reading rooms of the Melbourne and Adelaide clubs they are saying today, `Oh, God, we've done it again.' The Liberals cannot afford another leadership crisis, yet they cannot afford to stay with the leader they have. The fact is that the Leader of the Opposition has taken the Howard-Peacock virus and infected all the younger generation of parliamentarians. The old leadership disputes and acrimonies will now go down another layer to the younger members of the frontbench, himself included, so to prove the point.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, in all the years I have been in this chamber there has always been the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Bob Hawke think of you?
—The honourable member for O'Connor is not in his right seat.

—That is whom you would recognise from the chair. But though those opposite represent themselves as one party, they are simply a number of parties that are, as I said, catastrophically divided. Let me conclude where I started.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition is not helping.

—For a party that believes in the rights of the individual, it will be a very interesting test to see where the Leader of the Opposition votes on the government's legislation—to see whether the rights of individuals will remain paramount in the minds of members of the Liberal Party or whether it will be the rights of state coalition premiers to basically compel the federal Liberal Party to dance to their tune. It will be a very interesting test.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Is the left wing's plan for a Clayton's privatisation of airports dead and buried, or has the minister been told this morning to back off?

—That question would really knock your socks off. I think there is a considerable amount of merit in encouraging local government participation in regional airports and in some of the general aviation councils.

PARA.TAB: Mr Costello interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking up the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I do not think that because Kingsford Smith airport in Sydney is located smack bang in the middle of Botany municipal council it is the right body to acquire it. In terms of the major airports—

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right; they are trying very hard.
—Order!
—It seems to me—

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister is not helping either.

—Whilst it is entirely appropriate for local government to be encouraged to take an interest in regional and GA airports, it is really inappropriate to see a situation where only the state or local government concerned could bid for the major city airports. There are real limitations in having only the Queensland government or the Brisbane City Council being able to acquire Brisbane airport. Similarly, to say that Tullamarine could be sold only to the Kennett government, or, for that matter, Mascot to the Fahey government, has its limitations, because it would be very much a buyer's market. It would guarantee that one did not realise the government's objectives in trying to realise a proper value in respect of these airports.

PARA.TAB: For all those reasons, I think the debate is progressing in a most constructive way. I am absolutely confident that at the end of the day the government will meet its budgetary projections and we will see the introduction of benchmark competition between the airports of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to press reports of proposals for special new taxation concessions and reports that these taxation concessions would be paid for by improving the efficiency of the delivery of government services? Can the minister advise the House about the feasibility of funding major new taxation concessions by that means? What are the government's intentions with regard to these proposals?

—Yes, I have seen the proposals. They relate to a report of a speech made this month by the Leader of the Opposition—an advocate of strong views, weakly held—to a group of people assembled by the Australian Financial Review for a discussion on where the opposition wishes to take us on economic policy. In the course of his remarks, which are headlined, `Libs set to scrap tax on bank interest', the Leader of the Opposition indicated that that was one of the concessions he would contemplate and he would take it further than the proposition expressed in Fightback. The Liberals costed their proposition in Fightback at $500 million. When the Leader of the Opposition said that he would establish tax breaks for bank interest, the building societies, the credit unions, the cash management trusts, et cetera, pointed out that the breaks would break them and therefore they had to be included. Instead of backing off the promise, the opposition subsequently expanded it.

PARA.TAB: In the same speech, the Leader of the Opposition also promised tax breaks for small business, families, health insurance and exporters and a softer fringe benefits tax system. The Australian Financial Review was so impressed by this list of tax breaks—unlike just about everything else that the Leader of the Opposition has been going around the place spouting at the moment both on the expenditure and tax breaks side—that it costed all the tax breaks and came to the conclusion that he was offering a $10 billion to $12 billion hole in the budget. That was the estimate of the Australian Financial Review and, if you look through those tax arrangements, you can understand why it would arrive at that figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got a hole in your budget and you are the government.
—The Leader of the Opposition will not interject across the table.
—He has got a hole in his budget.
—And he will not argue the toss.

—At the same time as his boss is putting his views forward, the other member of the dream team has been going around the countryside saying to us that the government is doing the wrong thing about its budget deficit. But the boss has a view as to how he is going to pay for that. He is going to pay for that by making savings in the area of running costs. I tabled last week the document on our final budget outcome. Non-defence salaries last year paid out by the government amounted to $4.9 billion. So, if you sacked every single public servant in Australia and you assumed an efficiency gain of infinity via that process—quite a spectacular gesture in the running cost area—you would come to about half of the propositions that the opposition has put forward.

PARA.TAB: I have tried to find a copy of this speech which was so marvellously reported, but it has disappeared. It has become the scarlet pimpernel of speeches as far as we are concerned—you seek it here, you seek it there, you seek it everywhere, but it does not appear. It is rather like the future directions document; perhaps the speech is in the same category. We heard how the opposition was going to handle future directions when it came down. It was going to be handled by some Liberal Party version of Kim's game—that Rudyard Kipling training proposal for intelligence services—where you put 20 policies on a tray, stare at them for one minute, withdraw the tray and try to remember the 20 policies that were on it.

The opposition has learned from its experience with Dr Hewson. It is going to have access to Fightback mark 3 and there is going to be only one copy. It is going to be tabled in the opposition party rooms and opposition members are going to be allowed to sit down and read it for some time. They are not going to be allowed to take notes; it is going to be a test of their memories when they go out to leak its content. No doubt, at the time of its public release by the strong views, weakly held leader, you can guarantee that the Prime Minister will be out of the country. I just want to assure opposition members that we are always available to cost their policies. We assure them that, when they bring down future directions, we will perform the same service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Human Services and Health. A petition of over half a million citizens has been presented to this House concerning tax credits or rebates to encourage private health care funding. Irrespective of whether the government considers that this is not in the public interest, why has the government ignored the specific request of the petitioners? Will the minister make a ministerial statement on this issue, allowing the question to be fully debated in the House rather than in the media?

—I think that this is a very public debate and, in any case, I am more than happy to have it debated in the House at any time. No doubt it will be once the government announces the package of reforms under the private health insurance banner.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that there are sections of the community, including the shadow spokeswoman on health, who believe that tax rebates are a panacea for reforming the private health sector. I remind members that, in addition to the loss of revenue that the Minister for Finance has just outlined, we have seen some very extravagant spending promises and tax rebate promises from the opposition in this area, including somewhere between $1.5 billion and $3 billion worth of tax rebates and gap insurance, the effect of which would be to seriously run down the public side of the health system.

I do not believe that tax rebates are a successful way of dealing with private health insurance, and the extent of that will be seen when cabinet considers a package of measures to have a genuinely competitive industry, with premiums kept to a reasonable level, access for everybody, but not at the expense of the public health system. If anyone wants to tell me that the way to go is to rip somewhere between $1.5 and $3 billion out of the public health system and put it into the pockets of individuals—not those individuals, by the way, who are pensioners and on low incomes, because they do not get tax rebates—I will not believe them, because that is not a solution.

The commentators who are now having a good hard look at these rebate proposals—I draw the attention of honourable members to Australian Business Monthly, amongst others—have clearly come to the conclusion that the opposition in this case has only one policy in the area of health, and that is to bring in tax rebates. I urge the member opposite responsible for this area to lift her game, because we do deserve a debate in this House and we do deserve a debate in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has the minister seen an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Mr Ross Gittins concerning the national training wage? Will employers be discouraged from accessing the national training wage, as the article claims? What action is the government taking to ensure that traineeships are more readily available to young Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Oxley for his question. Yes, I have seen the article today. In answer to the second part of the question, no, the concerns that Mr Gittins says are being raised by employers are not being raised. Mr Gittins's assessment in this article has not been based on the usual dedication and commitment to research that normally goes into his articles. Mr Gittins was a very strong supporter of the training wage. Back in June he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The training wage is a brilliant and bold attempt to cut through all these problems—
and deliver a big improvement in fairly short order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us go to the issue that is now so exciting my opposition counterpart. Mr Gittins also said:

ANSWER.PARA: For many awards, the new youth training wage rates are much higher than the present rates.

That is just not correct. That statement misleads because it does not compare like with like. A training wage for which a day a week on the job is undertaken in training is being compared with a previous set of training wages where two days off the job were involved, and the rate was discounted to 75 per cent. If those opposite want to have the academic argument that 80 per cent of something is more than 75 per cent of something, I will concede it. But let us understand the detail of what we have done with the training wage.

PARA.TAB: There used to exist, and still do, training wages for youth under different guises. The fact of the matter is that the take-up for those has not been great. Why? Because the training rates are complex; they are not easily accessible by employers; employers complain about the red tape associated with accessing them; they require the work and the training to be undertaken off the job; and they do not give proper recognition to the enterprise focus, the needs of individual employers and firms in identifying the training they want.

The white paper has effectively corrected all of these deficiencies. It has simplified the structure. In the process, it has introduced as well the historic breakthrough in establishing a training wage for adults. It has cut the red tape through NETTFORCE and it has provided the ability for on-the-job training to qualify for access to the training wage. In addition, we as a government have committed to funding a capacity for 50,000 extra training places. We are absolutely committed to simplifying the system in a way which did not exist under the previous arrangements and to ensuring that there are additional resources.

In terms of our commitment to youth unemployment in this country, it is not only the training wage that one has to take account of but also the youth training initiative. This initiative is essentially a guarantee of vocational preparation through the school, the workplace or training programs, or a combination of those, and will not give the young people of this country the choice of exercising the option of the dole. What we are doing is using that combination of education, training, workplace activity and experience to develop the genuine competencies of young people and recognise those competencies around which the youth training wage has been struck.

I concede that youth unemployment is a major issue still facing this country, but we as a government are committed to tackling it. We want to make the entry of young people into the work force much easier, but we also want to make it much more attractive to the employer. The combination of vocational preparation through the youth training initiative, the training wage and the greater enterprise focus will help us achieve it. That is why employers are supporting what we are doing. That is why they want a speedy decision through the Industrial Relations Commission to sanction the training wage. Then they can access it with the combination of other initiatives that the white paper presents. Together this will ensure that we create new opportunities for young people in this country. It will ensure that we do not waste their opportunities and talents in the way that they have been passed over and ignored in the past. I commend to those on the other side of the House to look at the detail of this measure and support these initiatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Could the minister please answer this one before we all go to sleep?
—Order! The honourable member for Goldstein will get to his question or resume his seat.

—I refer to the recent appointment of Mrs Joan Kirner to the $104,000 a year job as chair of the Employment Services Regulatory Authority. The minister would be aware that this is a demanding job, requiring a great deal of travel. Was the government aware that Mrs Kirner pleaded ill health in her efforts to increase her superannuation payout by $360,000? Was the government aware of Mrs Kirner's complaints about ill health when it appointed her to this onerous position? Has this matter been discussed with Mrs Kirner? Are there any compensation arrangements in Mrs Kirner's contract if she has to leave her latest job in case of ill health?

—The answer to the honourable member's question is this: the issues concerning Mrs Kirner were discussed with her before her appointment. The question of her arrangements and her remuneration is determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. You assert the basis upon which she says she is claiming additional moneys for superannuation, but the important point that needs to be understood about her appointment to this position is that this is a major plank in the government's commitment to getting the long-term unemployed back into work.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Those on my left! The minister has the call.
—The difficulty—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister might resume his seat for a moment. The House will come to order!

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition again is not helping. The minister has the call and will be heard in silence.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. This really says something of those on the other side. It is very hard to get them seriously involved in the debates associated with the key issues facing the long-term unemployed in this country. What they want to do is concentrate on the circumstances of appointment to this very important body. I have given the member the indication that I did discuss this with Mrs Kirner and I am satisfied that she can fulfil the role. Otherwise I would not have appointed her. I did ask the question.

PARA.TAB: Mr Pyne interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Sturt!

—I would actually like to hear my shadow counterpart say something supportive of the importance of case management in getting the long-term unemployed back into work and of the structure under which ESRA will not only ensure that case management is delivered effectively by the Commonwealth Employment Service but will also open up the delivery of that service to private competition. It is about time you on the other side got involved with the real issues of importance to this country, stopped crying crocodile tears about the long-term unemployed and got behind the initiatives that are going to give them a real chance to get back into the work force.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Further to my question last week on the home child-care allowance, can the minister provide details of some typical families who will gain from the introduction of the home child-care allowance on 29 September?

—I would like to begin by referring to a totally inaccurate report that appeared in Saturday's Melbourne Herald-Sun, which claimed that some families could be $1,500 a year worse off as a result of this change.

PARA.TAB: Mr Pyne interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the member for Sturt.

—That is absolutely wrong and completely fails to take into account the fact that families unable to access HCCA will be able to fall back on the dependent spouse rebate. The people who might lose quite marginal amounts under the new arrangements are massively outweighed by the 800,000 or so people who will benefit from the general rate increase.

PARA.TAB: In fact, the converse is true. It is certainly not true that people can lose $1,500 as a result of the changed system, but there are certain families in realistic scenarios who can gain in excess of $1,500 as a result of the new arrangements. To give an example, one which bears on the opposition spokesperson's speech the other day about families where one earner moves in and out of the work force, if you take the case of a couple where the wife leaves the work force for a year, say, in January 1995, to have a child and then re-enters full-time work in January 1996, that family would not be eligible in either of the two financial years involved to receive any benefit from the dependent spouse rebate because the income for the part year precludes that.

However, for the 12-month period from January 1995 through to January 1996, that family would be able to receive the home child-care allowance, which would provide them with a benefit in that calendar year in excess of $1,500. So it is not the case that you can end up $1,500 behind—that is rubbish—but it is the case, in quite realistic circumstances, that you can end up $1,500 ahead. That is one example of the very substantial gain that the new structure provides.

Take a low income family where the primary earner gets $8,000 a year. It might be a self-employed business person; it might be a farmer. Under the existing DSR arrangements, the tax liability of $20 a fortnight would be eliminated by the operation of the dependent spouse rebate. Under our new arrangements, they will have to pay that extra tax of $20 a fortnight. However, on the other side of the ledger, they will benefit from getting $60 a fortnight through the home child-care allowance. In other words, they will be $40 a fortnight better off, over $1,000 a year better off. These are the sorts of gains that people potentially stand to accrue as a result of this changed arrangement, apart from the general increase that the maximum home child-care allowance represents over and above the dependent spouse rebate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. In view of his answer to the previous question, exactly what discussions did he have with Mrs Kirner? When did he have them? Did she alert him to the problem of ill health which she has claimed? Did she produce any medical evidence for him? PARA.TAB: Mr McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gippsland is not helping.

—I asked her whether she felt she could perform the job—it would involve a full-time activity in the first couple of years at least—and she assured me that she could. But, most importantly, she is committed to doing the task. She has the belief in the importance of this activity and is prepared to preside over a board that will see the implementation of a significant and world leading direction for handling the long-term unemployed. PARA.TAB: If people doubt Mrs Kirner's commitment and understanding of both labour market programs and working with people, then they are blind to the facts. Mr Reith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have appointed a lot from your side of the House, too—Warwick Smith, Fred Chaney, Peter Baume, Sally-Anne Atkinson, Malcolm Fraser, Nick Greiner—whom I see sitting in the gallery—and Janine Haines. This is a government that is prepared to look at the talents of people who are available and to make sure that, when their political life has ended, we do not waste that talent; we draw on it and turn it to advantage. I can assure the House that Mrs Kirner's talents will be turned to advantage, and she will play a major role in helping the long-term unemployed get the personal attention that is absolutely needed to get them back into the work force.
—Mr Speaker, on the same subject—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—the opposition—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister might just wait for a moment. I will get some order. The Prime Minister may add to a minister's answer.

—On the same subject of, as you are alleging, looking after people, you might tell us what the criteria is for getting a casino licence in Victoria. Perhaps you can enlighten us on that subject while you are at it.
—I call the honourable member for Reid.
—Mr Speaker, my question—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Reid has the call.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. The government's better cities program is now three years old.
—Cain and Kirner appointed the tribunal.
—I warn the honourable member for Kooyong!
—Can the minister inform the House on the infrastructure and employment benefits generated from the Commonwealth's initial $816 million investment in this program?

—I thank the honourable member for his question concerning the better cities program. A recent evaluation of the program produced, from the shadow spokesman for the opposition, the comment that the program had produced unnecessary tension between all levels of government and communities and created monuments which seemed to do little, if anything, to enhance the standard of living.

PARA.TAB: The better cities program reflects the capacity of the government to develop innovative and creative programs that have achieved cooperation not only between the three levels of government but also between the public and private sectors. The initial $816 million investment will generate a total of $1.5 billion in state government investment and local government investment and over $2.5 billion in private sector investment.

I am sure that the honourable member for Bonython would attest to the fact that, as a result of the catalytic impact of better cities, there have been significant changes with the revitalisation of the northern suburbs of Adelaide, much greater diversity in housing types, increased levels of home ownership affordability in terms of upgraded houses for low income earners and a demonstration in terms of Delfin of the reshaping of housing stock, which has been important in generating $30 million investment and representing a model right around Australia. Secondly, better cities has generated more than 50,000 jobs. The programs and the output of those programs will mean something like 50,000 ongoing jobs.

Thirdly, it is important to take the example of the Brisbane to Gold Coast corridor and the construction of heavy rail, the most significant suburban heavy rail project to take place in the postwar period. The $400 million project will help to service a shire, Albert shire, which is growing more rapidly than any other urban area in Australia and will double its population to about 280,000 over the next decade.

The Gold Coast to Brisbane railway line will provide a basis for planning and reinforce the SEQ 2000 set of plans, probably the most imaginative set of plans developed by any state government around Australia, and one that builds in a forecast of the need for resource allocation and the need to build that development around rail infrastructure.

So rather than the better cities program being a program which has resulted in tensions between the Commonwealth and state governments, it has been a model of cooperation between Commonwealth, state and local government. It has resulted in significant levels of infrastructure expenditure, more than $5 billion. It has been a catalyst for significant change. It will have a significant demonstration effect in providing new patterns of urban development right around Australia as we face the challenges of urbanisation in the 1990s.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Day
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

PETITION.PARA: The Anzacs at the Gallipoli landing on 25 April 1915 were instrumental in forging a new identity for Australia. That landing was a lifetime ago but the deeds of those Anzacs of 1915-18 still speak a message of selfless service and sacrifice that will last forever.

Anzac Day is a day to remember those who left their homes with a strong desire to return but did not, as well as those who did return, but in so doing carried for the remainder of their lives the scars of these experiences.

It is a day to contemplate the spirit that moves men and women to serve, to suffer discomforts, dangers and fears and to risk their lives in defence of their country and in the pursuit of peace, justice and freedom.

On Anzac Day, we salute not only the spirit of the Anzacs but, in paying tribute to them, we take the opportunity to dedicate ourselves to striving for our country as they did and to upholding their finest qualities of courage, commitment, endurance and mateship.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House urge the Government to declare Anzac day as Australia's National Day of Commemoration and that it be held on 25 April in each year, and on no other day.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the Child Support Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House enact the following changes:

PARA.TAB: 1. That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

2. That The Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel, the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
3. That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
4. That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
5. That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
6. That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

7. That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
