PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia:
(a)deplores the fact that six Australian women per day die from breast cancer and notes the possibility of contracting breast cancer is as high as one chance in twelve for Australian women;
(b)recognises the fact that breast cancer has the potential to affect every Australian family;
(c)recognises that there are inadequate research funds available to help combat breast cancer;

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representatives call on the government to:

PARA.TAB: (a)increase funding for breast cancer research 10-fold (a minimum of $14 million) in the 1994/95 Budget; and
(b)consider further initiatives through the tax system to encourage donations for breast cancer research.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman (from 14 citizens), Mr Cobb (from 10 citizens), Mr Downer (from 12 citizens), Mr Richard Evans (from 12 citizens), Mr Filing (from eight citizens), Mr Forrest (from seven citizens), Mr Hawker (from 144 citizens), Dr Hewson (from 79 citizens), Mrs Moylan (from 175 citizens), Mr Nehl (from 427 citizens), Mr Neville (from 180 citizens), Mr Tuckey (from 33 citizens), Mr Wakelin (from 11 citizens) and Ms Worth (from 3,566 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Homemakers Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned emphasises that:
1. The family unit is the most effective and most economic deliverer of primary welfare services.
2. The environment provided by the family is the most conducive to the nurturing of good citizens.

3. Studies conducted by organisations such as the Economic Planning Advisory Council demonstrate that single income families are disadvantaged, thus forcing more and more women into outside employment; hence, there is a strong case for economic assistance to enable women in the home to enjoy a measure of financial equality with women in the workforce.

Your petitioners ask that the House of Representatives enact legislation providing for the introduction of an indexed Homemakers Allowance of $130 per week, payable to a family in which one parent is engaged full time in the nurturing, caring for and raising of dependent children.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite (from 19 citizens) and Mr Forrest (from five citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Age for Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The petition of citizens and/or residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully show concern at the Commonwealth Government's intention to amend the Department of Social Security legislation to raise the age of women for pension eligibility from 60 to 65 because:

PETITION.PARA: The proposal is active economic discrimination against women
Women have a shorter paid working life than men
Women receive less than equal pay
Women have less access to superannuation
The proposal does not recognise the value of women's unpaid labour

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House intercede on behalf of the Petitioners to:
Ensure that women remain eligible for age pension at the age of 60.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Gorman (from 125 citizens) and Mr Nehl (from 74 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the House of Representatives ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker (from 198 citizens) and Mr Jull (from 228 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern that the Australian Flag, also known as the "Flag of Stars", should:
1.not be changed without the consultation of the people of Australia through a Referendum

2.continue to portray Australia's heritage by displaying the Union Jack in the upper left hand corner which itself portrays the red cross of Saint George and England, the white diagonal cross of Saint Andrew of Scotland and the red diagonal of Saint Patrick of Ireland.
3.continue to portray our religion and our democratic system of government by retaining the Union Jack
4.continue to display the Southern Cross under which we live as it is only visible in the Southern Hemisphere and is believed to shine brightest over Australian night skies
5.continue to depict the Commonwealth of Australia as represented by the large star at the bottom, each point of which represents the States and Territories of Australia.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that:
1.By Act, Parliament ensure that the Prime Minister of Australia cannot change the Flag of Australia without the majority consent of the people of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they object to:

PARA.TAB: The appointment of a committee to enable the establishment of a republic without any consultation with the people of Australia as to whether:
(a) it was their preference to dispense with the Constitutional Monarchy; and
(b) the composition of the committee should be evenly balanced in outlook and not overwhelmingly biased towards a republic

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House request the Government to desist from any action which is capable of deeply dividing the people of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: CSIRO: Agricultural Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament.
The petition of certain residents of the state of Western Australia being members of staff at CSIRO's Division of Animal Production,

draws to the attention of the House the serious consequences of the significant reduction in Australian research and development on agriculture particularly within CSIRO. Unless this decline is reversed or arrested, Australia stands to lose much of its unique expertise in agricultural research. The value of this market is currently estimated at around $20 billion per annum and is guaranteed to increase with the growth of South-East Asian economy. The Agricultural Industry cannot continue to be a significant export earner for Australia without significant R & D to underpin its status as clean and efficient.
Your petitioner therefore request the House to act to assign a higher priority and greater funding for agricultural research in CSIRO.

PETITION.TITLE: CSIRO: Agricultural Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the state of New South Wales, being members of staff of CSIRO's Division of Animal Production draws to the attention of the House the serious consequences of the significant reduction in Australian research and development on agriculture. With the current decline, CSIRO stands to lose many highly trained research staff with unique expertise in animal based research.

Agricultural research in CSIRO promotes the sustainable use of Australia's extensive natural resources to make food products and clothing materials for local and export markets. Investment in the research of CSIRO's Institute of Animal Production and Processing will significantly increase Australia's export earnings from high value-added meat and premium wool products, with a current net export value of $8.6 billion each year.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to act to assign a higher priority and greater funding for agricultural research in CSIRO.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS TV: Kalgoorlie
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain electors of the Division of Kalgoorlie:

PETITION.PARA: Draws to the attention of the House that they are not yet able to receive television broadcasts from the SBS network and are therefore further disadvantaged and deprived by reason of their remote location which already inhibits their participation in and enjoyment of many events with cultural, entertainment and sporting significance and standing both nationally and internationally.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request the House to bring our concern to the attention of the minister responsible with a view to his directing the early correction of the above omission.

PETITION.TITLE: School Building Funds
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the Federal Seat of Prospect draws to the attention of the House the limited applicability of School Building Fund monies.

Income tax concessions when making donations to School Building Funds is restricted in so far as such monies can only be claimed as tax deductions if money is used for "public funds established and maintained exclusively for providing money for the acquisition, construction or maintenance of a building used or to be used as a school or college by a government or public authority or by a society or association which is carried on otherwise than for the purposes of profit or gain to the individual members of that society or association." s 78(1)(a)(xv).
Monies donated to libraries, Public Hospitals, Royal Australian College of Surgeons or Physicians, etc. do not have such a strictly defined area of use for monies collected.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House approve that costs associated with public utilities (i.e. water, gas, electricity, sewerage and telephone) and insurance costs be included as a legitimate expenditure of the monies raised from tax deducted sources for schools.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia:
(a)deplores the fact that six Australian women per day die from breast cancer and notes the possibility of contracting breast cancer is as high as one chance in sixteen for Australian women;
(b)recognises the fact that breast cancer has the potential to effect every Australian family;
(c)recognises that there are inadequate research funds available to help combat breast cancer;
(d)notes that extent of research funding expenditure on other medical conditions with significantly lower mortality rates such as the HIV virus;
(e)calls on the Federal Government to provide more funds for breast cancer research; and,

(f)recommends that the Government introduces tax incentives for donations to breast cancer research in the order of 150% to encourage community support to help eliminate this disease and to increase the availability of research funds.
We therefore pray that the Parliament take steps to ensure that greater resources are made available for research into breast cancer.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the anomaly in the Resident Classification Instrument of nursing home residents. At present, funding to nursing homes is penalised by not allowing points for assistance to residents who are too ill or frail to be placed on a toilet or commode. This often means that the resident will be designated a lower category and therefore attract less funding although the care required may be excessive.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House review the Resident Classification Instrument in relation to Continence Management and the toiletting process so that equitable funding will enable the delivery of quality care to the incontinent frail person.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:
Your petitioners pray that the House urge the government to—
Please keep Anzac Day on the 25th April and not lose its significance by making it the nearest `weekend holiday'. It is a day of remembrance and should remain so.
We the undersigned wish this request be so.

PETITION.TITLE: Mount Stirling
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the legislative assembly in parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the state of Victoria sheweth that Mount Stirling being an undeveloped mountain available to all Victorian citizens for a wide range of recreational wilderness experiences and activities is under threat of being developed as a downhill ski resort with ski lifts, the associated infrastructure and a gondola linking Mount Stirling with nearby Mount Buller.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Mount Stirling be forever protected from such mechanical gondola, ski lifts and associated infrastructure and it be preserved for all time.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Agency: Hinton
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members in parliament assembled:
We the undersigned residents of New South Wales and Hinton humbly petition and request Parliament to retain the services of the postal agency at Hinton.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Grant in Aid Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament.
The petition of residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House the necessity of having a:

PARA.TAB: Grant in aid worker at Christian Community Aid Service Inc. Eastwood.
The non-English speaking background migrants residing in the Epping, Eastwood, Ryde and surrounding areas require the services of a G.I.A. worker to assist with settlement needs.
The NESB population of Epping, Eastwood, Ryde and surrounding areas is rapidly increasing.
There are no ethno-specific associations for migrant workers, nor migrant resource centres in the Epping, Eastwood, Ryde and surrounding areas to enable the needs of NESB migrants to be met.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House continue to fund the G.I.A. program at Christian Community Aid Service Inc. Eastwood.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Treaties
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that Australia is now a signatory to more than 2100 international treaties, conventions and agreements, which, once ratified, bind Australia by international law to implement and to abide by them.

While accepting that it is necessary for Australia to subscribe to many of these agreements if it is to participate freely and effectively as a member of the international community, we are concerned that such agreements are signed and ratified by the Executive Government without first being referred to the Australian Parliament for inquiry or debate.
We are further concerned that there is no provision in the Australian Constitution for such a course of action to be followed by the Executive Government.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will:

1.request the Executive Government to immediately place a moratorium on the signing and ratification of any further international treaties, conventions and agreements unless they have been examined by Parliament;

2.request that the moratorium remain in place until such time as the people of Australia have been asked, by way of a referendum, whether they will support an amendment to the Constitution to include a clause stating that all international treaties, conventions and agreements must be examined by the Parliament before they come into force in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: National Capital Plan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia and residents of the Australian Capital Territory draws the attention of the House to the provisions relating to Acton Peninsula and West Basin in the National Capital Plan 1990 (as amended on 2 January 1991), according to which the area is designated for a range of community uses.
Being concerned that this place is retained for public use, your petitioners therefore request the House to maintain unaltered the status of this nationally significant site.

PETITION.TITLE: Bears
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria draws to the attention of the House that approximately 8,000 bears are being kept in cages in China for the purpose of extracting bile for medical purposes and that the cages are so small the bears cannot move, which results in some of them going mad. It is further brought to the attention of the House that the Chinese plan to increase the number of bears, for these purposes, to 40,000.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to object most strongly to this horrendous and tragic practice and ask that steps be taken to stop it immediately.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: 1. We believe that our current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of our Nation's history.
2. Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note that our Constitution based, on the Monarchy, has:
ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:

PARA.TAB: a. There be no change in the design or colour of the Australian National Flag
b. Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia, as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Pass: Members of Parliament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws attention to the House the following matters:
1(a)We call for the immediate abolishment of Gold Passes (past, present and future) for retired Federal Members of Parliament.
(b)We call for the immediate abolishment of cars, offices, telephones etc., of retired MP's.

2.We call for a moratorium on all pay increases and "perks" for Members of Parliament and top bureaucrats for a period of five (5) years, and immediate disbanding of the so called Independent Remuneration Tribunal.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House

PETITION.PARA: will take these measures to stop Members of Parliament (past, present and future) from plundering the public purse.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Disability Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in parliament as assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the parents and supporters of children with Attention Deficit Disorder, being residents of Geelong, are concerned at the federal government's review of the eligibility criteria for the Child Disability Allowance.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the federal parliament calls on the Minister for Social Security, the Hon. Mr. Peter Baldwin MHR, to conduct thorough consultation with parent support groups like Geelong AddSup and adequately consider the significant care, attention and expense necessary to care for a child with ADD, compared to a child without a disability, and strongly urge that children with ADD continue to be deemed eligible for the CDA if they meet the current criteria.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain electors of the federal seat of Forrest draws to the attention of the House:

The intention of the Australian Heritage Commission to list two-thirds of the southern forest region of Western Australia (600,000 HA) on the register of the National Estate, including state forest managed for multiple use purposes outside the state reserve system totalling 30% of the available area.

Given the campaign by the WA Greens and their national counterparts to exclude timber harvesting from all National Estate forests and the failure of the Commonwealth government to recognise the CALM/AHC agreement as a definitive and comprehensive regional assessment process, your petitioners therefore request the House to:

Oppose the listing on the register of the National Estate of any forest or land outside the WA state reserve system until such time as a definitive and comprehensive regional assessment process is endorsed by both the state and Commonwealth governments.

PETITION.TITLE: Young Homeless Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1.We are concerned that teenagers are able to leave home by obtaining young homeless allowance without adequate investigation.
2.We believe that the flawed nature of the guidelines governing eligibility for young homeless allowance is in some circumstances encouraging family breakdown.

3.With the number of young people receiving young homeless allowance increasing by a factor of ten over the past six years, we consider that there are insufficient programmes to help keep families together.
Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representatives should call on the Government to:
(a) review the guidelines for young homeless allowance; and
(b) show a greater commitment to programmes which prevent family breakdown.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS TV: Stanthorpe
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: We, the electors of the Division of Maranoa, draw to the attention of the House the need for the installation of a SBS transmitter to be installed at Passchendaele Ridge, N.W. Stanthorpe for transmission in the Stanthorpe Shire.
Your petitions therefore request the House to allocate funding for this installation as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Mobile Net
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Maranoa draws to the attention of the House the need for Telecom Mobile Net to be made available to the Texas, Inglewood and Yelarbon areas in Queensland. Many businesses in the area are suffering financially because of the non availability of this facility. The extension of the Telecom Mobile Net would also provide access to greater security and emergency services.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to make the necessary arrangements for Telecom Mobile Net to be installed in the Texas, Inglewood and Yelarbon areas as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House our strongest support for the existing National Flag.
The Australian National Flag is the most important symbol of the Australian nation and our national unity, and has evoked deep feelings of honour and respect from many generations of Australians.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to preserve our current Australian National Flag and to ensure that its design is not changed without the support of a referendum carried by the majority of Australians in the majority of States.

PETITION.TITLE: Mabo
PETITION.PARA: To support a referendum on Mabo rights of State Governments and clearly defining land title.
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws attention of the House to the confusion over the Mabo High court decision and calls on Members to require the conduct of a Referendum to amend the Australian Constitution to reaffirm beyond doubt the rights of State Governments alone to define and issue land title.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposal to charge users of off-road diesel fuel a tax equal to one per cent of the amount rebated to them through the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme under the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

1. Users of off-road diesel fuel currently receive a full or partial rebate of fuel excise paid in recognition that they should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance in the same manner as on-road users of diesel fuel;
2. We object to being forced to pay fuel excise on diesel fuel and then being charged a tax, which the Government is calling an `administration fee', to have that money returned to us as a rebate;
3. This tax sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to governments charging similar taxes on rebates, such as those for personal income tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Schizophrenia: ORAP
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a grievance on behalf of a constituent of mine, Mr Richard Hoy of Ivanhoe. This grievance concerns the activities of the Canadian consulate and trade offices in Australia and indirectly concerns the activities of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

PARA.TAB: Briefly, the facts are these. In October 1990 Mr Hoy read an advertisement in the Sydney Morning Herald in which a franchise was offered by an entity known as Video Impact. In pertinent part, this advertisement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A Canadian success story comes to Australia
Video Impact
movie rental case advertising
Franchises available
93 and growing across Canada
Video Impact
c/o Mike Kelly
Canadian Consulate-General
Sydney

As a consequence of reading this advertisement, Mr Hoy made contact with the consulate. In fact, he contacted the consulate in Sydney on a number of occasions and was provided with some information, including a copy of a publication of the consulate entitled Business Canada. This document was published for the Canadian trade offices in Australia. It is volume 5, No. 3 of August 1990. On the first page of this document under the heading `Top franchisors in Australia next month' is an article which reads:

PARA.TAB: A team of eight highly successful franchisors from Canada is due in Melbourne and Sydney early next month, to mount a country exhibition at Australia's top franchise exhibition and hopefully appoint local master franchisees.
Managed by Ottawa-based Tom Van Camp of Industry, Science and Technology Canada, and in Australia managed by Mike Casey of the Canadian Consulate General—

SPEECH.PARA: a phone number follows—
the team has full support of Margaret Guerrier, president, Association of Canadian Franchisors.

PARA.TAB: Services and products on offer are air cleaning systems, vehicle corrosion services, fashion accessories, theme restaurants, sun protection materials, lawn care operations, weight loss centres and video advertising.
All carefully selected, each franchisor has a success record in Canada as well as the US.

SPEECH.PARA: At the foot of the article it describes some of the franchises available. It states:

PARA.TAB: Sales of advertising on movie rental cases, using unusual graphic art off a computerised system for optimum effect—Video Impact (34 Grenfell Crescent Ottawa, K2G 0G2) Gerry Corcoran, president.
The computer system eliminates the high cost of art design, plus the system has a specialised movie case with a clear plastic sleeve. There's 100 franchises in Canada and the US.
Canada's Casey says the above companies represent an excellent "cross-section" of proven franchisors. He is confident all could find master franchisees.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Gerald Corcoran who was named in the article in Business Canada, a publication of the Canadian trade offices in Australia, was a member of the Canadian government sponsored franchising trade mission to Australia the following month, September 1990. The trade mission, including Mr Corcoran, was provided with substantial assistance by the consulate, including office and secretarial services and public relations support. I am informed that meetings were conducted within the consulate premises and agreements entered into within them. As late as June 1991, I am informed that the Canadian consulate in Sydney was still providing support for Mr Corcoran.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence of these arrangements and negotiations, Mr Hoy's company, Crestcon Pty Ltd, entered into an agreement with Video Impact as a franchisee for the franchise of video cassette covers and their advertising system in Australia. A payment of $175,000 was made to purchase a video master for the purpose of manufacturing video covers. I am informed that this payment was made and the contract entered into at the Canadian consulate in Melbourne.

I am informed that this contract was made as a consequence of a series of representations made by Mr Corcoran to Mr Hoy both in the advertisement I have referred to and also directly. The representations included information on the nature and usage of the video cassettes, that there was a current market establishing the effectiveness of these cassettes, the frequency of hire of the latest release video cassettes, the establishment in Australia of a national management and marketing organisation and also that major high profile companies such as Coca Cola, Pepsi, McDonalds and Nintendo were advertising with Video Impact in America. At the same time there were a series of other representations made by Mr Corcoran to Mr Hoy.

It seems that these representations, and in fact the whole business, are misleading, the representations were false and the arrangement is nothing more than a sham. When searches were made in Canada subsequent to the passing over of $175,000 on the basis of these representations, it was discovered that the only address given for this company was in an industrial district in a part of Canada that was unlikely to be the home of an international marketing operation of this nature; that there were no franchises in Canada or the United States and that the companies concerned either did not know anything about this particular franchising operation or had only received a letter from Mr Corcoran and had not taken any action on it themselves.

What concerns me is that the Canadian consulate has been involved in the representations. Not only was it involved in the advertisement which was placed in the Sydney Morning Herald; in its Business Canada bulletin there is a glowing reference to these franchisors which says basically that they have the support of the Canadian government. Mr Hoy went to the consulate and said, `What about this Mr Corcoran? We can't find him. The money has gone missing and this whole operation is a scam. What are you going to do about it?'

As a result of representations that were made to the Canadian consulate by me, Mr Hoy and others, all we got was a reply saying that this is a commercial dispute, that the government of Canada can assume no responsibility for its resolution and that it can make no further comments about the matter. When the Australian government was contacted about this matter, all we got from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, was a statement which read:

SPEECH.PARA: On receipt of your letter of 13 December, officers in my Department sent a copy of it to the Canadian High Commission with a request for comment. None was forthcoming from either the High Commission in Canberra, or the Consulate-General in Sydney and there has been no further contact with Canadian representatives on this matter.

As a consequence of the complaints made to the consulate in Sydney, it has said that it accepts no responsibility at all for this matter, even though it provided the mechanism, the means, the place where the business was done and the support for this operation in the first place. When some efforts were made to issue a writ against the Canadian consulate, it said that it was not prepared to accept a writ at all. In a letter dated 18 June 1993, it stated:
The Canadian Consulate General is not willing to accept service of a Writ. Should an action be introduced, this office will claim Consular Immunity.
Prior to that, when complaints were first made to Canada, it said:

PARA.TAB: In response to your written and verbal comments concerning your experience with Video Impact in the course of commercial negotiations toward a franchising agreement, our colleagues in Ottawa have found no adverse comment or irregularities regarding Video Impact's commercial conduct in Canada.

SPEECH.PARA: People from Australia who went to Canada could not even find Video Impact—let alone find any irregularities. The Canadian consulate owes a much better explanation than that which it has provided at present. In fact, no Canadian franchisers have been able to be found. Mr Corcoran is not a franchiser. The Canadian consulate has simply accepted his word. Perhaps it has written in its Business Canada bulletin what he provided for it in the first place. No telephone listing could be found in Canada for this business at all. All the Canadian consulate says is that it will claim consular immunity.

PARA.TAB: My advice is that the Canadian consulate should waive that immunity. I believe that it ought to do so in this case because its representations and conduct have led to the situation where an Australian citizen, acting in the most proper way, has invested $175,000 in a scam which has been aided and abetted by the Canadian consulate. Something more should be provided by the consulate. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade ought to do something more to protect an Australian citizen in these circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance concerns a number of issues raised by the Ukrainian community of this country. The last week has seen the third anniversary of Ukrainian independence. A decision was made by the Ukrainian administration in August 1991, which was followed by a plebiscite in December in which 90 per cent approval was gained for the concept of independence from the former Soviet Union. There was recognition by Australia and virtually all countries within a short period after that. The last week has provided an opportunity to reassert, as Australia did in May this year, the integrity of the Ukraine's boundaries, most particularly in the case of the Crimea, where there have been escalating problems with recent regional elections and demands by some for reunification with Russia.

PARA.TAB: I took the opportunity at yesterday's Ukrainian Independence Day celebrations, organised by the Ukrainian Council of New South Wales, to quote an article from the Economist of May this year. It contained an overall review of the Ukraine which puts very clearly the crucial role of the Ukraine with respect to moves by the more way-out fringe of Russian politicians, such as Zhirinovsky, to re-establish a former Russian empire. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Without Ukraine, Russia ceases to be an empire, at least in Europe. For those Russians who want to recreate a greater Russia, control of central Asia and the Caucasus is not enough. To keep Russia's position as a Eurasian power, rather than a purely Asiatic one, they need Ukraine and the access it offers to the rest of Europe. Without Ukraine, they fear, a would-be imperial Russia would look like a latter-day Byzantine empire, shorn of its most valuable western provinces and doomed to succumb to more dynamic forces from the East.

As I said, this last week has provided an opportunity to continue to reassert a degree of identity with the Ukraine, despite a multitude of problems. Issues affecting the Ukraine include the long-term future of the Black Sea fleet and nuclear missiles, the regional push by elements in the Donetsk region, and Sevastopol. When these issues are accompanied by a very unfortunate decline in the Ukrainian economy—this now sees as many as 12.5 trillion coupons circulating as money in the country, which has resulted in very serious shortages of a number of foodstuffs—and wrangling over provision of oil from Russia, the picture is somewhat worrying for those people who assert support for the Ukraine's continued existence.

PARA.TAB: However, the reality is that this country has Europe's fifth largest population and, geographically, it is a very significant country within the continent. Over the last few years, we have had the opportunity to take up a number of issues with the Australian government that relate to the needs of both the Ukraine and the Ukrainian citizens of this country.

I am pleased to say that, in the recent budget, the government did renew the APTEA funding, which is a training scheme for eastern Europe that last year involved five Ukrainians who gained training in management practices through work experience. A further three Ukrainians will be involved in this scheme in each of the next two years. That renewal was very valuable. It typifies this government's support for a number of international funding organisations that are helping in the reconstruction of the Ukraine.

One of the continuing issues that I wish to raise today concerns representation in Kiev. A series of letters by members of parliament have been answered with a response that the place can be served very well by Moscow. Various letters have also asked why people in the Ukraine should object to going to Moscow because, after all, Albanians and Romanians have to go to other countries and the Scandinavians are in a similar situation.

I reiterate that we are talking about a very changed circumstance. We are talking about a nation with in excess of 52 million people. It could be that to some people the statistics with respect to the number of visas that are currently being processed in Moscow—it was last reported as being 20 per cent of the total visa issue—might not be a good enough reason to locate Australian based staff there rather than to just rely on the consul. As I said, I think we are inclined to get into a time warp which says, `As it has been part of the Soviet Union for so long, why should we do it? We're getting out of Europe; we're focusing on Asia.' People can come forward with cases of a number of European countries with populations of 10 million or less which suffer the same predicament. But, quite frankly, I think we have to start recognising the reality of the Ukraine's population and the number of its citizens in this country.

Related to this failure to increase our presence is the degree of inconvenience that it is causing those people who are trying to come to Australia on tourist visas and those people who have other migration needs. They are forced to pay for a courier service. Until recently, before the government rectified this matter, they had difficulties with a payment that the consul sought for a combined courier and document provision. Because of the difficulties of hard currency in the Ukraine, many people have had to go to Moscow and basically camp on the streets overnight to get this service.

Despite the fact that we are focusing on Asia—and no-one is condemning that—and despite the fact there has been a pull-back in our representation in Europe, perhaps the time has come for a reallocation within that continent and for a greater emphasis to be placed on the Ukraine. We have a very committed diaspora in this country in that, despite the current financial difficulties and crisis in the country, we do seek to be part of economic cooperation.

Similarly, the government should look at the question of granting aid to this community. I am pleased to say that there has been a recognition of a need there, but this year's allocation was reduced, at least in Sydney, from a full grant to half a grant. Once again, I think there are plausible, viable arguments up-front, such as that the community is fairly small compared with others.

We do have to recognise, as the government has in other spheres, that 75 per cent of the Ukrainian born population are over 60 years of age, according to the last census, which indicates a particular need. When we relate that to their own peculiarities—many of them came here as displaced people after the Second World War; they did not come as family units, they came as individuals; and many of them were in areas such as the Snowy Mountains and what is now the Bathurst-Orange region—perhaps these individuals need a lot more assistance in coming to urban areas and concentrating resources. There is a very real need in the community. There is a very strong argument that they do need this service. They are distinct from the Russian community, and the government should recognise this.

On a more positive note, I am pleased to note this week the presence of the deputy foreign minister Marakenko and a delegation from Ukraine with sizeable business representation, whom I was pleased to meet yesterday. They are here to move forward more strongly on the draft trade and economic cooperation agreement between the two countries. Draft documents were considered in Kiev in the last year or so.

I hope this very strong delegation goes some way down the road to ensuring that there is an upturn in cooperation, that we recognise the long haul and that we understand that despite the current difficulties—the restructuring occurring in the Ukranian economy—the Ukranians have the kinds of resources and skills that were evident in their manufacturing sector and science base. For the long term, Australia really should be looking at giving greater priority to the Ukraine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my dismay that the National Food Authority is currently circulating a draft variation to the Australian food standards code to double the maximum permitted concentration of cadmium in peanuts, rice and wheat. This action is being taken not to benefit Australian industry or our consumers but to facilitate access to the Australian market by cadmium contaminated imports.

PARA.TAB: Cadmium is a naturally occurring metal and cannot be removed from the environment. However, it can accumulate in the body and, with excessive intake, gradually poison the system. So it is important to minimise human exposure to it wherever that can be achieved. Health authorities believe that long-term exposure to cadmium can cause irreparable kidney damage and there is also concern that high cadmium levels may be a significant factor in the early onset of osteoporosis in post-menopausal women.

Generally speaking, Australian producers have few problems with cadmium concentrations in our food. The low level of cadmium in Australian produced foods is of obvious benefit to Australian consumers and is also a natural competitive advantage. Low levels of cadmium can be sustained only with careful management and effective monitoring of production areas. Australian farmers and food producers should be encouraged and rewarded for their efforts in limiting the amount of cadmium in local food. But, instead of being proud of this achievement and endeavouring to build on Australia's success in this regard, the National Food Authority is now proposing that we abandon these achievements and relax the permitted level of cadmium concentrations in food products.

At the centre of the argument is the peanut industry. Most Australian peanut producing areas, including the major production area of south and central Burnett in my own electorate, have little or no difficulty in producing peanuts within the maximum permitted concentration of cadmium of 0.05 milligrams per kilogram. However, other producing countries, particularly China but also the USA and Africa, consistently have cadmium levels which do not meet the Australian standard.

In an article in the Courier-Mail on 29 January 1994 by rural editor Gordon Collie, and based on information contained under freedom of information legislation, it was revealed that in 1992-93 more than six per cent of imported food consignments tested by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service in high risk categories failed to pass health and quality checks. More than 3,700 shipments of food in risk categories were tested at point of entry and of these 230 failed to comply with Australian standards.

It needs to be acknowledged that any sampling system will be less than perfect and no doubt many other contaminated shipments were able to slip through the checking system undetected. And the majority of lower risk imports are not tested at all. The quantity of food imported into Australia which does not meet Australia's health standards is unacceptably high. Consumers should always be aware of this fact when they buy imported products.

Even though peanuts are comparatively a small food import, 54 of the rejected samples in 1992-93 were peanuts—well above the next highest offenders, which were, perhaps not surprisingly, seafoods. The most common reason for the rejection of peanuts was, by far, unacceptably high levels of cadmium and, by far, the worst source of rejections was China. Breaches ranged from 0.06 to 0.25 milligrams per kilogram, up to five times the accepted Australian standard.

Chinese peanut exports to Australia have become infamous over recent years for their poor quality. Not only have they had cadmium and other contaminants but also they often have inconsistent appearance and flavour and very poor shelf life. The import of Chinese peanuts has already done substantial damage to the reputation of peanuts in this country as a tasty, nutritious and quality food.

Chinese peanuts can only find a market in this country because of their low price, and in a country like China that price exists only because of the high level of subsidies provided by the Chinese government in production, marketing and transport. But these dumped, poor quality peanuts also consistently contain high levels of cadmium.

Instead of seeking to source imported products from other producing countries which can meet Australia's maximum permitted cadmium concentrations, the Food and Beverage Importers Association lodged an application—No. 208—to raise the maximum permitted concentrations of cadmium in Australia. The National Food Authority seized on its application, which originally applied only to rice crackers, to review permitted cadmium levels in all cereals, legumes and pulses and has now circulated a draft proposal recommending the doubling of permitted cadmium levels.

The National Food Authority argues that 0.1 milligrams per kilogram is the international standard. This standard is set at that level not because it has been proven safe but because producers in some countries do not want to undertake the necessary measures to reduce their cadmium concentration. Once again, the National Food Authority has put other factors ahead of the health and public safety of Australian consumers and the interests of local industry.

When Australian consumers get to know that, in future, peanuts can have double the level of cadmium they have at present, there is a risk they will choose to eat other foods, thus damaging not just the polluted imports but also the local industry, which would still be capable of producing low cadmium peanuts. The President of the Burnett Zone of the Queensland Graingrowers Association, Mr Trevor Rook, said recently:

SPEECH.PARA: I can't understand why the National Food Authority would be pushing to double the acceptable level of cadmium in a product which boasts a clean, green and healthy image, both here on the domestic market and overseas. As a peanut grower I am proud of our high standards and clean image. From a consumer point of view, it must be a crazy proposal.

The cadmium scandal demonstrates once again that the only way Australian consumers can guarantee getting food products which meet high health standards is to buy food grown in Australia. Kingaroy's claim to producing the world's best peanuts is no idle boast. But with labelling laws as they are in Australia at the present time it is often difficult to know whether food being bought in this country is indeed Australian. The proposed amendments to labelling laws which are currently before the parliament will not adequately resolve country of origin issues.

PARA.TAB: While it is true that the major, very powerful supermarket chains, with their generic brands, provide much of the impetus to import cheap, low-quality food products into Australia, they are not the only offenders. Recently on an Ansett Airlines flight I was handed peanuts which were labelled `Packaged in Australia from Australian or imported ingredients'—a give-away that the contents of the packet were indeed imported.

Another matter of concern is what happens to food imports which are condemned by AQIS as not meeting Australian standards. In a letter to Mr Gordon Collie of 22 April 1994, Mr John Merton, an assistant director of AQIS, said that between 1 July 1993 and 17 March 1994 `there had been 142 instances recorded where imported foods did not comply with Australian food safety or food standard requirements'. Of these 142, only 33 were destroyed. A further 32 were re-exported in the hope they might slip through some other country's import inspection arrangements and be served up to consumers somewhere else. In 36 instances the goods were still being held pending a decision to destroy or re-export. Perhaps most alarming of all is the fact that in 20 cases the goods had been released after sampling but before the results were to hand.

In these instances, AQIS merely notified the state authorities of the failures. As Mr Merton confirmed in his letter, `AQIS is unaware of what action, if any, was taken.' In fact, most state health authorities have an abysmal record of enforcing National Food Authority regulations. Recently Mr Collie told a meeting that the states often did little or nothing to recover the food imports which had failed AQIS tests. The products end up being sold to unknowing consumers.

Australian farmers are able to supply to consumers peanuts with very low levels of cadmium contamination. That provides real benefits to the health of Australian consumers. There is no sensible reason why these benefits should be compromised to accommodate the wishes of a few rogue importers. I call on the National Food Authority to entrench the highest reasonably achievable standards for Australian foods and to reject the current needless push to accommodate low-quality imports.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to refer to today is the continuing tragedy in East Timor. Successive Australian governments have in effect accepted the Indonesian invasion and subsequent devastation of the people of East Timor. Today I wish to place on record my disagreement with the position that has been adopted by all of the Australian governments that have held office in the time since the Indonesian invasion.

PARA.TAB: The initial justifications that were put forward in opposition to anything being done by Australia in any form to resist the Indonesian invasion were that there was potential for a so-called communist enclave to develop in an independent East Timor; that an independent East Timor would be economically unviable; and that only a minority of the East Timorese people were committed to independence. Time has proved all of these purported justifications to be false.

In our region there are many nations which are significantly smaller than East Timor. Although they all have economic problems, as indeed do we, they clearly are not economically unviable. The collapse of the Eastern bloc removes any real justification of the communist issue—if it ever was a justification. Events have clearly proved that the overwhelming majority of East Timorese people genuinely do desire national independence.

Australia is one of very few countries throughout the world that give legal recognition to Indonesia's control of East Timor. The reason why we do that is abundantly clear: self-interest. In order to be able to found a strong legal base for the Timor Gap treaty, it is necessary for us to legally recognise Indonesian control of East Timor and the associated seabed, which of course is all important with respect to the treaty.

In the Age of 6 June this year, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) described the treaty as `a logical corollary of Australia's recognition'. He stated that there were `questions of basic Australian national interest involved' and that `resources to which Australians were entitled were locked up pending resolution of the issue'. Finally, he said, `It increased our capacity to be influential on other issues, including human rights.'

It is perhaps also worth noting that, when questioned about the situation in East Timor in another context, Senator Evans stated, `The world's a pretty unfair place.' I would suggest that these comments are unfitting for Senator Evans, who I think has been an excellent foreign minister. Certainly, the comments are not in keeping with his efforts in many other areas, particularly in the area of Cambodia.

I would suggest that, in effect, the Timor Gap treaty legitimises mass murder and that it has been erected on the basis of the devastation of the East Timorese people. Yes, national interest is involved. Yes, a very substantial amount of potential revenue will accrue to the Australian people as a result of exploiting the Timor Gap territory. The question we have to ask is: what price are we paying, morally, for doing so?

If we took these arguments to their logical extension, we might want to invade and colonise—or recolonise—some of our immediate neighbours and enslave some of the peoples. That probably would produce some pretty good economic results as well. But whether Australians would consider that to be compatible with some of the values upon which this country is built is another question. I would seriously contend that the Timor Gap treaty is not in accordance with the values which we, across both sides of this House, hold as fundamental to Australian society.

In more recent times, the Dili massacre, the show trial and imprisonment of Xanana Gusmao and the never ending flow of refugees, both directly and indirectly, from East Timor give the lie to claims that things are normal in East Timor and that the integration is proceeding okay. I was at a function recently where Catholic Bishop Deakin, who had recently returned from East Timor, gave a description of a man who showed his back, with dozens and dozens of cigarette butt burns on it, having recently been tortured. This is just one small illustration of the types of things that are still going on in East Timor. He also recounted some of the tribulations that Bishop Belo, a very brave and very committed person, is undergoing in his attempt to reach some resolution of the issue.

What results for the East Timorese people has our supposed position of constructive engagement actually delivered? How can we possibly say that things would have been worse had it not been for Australia pursuing a policy of constructive engagement with Indonesia and eschewing a harder line such as I would pursue? To be fair to the government, and to Senator Evans, we have made it plain that we disapprove of many of the things that have occurred in East Timor, and the complaints that were put forward with respect to things like the Dili massacre were quite strident. I do not take the view, as some do, that the Australian government is absolutely compliant, but I think there is room for considerable improvement. We could ratchet up our position to a much stronger and a much more honourable position than that which we hold at the moment.

The critical questions are: what has our soft line achieved, and what evidence is there of less suffering, of better human rights and of greater reconciliation? The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) indicated that human rights are now improving in East Timor. I am not aware of any evidence to that effect. Certainly, indications from people whom I suspect are in a better position to know, such as Bishop Belo, are quite to the contrary. Even the United States, which gave a nod and a wink to the original invasion, is now taking a stronger line on the issue.

It worries me that the logic of constructive engagement is disturbingly similar to that which used to be advocated with respect to South Africa—that is, the way to solve the apartheid problem was to be friendly to the South African regime, and that would enable you to in some way exert some influence over it. Our friendship with the Indonesians on this issue and our willingness to turn a blind eye to what has been done have had no impact on them or on the situation in East Timor. However, we must face up to the fact that to some extent we are prisoners of our past. We cannot simply turn the clock back to 1975 or 1976 and correct the mistakes that we have made, yet we can still make a contribution.

International opinion with respect to the situation in East Timor is hardening. American concern is growing, the Portuguese resolve is stiffening and many other issues that have dominated the world agenda, such as South Africa and the Middle East, have at least to some extent calmed down. The spotlight on East Timor will increase.

Removing our recognition of the legal Indonesian control of East Timor would be a good start. The basis on which we are entitled to do that is that virtually nobody else of consequence in the international community has taken a similar step. We could take the step of, in effect, pleading no contest in the forthcoming trial of the Timor Gap treaty in the International Court of Justice, where the Portuguese have taken a case. We could simply say, `We will leave it up to the court to decide,' rather than defending it vigorously. We could reduce our military interaction with Indonesia on the basis that that is a concrete expression of our disapproval of the behaviour of the Indonesian military. What puzzles me is why we are so worried about offending Indonesia when we are prepared to offend Malaysia about something as relatively inconsequential as its Prime Minister's failure to attend a regional meeting of leaders.

John Pilger's recent film Death of a nation attracted a certain degree of invective from various quarters. But it really does not matter whether he or anybody else has exaggerated the number of East Timorese people who have died. The fact is that an awful lot of people have died. Tens, quite probably hundreds, of thousands of people have died. To argue about the body count is absurd and offensive. John Pilger, like many journalists, occasionally lets his rhetoric run away with him a bit and he overstates the case. So what; the substance remains the same.

I would like to see a growing bipartisan attitude on this issue. I am pleased to see the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) at the table for the opposition today because he is one of a few on the other side whom I consider to have adopted a good view on this issue. I applaud him for it. I would like to see other members on both sides taking a stronger view and getting involved in trying to do something about it.

I say in conclusion that, in 1975, a previous Labor government made an embarrassing decision: it recognised the USSR control of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, partly on the basis that their incorporation in the Soviet Union was irreversible. That is the same description that Senator Evans has used with respect to Indonesia and East Timor. I do not want to see that embarrassment repeated.

I ask finally why we do not have any opinion polls about the issue of East Timor. Could it be that the leading groups in both parties do not want to see that happen? We have opinion polls on some of the most extraordinary issues, such as whether the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) should be the Prime Minister or other inane propositions. Why can we not have an opinion poll that asks the Australian community what they think about this? If the indications that we get in the media day in and day out are any guide, the community does not support the policy of the government or the current opposition. It is time that that was changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I deal with the matter which I wish to address today, I want to make a brief comment about the previous speaker, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). I have a lot of sympathy with the views expressed. Having very recently been in Indonesia, it seems to me that there are other problems there of a significant nature. I am talking particularly about the advent of AIDS, which the government there refuses to acknowledge as a problem. It seems to me that AIDS will have an absolutely catastrophic impact on that country in the next decade. We might need to give some attention to this issue because of the proximity and number of people involved. It really will be a serious problem. As I understand it, the government will not acknowledge the problem and is not doing much about it for religious reasons. It will be another major issue for us to debate in coming years.

PARA.TAB: I want to talk today about an article that appeared in the Melbourne Age a week ago by a journalist who obviously accompanied the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) on his recent trip to the United States, particularly to the Navaho nation of Indians. The Navahos comprise about 200,000 people, which is something like 50,000 less than our total indigenous population in this country. They have a fair degree of autonomy, based largely on the fact that they signed a treaty in 1868. Therefore, they have never formally ceded their sovereignty to the American nation per se. They have a fair degree of local self-control on a range of issues.

The message that comes out of this article is that sovereignty for indigenous people does not do any harm to the economy and that it is really necessary for the wellbeing of indigenous people. Whilst I personally have some sympathy with that view, I have to say that I do not think it is as simple as that.

The article also points out on a number of occasions what a pity it is that just the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs bothers to go overseas to look at these interests and experiences and states how the coalition would benefit from a similar journey. I have to tell the journalist concerned and inform the House that at the time the minister was visiting the Navaho Indians I was also in America and Canada talking with a number of governments, both state and federal, and indigenous tribes that are looking at similar issues. We on this side of the House are interested and concerned to learn from overseas experiences what should, and often should not, be done to try to improve the situation of our indigenous people.

I went to San Francisco and Sacramento, the state capital of California. I met with BHP mining executives, who have to deal with negotiations with indigenous people in New Mexico. I met with state government people in Sacramento. I then went to Vancouver and across to Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was this your honeymoon?

—This was not my honeymoon; this was a work trip. I went across to Victoria before most people knew where it is. They all know now where Victoria is because of the Commonwealth Games. But I was there before the Commonwealth Games started and left before they started. There I met with British Columbia province officials and indigenous people. I then went to Ottawa and, over three or four days, met a range of government officials from the health, housing and employment sectors. I then went to Washington and met with a number of health officials who are looking at indigenous issues.

PARA.TAB: I found it particularly depressing that the profile of disadvantage for indigenous people in those two countries is really not all that different from ours, be it in poor life expectancy, poor standards of education, health, housing, employment, domestic violence, alcohol problems, overrepresentation in the penal system and so on. However, a couple of noticeably different trends regarding the approach to indigenous affairs emerged in those countries. It was very clear that the United States makes a very specific distinction between Indians who live on reservations and those who do not. Fundamentally, those who do not live on a reservation do not get any special measures while those who do might well get special measures.

There are certainly opportunities, as this article explains, for Indian nations to receive royalties from various mining and other activities. But it also seemed to me that there is a developing trend whereby the government is saying to Indian nations in America, `You've got your own land. The gaming laws don't apply to you as they do to the rest of the state. Why don't you set up some gaming facilities and generate revenue from that?' A number of tribes are going down that route. I am not so sure that in the long term that will be beneficial to the tribes concerned.

I talked with representatives from the National Institute of Health in Washington, where there are some major research facilities. They were talking about perhaps getting together with Canada and Australia and looking at how we can deal with some mutual indigenous health problems.

Canada deals with indigenous people tribe by tribe, whereas we have ATSIC and we try to approach the whole subject on a national basis. British Columbia, where no treaties were signed with the Indian people, talks about its own Mabo legislation. It is going through a very similar debate. It often has a very similar view to the Western Australian government about land rights for Indian people in British Columbia. A number of the indigenous people I talked to in Victoria were just as disenchanted about what is going on with land rights in that country as many of our own are in this country.

I talked to a number of BHP executives in Vancouver. Ironically, I had met some of them on Groote Eylandt a couple of years ago. This is part of the international economy. Big companies move executives around. The view of certainly one of those executives is that there is not the same profit motive here. There is a very firm profit motive amongst indigenous people in Canada. He put that down to a harshness of the environment. I am not sure whether that is right. But he certainly felt there was a distinct cultural difference in their approach to commercial exploration and the revenues generated therefrom.

It was also interesting to note that in Canada the government expenditure per capita is almost identical to the government expenditure on Aboriginal affairs in this country. As I mentioned before, Canada has very similar outcomes in all indicators. We should recognise that North America has a very different history in terms of indigenous people and that many of those tribes signed treaties, which were honoured in the breach more than in the actuality in many cases. Nevertheless, there is a different basis on which the tribes are dealt with today.

As a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, I am obviously as committed as most to the importance of land and the very urgent need for indigenous people in this country to accept responsibility for their own future and to have more control locally over their own lives. But I am very wary about too readily picking up on experiences from overseas. It seems to me that we should not just slavishly copy what we hear from overseas because other countries are not necessarily more successful than us, and success can sometimes appear illusory.

It is interesting that the article in the Age which I was talking about earlier states that the unemployment rate of Navaho Indians is 55 per cent, in spite of independence, owning their own land and all the rest of it. The article talks about the problems of the suppression of freedom of speech within the media within the Navaho lands and it talks about the poor range of shopping available and the poor quality of food available. Overall, it does not paint a particularly bright picture.

One area about which I would have some sympathy with the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs is, as stated in the Age, the need to recognise the differences between this country and the States. Rather than blindly picking up what they are doing over there, we have to recognise our own unique profile of indigenous problems and we need to fashion our own solutions rather than slavishly following others. Sovereignty and so on is important; nevertheless, we cannot just pick up the sorts of things that are advocated here, and I think that that is a lesson which we all ought to be aware of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is aware that a by-election occurred in New South Wales on the weekend and it is now history that Gabrielle Harrison is the new member for Parramatta, with a massive 11 per cent swing. I heartily congratulate her. But I find it very interesting that the Premier of New South Wales and the Minister for Health in New South Wales both claim that the ALP ran a fear campaign on health and did not tell the truth. Mr Phillips, the Minister for Health, even went on to say that the New South Wales government will have to spend more money so it can tell the truth about health services in New South Wales and how they have improved. It would appear that Mr Phillips is indeed proud of the health services his government provides.

PARA.TAB: I want to use my time today to tell this House about some of the problems constituents in the electorate of Paterson face when they need medical and, in particular, hospital treatment. I spoke last week about oncology services and the use of radiotherapy to treat cancer patients. Patients at the oncology unit at the Mater Hospital are currently being advised that they have to wait six to eight weeks for treatment. In my electorate, which is one of the fastest growing areas in Australia, there are three hospitals—Maitland, Dungog and Gloucester—and a polyclinic at Nelson Bay. I remind the House that Maitland is a city with a population of some 53,000, yet with all these facilities there is not a single facility where residents suffering from renal failure can obtain dialysis. They have to travel to Newcastle or Singleton three days a week for this lifesaving treatment to be carried out.

A machine to do this service costs about $20,000 and I understand that a nurse can be fully trained in eight weeks to assist such patients during dialysis, yet none can be provided in my electorate. Is that service? I remind honourable members that many of these patients are elderly pensioners who rely on public transport. I am sure that many honourable members know people who require dialysis, know the enormous distress and discomfort that it places on them and know that, afterwards, they have to spend a considerable time in bed, simply because they feel unwell.

I set about carrying out an audit of hospital services in my electorate and I found many examples of what I can describe only as subhuman treatment. One constituent, an elderly lady who needed a small operation on her hand, was advised that there would be a six-month wait for the operation to take place at the Mater Hospital in Newcastle. On the day of the proposed operation, she was informed 2 1/2 hours before it was scheduled to begin that it was cancelled and she was told to return in a little over a month's time. When that lady returned for her second scheduled operation, one hour before it was due to begin she was advised that it had been cancelled again due to the lack of an anaesthetist. The operation finally took place a week later. One can only imagine the trauma placed on such a person. Yet this is not a single occurrence; this sort of thing is not uncommon.

I would also like to advise the House that this particular lady has a husband who is a stroke victim, so you can imagine the amount of planning she would have to do before she could go to hospital. She knew that she was going to be away from her home for a couple of days and, on each occasion she was preparing to go to hospital, she had to make sure that her husband was cared for. This is indicative of the lack of counselling that takes place, the lack of understanding of the individual needs of patients. So much for caring for the individual.

As well, overcrowding occurs in the maternity section of the Maitland hospital. Expectant mothers are often held in corridors and waiting rooms in a queue for a bed. On weekends, public holidays and other occasions, we often see wards closed due to budgetary overruns or constraints. If only our illnesses could attack in business hours on week days.

As I have already mentioned, there is a regular rescheduling of admissions and deferral of surgery due to the closure of wards. Cuts in operating times and the lack of specialists—particularly anaesthetists—cause major inconvenience to the ailing public. There has been a waiting period of 18 months for general dental surgery, due to a lack of facilities and professional staff. Patients are often transferred to neighbouring hospitals on admission to accident and emergency, because of a lack of beds. On discovering these inconveniences, my immediate reaction to this congestion was that there must be a shortage of health funds available to the New South Wales government.

Then I found some really interesting information. In 1992-93, the New South Wales government underspent its budget on health by a massive $82 million. This year, the federal government increased funding to New South Wales by some $178 million and, so far this year, the New South Wales government is already underspending its health budget. We have found that, since 1991, the New South Wales government has closed some 3,000 beds in its public hospitals. This would tend to indicate that the demand for beds is not there. My survey certainly shows otherwise.

The Fahey government has accused the Labor Party of running a fear campaign on health and acting in a guerrilla warfare style. Yet, from looking at the results of the New South Wales government's health policy, it is questionable whether the monstering is really coming from the opposition.

An article in the Newcastle Morning Herald on 25 August told the story of Mr Allan Mathews, one of my constituents. He is one of 30 people waiting an average of four weeks to access the Newcastle Mater Hospital's radiotherapy unit and one of 10 patients in extreme pain. He was admitted on a Saturday morning with early signs of spinal cord compression. The extended wait for treatment and the spreading of the cancer has now resulted in his becoming effectively a paraplegic. Doctors at the hospital have stated that, if they had been able to provide treatment for Mr Mathews earlier, his condition would not have deteriorated to that extent.

When a person becomes a paraplegic, not from an accident but merely from waiting in a queue, it must be asked: in what sort of state is health care in New South Wales? Judging from the condition of Mr Mathews, it has become a state lacking in medical compassion, with the state government's neglect of its responsibility to provide basic health services to the people in that state.

The funding provided by the Fahey government to health over the last few years has steadily continued to decline, with worsening results. Yet this state government has announced $1.5 billion worth of initiatives as, of course, the election draws near. The Labor opposition has described it as the billion dollar slush fund, and the spending seems to go in every direction except health. The amount of $86 million has been allocated for 1,466 extra teachers; of course, they are replacing some of those that Nick Greiner sacked. There are to be another 500 policemen and another 12,500 public servants—the sorts of things that the coalition is a master of.

We had a billion dollars in promises in the Parramatta region immediately prior to the by-election. I wonder what will happen to those promises now. The Premier, Mr Fahey, showed his lack of concern when he dismissed the suffering undergone by residents in the Parramatta electorate, an action exemplified by his light-hearted suggestion to an elderly pensioner that he hoped she would have better luck at bingo than at obtaining a hospital bed. (Time expired)
