TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for this opportunity to pay tribute to the 256 great Australians who have just represented their country very proudly. I say 256 because this is the number of athletes who left Australia to represent Australia at the Commonwealth Games. We have seen many obvious successes from these athletes. First of all, there is the medal tally—the greatest ever—with 87 gold, 52 silver and 43 bronze; that is a total of 182.

PARA.TAB: More than that, we have seen outstanding effort on the part of all of them. We have seen incredible personal bests and broken world records. And who could ever forget Kieren Perkins's swims? Even in failure, we have seen some fantastic success from some of our athletes. For example, no-one could say that Tani Ruckle, as she fell over the line at the women's marathon, actually failed; the fact that she finished that race was a huge tribute to her determination.

We as parliamentarians are very proud of the efforts of our athletes. The medal tally compares so favourably to past efforts. In Auckland, for example, there were 52 gold, 54 silver and 56 bronze. The achievement in this Commonwealth Games is the greatest achievement of any country ever in the Commonwealth Games. That is obviously because of years of personal effort by many of these individual athletes and team members, and the great sacrifices that they and their families have made.

There has also been a very special partnership with government. Money is not everything in sport, of course, but it sure helps. Through the next step program and Maintaining the momentum, $275 million has been spent in sport from 1989 to the 1993-94 financial year. That has really helped. In all the studies done of that money that has been expended, there has always been seen to be a correlation between the amount of money and the performance. That has meant not only that there has been personal support to the athletes but, very importantly, that there has been a new level of professionalism in sport—all the back-up mechanisms that are so important for those athletes to get out there on the track or to get into the field. Those mechanisms are centred at the institutes of sport. I am very proud to have Canberra as the centre of that, but we have also set up satellite institutes around Australia. I think that has worked very well. It has brought with it absolute professionalism in sports medicine, diet, sports psychology, education and, most importantly, coaching.

All of us forget, when we see those great individual efforts of the athletes, that behind each of those athletes is a fabulous coach. Coaching is the real essence of success in sport. I particularly pay tribute to those unsung heroes—the coaches—who have really worked so hard to make our athletes win through. Management of sport is also really critical, and true professionalism shows when we get the results we have just had in the Commonwealth Games.

Besides that link with money, there are a couple of lessons to be learnt. Catherine Freeman clearly demonstrated what an Aboriginal child can do. A young Aboriginal woman has excelled for her country and for her people. There is a lesson in that. I do not think we as a nation have done enough to develop our Aboriginal kids in sport—not just the Aboriginal kids but also many of those children who are living in remote parts of Australia. With the additional money going into sport, a real priority has got to be the developing of opportunities for kids in remote parts of Australia.

The other lesson to be learnt is the need for real professionalism, particularly at the very top levels of sport. We expect the best from our athletes. We should also expect the best from our administrators.

I would like to thank all the members of the team for their fabulous effort, not just because of the medals, but because they are the backbone of sport as we move towards the year 2000. Not only will many of them continue to improve; even more importantly, they are the role models for our athletes of the future. All the kids who have been watching these great achievements over the past 10 days will be out there trying especially hard for the Olympic Games in the year 2000 because of the efforts of these athletes. That is one of the very important roles of these athletes: to be role models for the future.

Finally, to those athletes and the athletes of the future, I make this promise: the government will continue its partnership role. Recently, we announced an olympic athlete program which will put another $135 million into sport over the next six years. As I said, money is not everything, but it sure helps. Congratulations to all those athletes who have done Australia so proud.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with other members of the House, particularly the former Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), in supporting this motion before the House today. I join with them in commending the Australian athletes for their outstanding individual and team performances at the Commonwealth Games. As one of the metropolitan newspaper headlines screamed, it is raining gold for Australia in Canada. One can only anticipate the glory that is yet to come for Australia at the world titles in the near future and the Olympic Games in Atlanta.

PARA.TAB: The dedication displayed by these athletes was admirable. I know that across Australia people were glued to their television sets as our athletes established a new record for the number of gold medals ever won by any nation. I think it has been said by others in this debate that sport is the sort of thing that draws Australians together. Of any nation in the world, I think we are more interested in sport than most other things. Even a former Liberal prime minister once said that the important thing to do was to put sport on the front pages and politics back on the back pages. Unfortunately, at present, his successors are not managing to do that. From our point of view, that is probably not too bad.

All of Australia was proud of the athletes, of the work they did and of the glory they brought to our country as well as to themselves. I think the overall performance of the Australian team says as much for the people behind the scenes as it does for the athletes. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Canberra, talked about the effort that managers and coaches put into these games. The games are not just about any individual; they are a team effort. Even if a person is running a solitary marathon, others are there urging them on. Other people have put a lot of effort into the preparation. They have put in the performance of their lives to ensure that the athletes put in the performance of their lives.

The managers of our Commonwealth Games teams play a very important part. In the main, the managers of sport that we have had in Australia over the years have been fairly good. It has been unfortunate that our overall situation in Canada has been tainted by the problems with Arthur Tunstall. I think the Commonwealth Games Association should wake up to itself. If Australia is to put forward very good, high profile athletes and very good technical coaches, the level of management and leadership that management provides has to be up to the same standard. No longer can we just give people a turn because they have been on the association's executive for 20 years.

I do not think any manager has made more of a muck of managing than Arthur Tunstall. Only one other person nearly made the same muck of it, and that was one of our colleagues on the other side who joined in with Mr Tunstall on one day. Letters to the editor in the newspapers and the talkback radio programs have all shown that Tunstall was out of step in what he thought athletes should do, in what he said about the disabled athletes and in what he said about Cathy Freeman.

I think that all Australians would have thought Cathy Freeman's attitude in carrying the Aboriginal flag and the Australian flag was what we want to see. If we genuinely believe that there should be reconciliation between the Aboriginal people of this country and the people who came here after the British arrived, Cathy Freeman embodies that reconciliation. Here is a young girl who is just excellent. It does not matter what race she is; she is excellent. The fact that she is excellent and an Aboriginal girl, as she has said, gives a lot of hope to a lot of other Aboriginal children. They can say, `There's a very good role model for us.' For someone to publicly try to tear her down was pretty disgraceful.

Cathy Freeman was the image of Australia. She represented what this country can be rather than what it was. Often in our lives we will see a bit of a sea change. I think after that girl's performance at the Commonwealth Games we saw a bit of a sea change in the attitudes of Australians towards indigenous people. I think the letters to the editor in the newspapers and the talk on the weekend that we all would have heard around our electorates showed that that girl probably did more for the cause of indigenous people in a short time than others have who have worked very hard over longer times.

I think all in all Australia has come away from the Commonwealth Games a far better country: better for the fact that we did well in the sporting events, better for the fact that we can say `We're back up at that high level of international competition' and better for seeing that image of Cathy Freeman wrapped in the Koori flag and the Australian flag. It showed the world that was the future of Australia, and that is a future in which I think we can all take some pride. It is not about which flag she picked up first or which flag some people want her to say she should or should not have carried; it is about the fact that here is a young woman who is a world beater, an Aboriginal and an Australian—she is the future.

We have seen some really good things for our country at the Commonwealth Games in Canada over the last week. I commend the athletes, their coaches and managers—with the exception of Arthur Tunstall—and all those people who, by being at home and watching the games, added their bit of oomph to make this something that Australians right across the country can be proud of. These young people have shown us what the cream of Australia is about—hard work and dedication. They have come home with the goods. I commend the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for proposing this motion and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) for supporting it. I hope that when the athletes return they will be given the resounding parade and shower of goodwill that they certainly deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also join in congratulating the Australian athletes on their achievements at the Commonwealth Games. Probably never before in the history of the Commonwealth Games has any country dominated the event to the extent that Australia has over the past few days. We went to the games with high expectations, particularly in the swimming pool. We had high expectations in weight-lifting, and we always expect to win medals on the track and in cycling. I think one of the welcome surprises of these games has been the emergence of Australia as a successful nation in gymnastics. We were all thrilled to see the wonderful performances of the Australian team in that regard.

PARA.TAB: A lot of reference has been made to the performance of Cathy Freeman as an Aboriginal Australian who performed with great success and obviously with great achievement. We also have a Japanese Australian who did very well in gymnastics, Hungarian Australians who did well in weight-lifting and people from other parts of the world—all part of our Australian team; all Australians—who did our country so very proud over the last few days.

There are always unlucky losers. Our tally of 87 medals—an unlucky number, is it not?—could easily have been 88 or perhaps some other figure. Just as there are some medals that got away, there are also those which were won narrowly—and those events add to the excitement of an occasion such as this.

All Australians enjoyed not only the excitement of an occasion such as this but also the way in which it strengthened our Commonwealth. It is an opportunity for nations around the world to get together. It is no longer all white and British to the bootstraps. These days our Commonwealth is made up of a large number of nations, many of whom have different traditions and backgrounds. Some of them do not even speak English as their mother tongue, as we found out with announcements in French during the Commonwealth Games proceedings.

It is always unfortunate to pick out one athlete as being the outstanding achiever. A lot of attention has been given to Cathy Freeman. She has been given credit for something she is not entitled to. It is not true to say that she is the first Aboriginal to win a medal. As I have read somewhere in the papers, that honour in fact belongs to a constituent of mine. The article states:
Cherbourg boxer Jeff Dynevor . . . was the first Aborigine to win a Commonwealth Games gold medal.
Southpaw Dynevor won the bantamweight gold medal at the 1962 Commonwealth Games in Perth.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an honour he will always have. I a sure he will be as delighted as all other Australians that another Australian Aborigine has performed so well in these games.

PARA.TAB: As I said, it is probably unfortunate to pick out particular success stories. But, if we are looking for one, it clearly has to be Kieren Perkins, who continues to break world records and who gave these Commonwealth Games world class by breaking two world records in his fabulous swim. The Commonwealth Games, and success in international events such as this, are of themselves important to our national pride in building a unified nation and one that has confidence in its own future. But the success of our elite athletes also provides encouragement to ordinary Australians to do a little better in their chosen sport.

It is particularly good that the Commonwealth Games has sports, such as lawn bowls, shooting and others, which do not necessarily require athletes to be super fit or to be at the absolute peak of their physical prowess to compete and to do well. I think that helps to make the Commonwealth Games the friendly games, the sorts of games that involve so many Australians and so many people around the world that they can then identify with those events and feel part of a very special process: the Commonwealth Games.

If ever anyone had any doubt about the future of the British Commonwealth of nations, and about Australia's commitment to that Commonwealth, it must surely have disappeared entirely over these last 10 days as we took pleasure at the success of our athletes in this level of competition. It helps to build a stronger Commonwealth, it helps to build confidence in ourselves as a nation and it helps to encourage young Australians—and, indeed, old Australians—to participate in sport and to have pride in their country and in what it is able to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —They say it is an ill wind that blows no good. In my case, I have been housebound for the best part of the last three weeks with a rather severe viral chest infection. The good side of that is that it gave me a chance to very closely follow the Commonwealth Games on the radio when I was in bed and on the television when I managed to get up. I followed it right through and I have learned a lot. I still have not learned the intricacies of scoring in lawn bowls. Maybe that will happen one day. Maybe I will end up taking it up myself. Watching the Commonwealth Games has been a rare privilege for me. I, like most people with busy lives, watch the snatches on the news or the bits on weekends. It was a great experience to have watched so much of the games.

PARA.TAB: I must also commend the radio and television coverage. I consider it a rare privilege to watch very closely the face of a diver who is standing on tiptoes, balancing on the edge of a board, focusing, concentrating and getting into the right frame of mind to make a superb dive. Some honourable members may have seen the two-part documentary last week on Leni Riefenstahl, the German filmmaker who filmed the 1936 Olympics using a lot of new techniques. When I looked at our coverage of the Commonwealth Games, I saw that those are techniques we now take for granted: the diver on the board, then under the water, and then coming out—as well as the replays.

One of the things that struck me was the spirit in which all the athletes entered into these games. I had great pride as an Australian to see so many of our athletes taking prizes, the flag going up and to hear the anthem played so many times. I did remark to several people on the number of athletes who sang the national anthem during the medal ceremonies, particularly the swimmers. The one that really got to my heart was young Melissa Carlton, the disabled 15-year-old swimmer who left her sticks, got onto the podium with one leg, stood there rock solid through the whole ceremony, shifted her balance slightly towards the flag for the anthem and sang the anthem with gusto. I thought, `That is what it is about.'

It is a marvellous idea to integrate the disabled games. How that will work on a long-term basis when we have a lot of events in the normal disabled games, I do not know. It was great to bring the disabled in. We won the silver in the men's swimming—I am sorry, I cannot remember the name of the young man who won the silver—and, again, I will never forget his face when he was standing up on the podium receiving his medal.

One of our speakers referred to the young people at the games. If you watched the lawn bowls, the shooting and some of the other events, you would have seen that there were some not so young people there. I do not think it was a deliberate attempt by our two lawn bowlers who bleached their hair for the occasion to look younger, but to say, `Here we are, we're sun-bleached Aussies.'

TALK.START.PARA: —One was 23 so he didn't need to do very much.

—They certainly played their part as well. Sometimes we focus only on the glamour events—particularly in the pool and on the track—but to see javelin, hammer and discus throwers as well as long and high jumpers doing so well, and the young lass who won the single badminton who was not even seeded and was so surprised at the win, is a sheer joy. Likewise are the five gold medals from Kasumi Takahashi, who was absolutely splendid.

PARA.TAB: I am sure those of you who are around my age, or even younger, can remember some Commonwealth and Olympic games when gymnastics was a sport that Australians hardly ever entered, or we never thought we would ever do any good. Look at the great success we have had both with our male and female gymnasts; they have been absolutely superb.

I cannot let Cathy Freeman go past because she has been the subject of a lot of discussion this last week. I must correct the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), who said it was claimed that Cathy Freeman was the first Aborigine to win a medal at a Commonwealth Games. This is not so. She was the first female Aborigine to win a single medal. That was the claim that was made, and that is certainly what she did. I would support all of my colleagues who have praised her for carrying both the Aboriginal flag and the Australian flag.

I inferred from the speech of the member for Wide Bay that he was comparing Cathy Freeman to those athletes who have come from other countries, are now Australians and were competing in the Commonwealth Games under the banner of Australia. There is a distinct difference. Cathy Freeman is an original Australian. Her descendants were here long before the Europeans or anyone else who came from any other country. It is worthy of note that she is an Aboriginal Australian who has done so well.

As the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) has said, young people like Cathy Freeman serve as an inspiration not only in sport but also in life generally. As Cathy herself said in several interviews, she wants her fellow Aboriginal young people to feel that they are worth something; that they can get up and do the things they want to do, whether it is in sport, commerce, education or in any other field. I think that is enormously important.

When the honourable member for Canberra was the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories she arranged for our caucus committee to visit the Australian Institute of Sport for breakfast one morning. We all felt very small when rather large male swimmers came in from their training session, but then we felt rather large when we watched the young girls who were training as gymnasts. Whether it is the strength of the swimmers or the grace, agility and style of the gymnasts, we have it all.

Several people have said to me recently that they do not think we should spend all this money on the Institute of Sport. They think that people who train with their local trainers can achieve just as much and, certainly, a lot of them have. But I think the worth of the Australian Institute of Sport has been well shown in these Commonwealth Games. It has given an opportunity for so many of those people to get in there, train seriously and live a normal life at the same time. In no better way is that shown than with the gymnasts. Most of them are very young. They are still at school and still need a certain amount of parenting. Some of you may have seen a documentary on their training program. I think the Institute of Sport plays an enormous role in the training of these people.

I would like to add my congratulations to all of those involved. As the honourable member for Canberra said, we must not forget the trainers, managers and support staff—all of those people who ensure that the athletes get there and do the things they were trained to do. Congratulations to everybody who has been involved. Well done. I hope we do just as well at the next Olympics.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to follow up the comments that have been made by others before me in this debate. I give my personal congratulations to all those who competed—to those who won medals of all varieties and to everyone who did not win a medal because their contribution was equal to that of those who were rewarded for their efforts.

PARA.TAB: I make absolutely no apologies for being totally parochial in what I am going to say. I am going to refer to the great efforts of the `Ballarat bullet', Steve Moneghetti. Steve's win in the early hours of this morning, which I watched when I was tucked up in bed with my electric blanket on 3 as it was minus six degrees, was a very hot performance from a very talented man. To see his wife, Tania, who has been an enormous support to him, at the finishing line last night was something that would have moved all people from Ballarat and I think it would have moved all Australians as well. Waiting at home is their young daughter, Emma Grace Moneghetti.

I do not want to talk so much about Steve Moneghetti in his role as an athlete but as the ambassador of Ballarat and Australia. This is a man who is extremely charming and friendly but, above all, he has maintained and retained his modesty. For any world-class athlete to do that is something of great significance and something that we should recognise in this place. When Steve Moneghetti runs around Lake Wendouree, he is running for Ballarat. That can never be overestimated. When Steve Moneghetti runs that lap, he is saying, `I am here supporting you and I will push this region as hard as I can.'

My own children, aged nine, seven and four, affectionately refer to Steve Moneghetti as `Mona'. When my children, or other children, see Steve running or walking around the lake, they ask, `How are you going, Mona?' and they get a response every time. This man has retained his modesty, and I think he is a shining example for every elite athlete in this country. I know that he is very widely respected and was made captain of the men's athletic team.

While I am talking about marathon runners, I would like to talk about Tani Ruckle. That was an extraordinary performance from a young lady who showed quite extraordinary guts. That is the only way to put it. My sympathies go out to her for what she had to go through and I hope that she makes a speedy recovery. When you look at Steve Moneghetti, he has seen the highs and the lows. I am sure there have been times when he felt like giving it away, but he has not. He has stuck to his guns and he has now reaped that ultimate award, which is the Commonwealth medal.

On behalf of everyone from Ballarat, and I am sure I speak for all Australians, I ask Steve Moneghetti to compete at the next Olympics. I am sure that an Olympic gold medal would quite justly cap off what has been an extraordinarily successful career. My thanks go out to all those athletes who did this country proud over the past 10 or 11 days. They are elite athletes without peer throughout the world. I know that everyone in this House is extremely proud of what they have done. I give my personal thanks to Steve Moneghetti, again, for what he does for my own region of Ballarat.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to participate in the debate this afternoon. It also gives me much pleasure to see the way in which we are able to jump across the political divide today to support the Commonwealth Games team. Many have spoken already and more will speak in the next hour or so about aspects of our Commonwealth Games performance, such as the way in which our multicultural society has been represented by the results in Canada. I think that is testimony in itself to the success of the multicultural policies that this government has been fostering.

PARA.TAB: What gave me a great source of pride in being able to listen, watch and read about our performances in Canada was not necessarily the winning, although that has been given a great deal of prominence, but the way in which our athletes participated. Whether they were disabled or able-bodied athletes, they participated wholeheartedly and in the spirit of good sportsmanship.

Whilst there have been those who achieved success by winning a medal, there were many who did not, and one of those was a person from the Northern Territory, Brendan Tennant, who finished ninth in the decathlon. Brendan is young; he is only 21 years of age. I think he can be justly proud of his performance for his country. I know the pride that he should have for himself, and I am sure is shared by his family, is pride that the community of the Northern Territory has as well.

As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Northern Territory takes great pride in its high level of participation in sport and has had many sporting heroes. In these Commonwealth Games, Brendan and two other competitors—they were more successful than Brendan, at least in so far as medals are concerned—were from the Northern Territory. Brendan, as I said, is 21 years of age and, after putting in a tremendous performance, he finished in ninth place behind the gold medallist for the decathlon, Michael Smith.

Christine Trefry, as I am sure you would be aware, won three gold medals for Australia and is from Alice Springs. She won a gold medal in the women's sport pistol pairs, the women's air pistol pairs and the independent women's sports pistol. She was the first woman from the Northern Territory to achieve the honour of being chosen to represent this country in the Commonwealth Games. Christine, along with a boxer, James Swan—a young Aboriginal bloke from Alice Springs—were the first two centralians to be chosen for Australia in the Commonwealth Games.

Alice Springs is a relativity small community and to have two of its citizens chosen to represent this country at the Commonwealth Games—one of them to win three gold medals and the other to win a bronze medal—is a source of pride and great celebration to us as it is to the Northern Territory generally. I want to say just a couple of words about these two people, in addition to what I have said about Brendan. I think it is important we understand that living in a remote community is not always a bar to achieving the highest level of performance in a particular field.

Christine first took up pistol shooting as a hobby 10 years ago whilst living on Groote Eylandt. Groote Eylandt is not a metropolis. She then moved to Katherine and subsequently to Alice Springs. She was able to achieve selection and win, I think, two national championships. She won selection to the Commonwealth Games and at 39 years of age has won three gold medals. She is obviously someone of great ability and has been a great ambassador for this country.

James Swan is a different sort of person who, from the reports which have been sent from Canada, warmed the hearts of many Australians because of the way he bravely fought in his division as a 57-kilogram featherweight and, whilst winning the bronze medal, lost a fight on what any objective observer would have seen as a disputed points decision, but nevertheless took that defeat very courageously. Although he must have been bitterly disappointed, he demonstrated his resolve, his commitment and his desire to win and to do the best for himself and his country, but most particularly for his family and for his grandmother, who brought him up.

It is difficult for many of us who live in more comfortable circumstances to understand the struggles that take place in some communities in Australia. For a young Aboriginal bloke like James to become a successful boxer in the amateur ranks in Australia, win successive championships, be selected for the Commonwealth Games and then go on to win a bronze medal says a great deal about him.

Prior to each fight I understand that he would go across to his opponent's corner and give his opponent a small memento of Australia. Obviously I do not know whether this was a disarming tactic, but it was surely an indication of the goodwill with which this young man participated and was involved in his sport. He wanted to achieve the best possible results, he wanted to win, he was committed and he was dedicated. That dedication, I am sure, will do a great deal for James, not only if he continues as a boxer but in his general life. I pay particular tribute to him for his performance in these Commonwealth Games.

We as Australians can be justly proud of our sports men and women. Any casual observer of their performance would have to say that at least the way respected governments around this country have put in for developing the particular ability of our sporting men and women has borne massive fruit. I am sure that our competitors, those people from the other Commonwealth nations and eventually those in the Olympic Games—if not in the next Olympics, certainly by the year 2000—will see that the way we have dedicated resources to foster sporting ability in this country will achieve further results in those subsequent games appearances. They will be wanting to learn from us. Certainly there were some observations made by English swimmers about the way the Institute of Sport operates. I am sure that will be the case for our cyclists, most importantly. Their outstanding performance will make everyone take note, as with our weight-lifters from Victoria. We have done a great deal to foster sporting activity in this country. We can be very proud of it. It has been shared by the general community. We as a nation can be proud.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to add my congratulations to our athletes to those that have already been offered by other members. Unfortunately, I have seen very little television, but 7 o'clock in the morning seems a good catch-up time. I was pleased at that time to have seen Cathy Freeman. I certainly found no offence whatsoever in the fact that she first picked up the Aboriginal flag, but then so promptly after that the Australian flag, and paraded both proudly. I thought she was a great example to others. The sheer elation she showed and her pride in her country is to be commended. The controversy that followed was unfortunate but I am sure that she has the support of the majority of the Australian population.

PARA.TAB: Eighty-seven gold, 52 silver and 43 bronze is a great record for Australia and puts us a long way in the lead of other Commonwealth countries. In the brief time that I had to watch television it was good to see a reminder of the Commonwealth and the spirit that exists not only in sport but also in other ways. It was good to see countries like Namibia and South Africa represented, both new to or rejoining the Commonwealth—certainly, in South Africa's case, very recently. Our athletes were a great example to our other young Australians, showing that discipline, working hard and really trying to reach their potential can mean great success.

Nine gold medals will come home to my own state of South Australia. I have been assured by our sports minister there, who has recently returned from Canada, that we will be holding a reception to welcome them home. That is particularly appropriate. We are rather hopeful that in South Australia we will be able to host the games in the year 2002. I understand we will need some federal funding to achieve that. I hope that the government will be pleasantly disposed to our requirements so we can then put in a bid. I understand that only if the bid is successful will we need that funding. It would be good to think that we could have it on our home turf. It would not be quite so far for other Australians then to travel to see it, rather than having to see it on television.

Again, my congratulations to all our athletes who took part, to all those who supported them and to their parents and their families, who would have given huge support in the lead-up to the games, the coaches and to those who accompanied them and cared for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add another dimension to this short debate. Without in any way detracting from the magnificent performance of those who won gold, silver and bronze medals and certainly those young people and not so young people who have etched a place for us in Commonwealth history and, indeed, in the annals of sporting history, I think sometimes we get caught up in the hype of the media and not recognise that a vast number of the team won no gold, no silver and no bronze, yet made an magnificent contribution to the holding of those games, to the spirit of sportsmanship, to their own self-esteem and to the honour of this country. Not much has been said about them today. I think we should recognise them.

PARA.TAB: The fact that we are now winning gold medals in badminton, in boxing again after a long drought and in some of the fields of gymnastics did not come about overnight. It came about by a combination of factors, one of which was undoubtedly the Australian Institute of Sport. The second was the commitment of the governing bodies of those particular sports. The third thing, and in a way the most important thing, was that Australia sent athletes to those lesser known sports over a number of years. They played well, they performed well, they did credit to Australia, but they did not come home with medals. However, they built a profile for Australia in those sports that has been able to be capitalised on by this current team in Victoria.

I am sure we recognise that a number of athletes who spent two years or more preparing for these games had some sad eventualities. One athlete I would like to single out is Simon Doyle, who comes from my electorate. Simon has certainly made an immense contribution to middle distance athletics in Australia over the last three or four years and to be so cruelly deprived of success because of injury, firstly in Barcelona and then in Victoria, must go down as one most of the unfortunate situations that any young Australian athlete has had to suffer over recent years.

Nevertheless, I congratulate him. I congratulate those athletes who were not medal winners but who distinguished themselves, their country and their sports and who laid the foundation from which Australia will in future Commonwealth and Olympic games perform even more creditably.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—I call the Parliamentary Secretary who has returned safely from a recent visit to Inglewood.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seem to be doing a lot of visits to National Party electorates these days.
—Visiting a few branches too.
—A few members of the National Party have been concerned about the possibility.
—Are you going to talk about sport?

—Yes, but the honourable member for Kooyong will be pleased to know that I am not going to talk about Essendon. I want to add my support to what has been said and add that the government is very happy to see that there is bipartisan support for the magnificent effort of our sports people in Canada. I think the games have made the nation proud of itself and proud of its identity. They have made the nation more solid in its commitment to its future. This magnificent victory is no doubt one of the greatest achievements of modern Australian history. Australia has not only come out on top in these games but also come out well ahead of so many countries and it has been a magnificent effort by our people.

PARA.TAB: Sometimes people say, `How can we fashion the idea of national unity when we have a multicultural nation?'—as though the two issues are in contradiction. Anyone who has seen these games and who saw all of our people who stood up, proudly Australian, from different lands and with different surnames and Christian names, would know that they were all united in that they were all going for gold for Australia.

I think that is a very significant and symbolic point in our history. What it shows is that rather than multiculturalism being a weakness, as some people have argued, it is actually a great strength. It has allowed people from these different backgrounds to come together and to be able to rise within our system. That is what access and equity is about. Included in our system is sport and the ability to represent our nation and actually win and win well.

There have been fantastic examples of that success. Steve Moneghetti was mentioned before. He is from an Italian background. We saw the fantastic performance of Kasumi Takahashi in the rhythmic gymnastics. She is from a part Japanese background. It was well worth watching the grace and elegance of her performance—it was something else. Our weight-lifters have recently come from countries such as Romania and Bulgaria and they have become proud Australians and have participated in their sport and won gold for Australia.

Multiculturalism also encapsulates our indigenous people. Everyone has commented on the great performance of Cathy Freeman. It was summed up on the front page of the Telegraph Mirror where there was a picture of Cathy Freeman and a big headline `Cathy unites the nation'. I think that is illustrative of the way in which our people, the Australian nation, are looking at these games. In a sense these games have symbolised the message of the Australian people and brought it back into this chamber. What do the Australian people want? They want to celebrate multiculturalism, national unity and pride in Australia but they also want to celebrate our respect for the cultural diversity and the different traditions that have made this a great nation and an example to the world.

It is a wonderful time from a sports point of view and generally to be Australian. I think the big powers in sport that saw the performance of Australia in the Commonwealth Games must be getting a bit worried to see this smaller country with its wonderful effort and its multicultural base coming forward and bringing the best out in people. I am sure that Australia is going to do very well in the Olympic Games in 1996 and the year 2000.

I congratulate everyone involved in the organisation of the games. People have mentioned that the Australian Institute of Sport has done a marvellous job. In some cases, athletes' families have contributed through very hard work and effort to get the people there and to give them the support over the years so that they can represent our nation and do us proud. Congratulations to everyone. The government is very proud of the performance and I am sure the whole of the parliament is proud as well. The message about the cultural diversity of our people and the potential to unify and contribute to Australia's success has come back to this parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 25 August, on motion by Mr Gear:
That the bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Mr Costello had moved by way of amendment:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)its continuing mismanagement of Commonwealth-State relations; and
(2)its threat to recoup from any State funds paid to that State as a result of the Parliament of that State repealing laws which prescribe compulsory student unionism universities.

TALK.START.PARA: —In joining this debate on the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill, I take the opportunity to speak about a couple of matters that have arisen. I would like to start by addressing the rather peculiar and specific provision in this bill that proposes to fine state governments who have the temerity to do something that this federal government does not like.

PARA.TAB: I refer to sections 25A and 25B of the higher education legislation that was introduced in this place and the enabling section in this bill which allows the government to reduce its general purpose funding to a state if it passes legislation to make student union contributions at tertiary institutions voluntary. It is a fine situation when we have the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) lecturing us at question time about privacy and human rights, but we still have in this House a view that if this government decides someone should be in a union he or she will be in a union. Of course, there is both a human rights and a privacy situation arising there.

I have considered this issue for a long time. I have an absolute commitment to the right of people to volunteer to join a student union. I have never heard so much rubbish as that which has emanated from so-called learned people, such as university chancellors and others, who tell us why people should make these contributions. They are interested only in protecting their revenue.

The first reason that they give us is not that this is a great slush fund for certain political activists within the university system. They have to give it a higher profile than that. So they say, `Oh, it's for the provision of services.' That is fine. Services such as cafeterias, bars and sporting amenities are provided at universities. One would think it is reasonable to argue that people should contribute to the provision of these services.

However, some students may not drink alcoholic beverages. Some may prefer to take their own salad for lunch because, amongst other things, they are under some financial pressure at home. Some students may not want to pay even the subsidised prices at the cafeteria. Others may not like pies or the food that is presented. Why should these people have to pay for the services? Why should they have to make an up-front charge when they do not use all of those services? There is a very simple solution. Those services do not have to be closed down, as is implied by these highly intelligent people. They can be run commercially and tendered out. They can charge at a profit. Those people who think that the convenience is worth while can use them. Maybe McDonalds or Burger King could get in there.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member cannot tell me that the tucker is much better because I have eaten at the cafeterias from time to time. The simple fact is that those services can be provided on a commercial basis. They do not need to be subsidised up-front by people who do not use them. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), who is a committed proponent of student fees, is to speak after me. He might like to explain why someone who does not use the cafeteria or the bar and who is not interested in the free drinks that are turned on every now and again for political purposes should have to pay for them? It is a simple question. I do not see why that student should have to pay for those services when they can be provided on a purely commercial basis. Those who use them can pay the going price.

PARA.TAB: I refer to organised sport. A lot of people who go to university do not play organised sport or choose not to play within the university. Why should they have to pay an up-front fee for that service? Why can't the people who choose to be in the footy team, to be in the hockey team, to play tennis or to use other facilities which are provided pay for those services? That is quite reasonable. They are the ones who use them. There is a user-pays policy in just about everything you bring into this parliament today. It is quite reasonable. If certain people do not use those facilities, why should they be made to pay for them? It is totally unsustainable in the context of university life.

There is no reason why people who want to play organised sports should not pay for that service? Those who do not wish to play may have to decide between paying for a pair of shoes for their kids and paying that university fee. Why should they have to pay so that other single people can go out on the weekend and use free facilities provided at the university by people who do not use them?

Let us get to the facts. There are people at university today—and we know all about mature age education—who are struggling. They have children. You are telling them that they have to pay for these sorts of amenities and facilities when it might mean the difference between paying that fee and paying for a new pair of shoes for one of their children. Any member who believes that is right should stand up and put it on the record. I will make sure that it is well known in various places.

I refer to political activism. Any poll will show that the biggest percentage of young people who go to university are political `apathists', if there is such a word. They are totally apathetic towards and uninterested in student activism. They do not want to be involved in the Labor Party, the Liberal Party, the Democrats or any other party. In some cases, they resent the compulsion to vote. We tell them that they should fund it. Why should that occur in a free society? There is no reason.

Certain state governments, which are elected by the people of that state and which are subject to being kicked out if they take decisions of this nature which are not approved by the people of that state, should be able to make a decision about that. They should be able to say, `This is a user-pays situation. We're not stopping anyone from doing it. We're just going to make it voluntary.' But, no, it does not fit the collectivist attitude of this government on that particular issue. So the states will be punished. You will take some of their money back and give it to those student unions.

I am laughing my head off about this. Suddenly, you are turning away from a situation which was totally internal to the university. If there were scandals in the way the money was utilised, it was only the chancellor who was answerable. Now you will make yourself answerable. Let us consider all the little scams. I do not know whether they are going to keep sending a little bit of money to Libya or some terrorist organisation—as they have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish, absolute rubbish!

—If you want to stand up and say they have not, you would be misleading this parliament. If you want to be responsible for the free beer and the free buses that are turned on from time to time through student activism, good on you. I will just sit back and watch you make idiots of yourselves as your little low level union activists back in the universities get you into trouble when they do not spend the money according to the requirements of the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: Before this debate is closed, you might tell us who is going to audit these funds when you start providing the money. As far as I am concerned, if it is anyone less than the Auditor-General, you are failing in your responsibility to the taxpayers of Australia. You are so smart with this fancy idea that you are now committing taxpayers' funds to the hands of a little group, a committee, in each university. I assume you have not given a thought to the prudential requirements associated with that. But I have, and I will be demanding that, from time to time, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and a few others have a look at how that money is being spent.

That is what you are doing. You are going to give the unions the money and say, `The state governments will have a little less.' Where is that money coming from? It is the same with all of these issues. You think you can move money from A to B and nothing will change. Let me remind you that nobody has ever repeated the trick performed by the good Lord when he fed the multitude with two fishes and five loaves of bread—or the other way around. If you take from here, you have to put it there. Or if you put it there, you have to take from here. If you take money from state governments, if you force the taxpayer to pay for these student unions, then that is money that will not be spent on primary schools, roads or health. It will come from somewhere so that your little political mates can maintain this power base of money and largess that they distribute around the universities.

I have had kids at university. I know how it works. Some of you who have been there more recently know how it works, but you will not admit to it. The issue is: where is the money coming from? It will not materialise. It will come from one of those areas. That is why I support wholeheartedly the amendment put forward by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello), which condemns this particular decision.

Good luck to you! You have hung your hat on this decision and it will end up being an embarrassment. I will bet that before long you blokes will be running around in circles trying to explain where the money went, who got it and whether it was donated to some terrorist state or something else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—You can laugh your head off, but please write down somewhere, `I laughed at Tuckey today.' In two or three years, you will realise that you put your foot in your mouth.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! The honourable member should direct his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quite right, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will tell you about it, Mr Deputy Speaker, because you and I can laugh together when these people come in here and say, `We got it wrong. Those lovely little people we trusted have knocked off some of the money. They haven't stolen it. They've just spent it outside what any Australian taxpayer would think was reasonable for their money.' I can tell you straight that they will not be too happy about the free booze and the free bus rides when the activists get drummed up to protest against something.

PARA.TAB: The alternative, which currently applies and which you condemn because a couple of states are saying they will make it voluntary, has been iniquitous. So many people go to university today. There should not be a price of that nature to get your exam papers marked. That is not Australian. We have been talking a bit about what being Australian stands for today.

When this bill was being debated last week the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) gave us a lecture on the financial responsibility of state governments and how they might spend this money, and he sneered at the phrase `states rights'. States rights have been made into a figure of fun and sneering. Somehow, states rights are institutionalised. There is never a relationship between states rights and people's rights in the minds of those who sit on the benches opposite. But I see that entirely differently.

States rights are people's rights for the simple reason that people elect state governments. They have a great deal more influence over their state governments than they do over this parliament. It is not too bad if you come from Victoria or New South Wales and are only an hour or less away in jet time from this wonderful capital. It is not too bad if as a New South Welshman you hold 50 seats in this place or as a Victorian you hold 45 seats—I do not know the exact figure—because you have a pretty fair influence here. But, if you are a Tasmanian with five seats or a Western Australian with 14 seats, you rely very heavily on your vote for a state politician because you have got damn-all say here in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least you have got one vote, one value here, not like in Western Australia.
—That is all right. That is an issue you can argue as long as you like because they are all in my electorate. It does not worry me very much.
—The honourable member should direct his comments more directly to the bill and through the chair.

—You are quite right. I apologise, Mr Deputy Speaker. The people of a state have demonstrated over the years that they choose one side of politics over the other, but they demand some representation. The politicians, in representing their views, know very well that if they do the wrong thing they will be defeated at the next election.

PARA.TAB: Why not, under our constitutional arrangements, let the people of those states have their way on issues? Why have we constantly got to sell our soul to the United Nations through a variety of conventions so that we—the people who have a mortgage on morality, a mortgage on good intelligence; the 147 of us here apparently are the only ones—can tell those people in those states how to run their affairs on matters which our constitution fundamentally says are their affairs? States rights are the rights of the people of a state to elect a state government and ask it to conduct their affairs as they like.

We have been hearing all this rubbish about privacy in the home. Since when has any Australian under federal or state law had privacy in the home? The massive hypocrisy is we have two issues before us: one relating to laws in Tasmania and another relating to X-rated videos.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am finding it very difficult to relate this to the bill.

—It is states rights, which is fundamental to this particular issue, Mr Deputy Speaker, because it is the funding of state money. If you were to consult the Hansard of last week, you would see that I am basically responding to the remarks of the member for Werriwa, who made this attack on the rights of state governments.

PARA.TAB: We are about to pass legislation in this House banning even the ownership, the having in your house, of certain videos; and I think we are quite right to do so. We are going to have a classification that says you just cannot own them. You would not have the type of video referred to. If we are going to say that the home is inviolate, that you can have privacy for anything in your home, which I believe is what we are trying to do, then one must ask: what about videos? There are people who would claim that the watching of a violent or sexually violent video is their right as long as they do it in the privacy of their own home. They would argue that they are not hurting anybody else by doing it. Yet on that issue we will collectively say they cannot.

In every state—and the laws vary between the states—we put substantial constraints on people drinking and driving, and so we should. The argument that people have a total right to privacy is absolutely silly—just because it is convenient for them on a particular issue. Of course we do not allow people total rights within their house or within their motor car or anywhere else, and nor should we. We should not use that as an excuse if we want to subjugate ourselves to one political lobby or another. That is what the Tasmanian situation, of course, is all about.

States do have rights. If the Premier of Tasmania believes his people have an objection to a certain activity, be it in the privacy of their homes or anywhere else, he has a responsibility to represent that interest for that community. If the people of Sydney have the entirely opposite idea on that, let the Premier of New South Wales address it. That is quite reasonable. We have a federal system and that is the way it should work. But I am here to argue on this funding and I wish I had time—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are 100 years behind.

—No, I am not. I am saying that I am totally committed to the concept of people's rights, but I cannot see them getting justice in this place if they have five seats out of 147. The founding fathers could not see that happening and that is why they wrote the federal constitution we have today, which says that state parliaments have certain rights and certain responsibilities. The voters of that state will very quickly demonstrate that to them at the ballot box if they are not fulfilling them.

PARA.TAB: We should not interfere on that issue. If, for instance, Ray Groom has got it so wrong, he will be kicked out at the next election. Let it be decided down there. Why decide it here when the poor old people of Tasmania have so little influence in this place—five out of 147. They are mostly on your side too. That is an easy issue.

States rights are the rights of people within a state to have a slightly different view to the majority of Australians—our constitution recognises that—and they should have the right to do so. I will close on that point, notwithstanding that I would have liked to have talked about the money as well. People in a state do have rights, and that is what states rights are all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed to see the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) leaving. He was going to wait for me to respond to him. The States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1994 does a number of things. It provides on an annual basis general purpose funding for the states, which dovetails with the Loan Council arrangements with respect to the borrowing programs of the states and the Commonwealth. It provides for the level of financial assistance grants to be maintained on a real per capita basis over the next three years. It provides special revenue assistance for things such as Medicare guarantee payments and the like. It provides $350 million in arterial road funding to the states for the 1994-95 budgetary year.

PARA.TAB: Finally, it provides, as the honourable member for O'Connor dealt with at some length, for voluntary student unionism legislation in at least two states to have a countervailing neutralising impact in federal legislation. This is being pursued both in this piece of legislation and also in an amendment to the Higher Education Funding Act, which will be dealt with in this House in the very near future if not later this week. Other than to make a couple of brief comments, I will reserve my views on that matter until we debate the second piece of legislation I referred to.

It is unfortunate that the honourable member for O'Connor has chosen to challenge me to respond to the matter, has said that he would be very interested to hear what I had to say about it, and then has left. Such is life. I would point out to him that, for all his wailing about how evil it is that university students are being forced to contribute to the cost of running university sporting clubs, his own party, under the Victorian state government legislation, has provided for that to continue. Perhaps he should have a chat to Jeff Kennett about this issue, because under the legislation that the Victorian Premier introduced into the Victorian parliament there were a number of areas where compulsory fees were still able to be levied on students enrolling at universities. The funding of student sport was one of them.

In the initial legislation there was a very stark contrast—a quite obvious contradiction—between sporting, cultural and artistic activities. Under the legislation, although it was not possible for any levy or fee to be struck to cover cultural, artistic and musical activities, it was possible to cover university sporting activities. Subsequently, the legislation has been amended by the Kennett government to remove that most glaring anomaly and include areas such as culture and music. I would suggest to the honourable member for O'Connor that maybe he should have a bit of an argument on this issue with people in his own party first.

I would also suggest to him that the principle of user-pays that he has advocated is a fairly extreme one which is not taken literally anywhere in our society. I live in the local government area of Moreland, which was previously the local government area of Brunswick. It has a public swimming pool, which costs a bit to run. There is a bit of a subsidy from the local council, although it is a lot less than it used to be. Unfortunately, it is a long time since I have gone for a swim there. A variety of other local council services that I do not use—and may never use—are funded by me, indirectly, through my rates. So the notion that we should collectively act to provide services to the community at large, based on some form of compulsory levy—in this case, rates—is very well entrenched in our community.

It is not an absolute analogy, but local governments and the student organisations in universities have many similarities. I would argue that, as social entities, university campuses are in fact very similar to local communities. Therefore, some form of compulsory fee which contributes to the provision of a wide variety of services to students and is controlled by democratically elected students—roughly equivalent to local or council elections, and with turnouts for voting that in many instances are not much lower than the turnouts for local council elections—is appropriate. There is no more logic in suggesting a complete user-pays approach in a non-academic services provision for a university campus than there is in suggesting it in local government. I suspect the honourable member for O'Connor may even contemplate it in local government. I suspect some more extreme libertarians in his party certainly would.

I would like to concentrate on an issue which is connected with these very vital matters of federal-state financial relations; that is, the future of Australia's airports. On the weekend a proposal was floated that would see the state and local governments assume a vital role in owning and operating the airports in Australia that are currently run by the Federal Airports Corporation. Of course, this would have significant implications for the federal-state financial relations framework with respect to grants and loans covered by this bill.

By way of background, I would like to respond to some of the things that were said on this issue by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) in his speech, to which the honourable member for O'Connor previously referred. I asked the following questions about the proposed sale of the airports, which the honourable member for Werriwa sought to answer. Has the performance of the FAC been satisfactory? What is the overseas experience? Is it appropriate that there should be internal cross-subsidies within the airport structure? What impact would privatisation have? What scope is there for competition between airports? Would the federal government achieve an optimum financial outcome? This is obviously relevant to its relations with the states as well, depending on where the airports ended up as a result of their being sold. What are the implications for workers in those organisations?

The honourable member for Werriwa sought to respond to each of these questions, and I would like to respond to his response. He indicated that in his view the FAC performance had been particularly unsatisfactory and that the PSA was very critical of the pricing policies and investment criteria that had been adopted by the FAC. I suggest to the honourable member for Werriwa that he is overstating somewhat the criticisms of the PSA. Yes, it was critical, but it did say that it `had difficulty making a firm judgment about the operating efficiency of the FAC' because it very much depends on which indicators you look at. Its conclusion was:

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the commercial and financial objectives set for the FAC in its Act, the FAC could be considered to be successful. It has met the Government's target rate of return in each year of its operation and it has paid dividends to the Government. Also it is now liable to pay income tax. The FAC has significantly increased revenue from non-aeronautical sources. Aeronautical charges have not risen significantly in real terms.

A recent Bureau of Industry Economics study has indicated that our airport charges are amongst the lowest in the world and our service levels and efficiency are amongst the best. The fundamental point here is that, to the extent that there are problems with our airports as they currently are managed, those problems can very easily be addressed by the government without its having to sell them.

PARA.TAB: The second point is overseas experience. The honourable member for Werriwa indicated that there are several precedents for private ownership in the United Kingdom, the United States and Asia. Certainly in the United Kingdom that is the case, but I would be interested to hear where are the other precedents in the United States and Asia. I am sure that the honourable member for Werriwa is right, but in the research that I have done I have not discovered any.

I was interested to find that in 1991 even the Bush administration opposed and blocked the proposed privatisation of a major airport in New York state for a variety of reasons similar to the concerns that I have with respect to the proposal in Australia that is before us at the moment. So I think the sweeping statement that private ownership exists to some significant extent in the United States and Asia really requires some greater indications of which airports and on what basis.

The honourable member went on to say, `Those countries have demonstrated that private ownership of airports leads to a better incentive for urban and regional development surrounding the airport site.' Again I am prepared to give the honourable member the benefit of the doubt and ask for further information and evidence to back up that statement, but certainly the research work that I have done suggests that it is difficult to see how that can be the case.

The honourable member cited the Cairns airport as an illustration of how this can occur, and already has occurred, in the Australian context. The point he missed about Cairns is that it is still under public ownership, albeit local public ownership—as are most of the non-FAC airports across Australia. Obviously we have to acknowledge that the strength of Cairns airport and its custom substantially reflect the popularity of Cairns as a tourist destination.

Clearly you can argue—and I think it has to be conceded to some extent—that there is a synergy between the two. A higher quality of airport service provision may have been a contributing factor, at least on the margins, to Cairns's growing popularity as a tourist destination, but I doubt whether it is anything more than on the margins. The third question addressed by the honourable member was cross-subsidies within the existing FAC network. They occur at three levels: from the major airports to the smaller airports, on a regional basis; from non-aeronautical revenue to aeronautical costs; and from the major passenger and freight air traffic to general aviation.

The honourable member described the cross-subsidies regime that operates at the moment as `flawed'. I think that is an arguable point. I think there are certain points which could be put to suggest that that may be the case in some instances. However, the government could solve that problem—if there is a problem—tomorrow. We do not even need to legislate. The minister has the power to direct the FAC, in the public interest, under the existing legislation. Even though there are limitations on that power, if those limitations came into play, we could legislate. Even if we accept that the cross-subsidies regime does have problems, we can solve those problems without having to go to the extreme of selling the airports.

It is also worth pointing out that in at least one instance—that is, cross-subsidisation from non-aeronautical fees to aeronautical charges—it is common around the world. It is a standard picture. Where it is particularly happening more than anywhere else is in Britain. The British Airports Authority is relying increasingly on revenue from shopping malls and the like to bolster its airport services.

The comments by the honourable member with respect to flawed accounting and a lack of transparency on the part of the FAC may well be true. But, once again, the answer lies in our own hands; we do not have to go to the extreme of selling the airports in order to fix it. He said that, stripped of debt, only two of the existing FAC airports would be non-profitable. That is true. In fact, it may well be that none of them would be non-profitable and that they would all be profitable, but it is a fairly artificial way of looking at it.

In the future, I look forward to people fronting up at the Federal Court for bankruptcy proceedings and saying, `If it was not for the debt, we would be perfectly viable.' Debt is obviously a logical part of a corporate structure both in the public and private sectors. To suggest that we look at these airports and forget about the debt is a very artificial way of looking at the picture.

The suggestion that the rich benefit from cross-subsidies is a little difficult to sustain because it ignores the question of who pays the cross-subsidies. By and large, those who are better off in the first place pay the cross-subsidies which head to regional airports. It is also worth pointing out that not only rich consumers benefit from cross-subsidies. For example, the increased freight costs that are part of any cross-subsidy situation obviously flow through into the price of products that are purchased by the whole community. So ultimately you could argue that an increase in freight costs for some of the smaller regional airports will be borne in a similar way to a GST by people in the community. So the issue needs closer examination.

With regard to the impact of privatisation, the honourable member for Werriwa suggested that we missed our chance to tackle these issues when the FAC was corporatised and that, in a sense, corporatisation was all about making the airports run in the market like private enterprises. That is an inaccurate description of what the government did when it set up the FAC. The primary thrust of the FAC legislation was to remove the subsidisation of our airports from the general revenue. Something like $1.5 billion over the preceding 12 years had gone into our airports from non-airport derived revenue—namely, from the general taxpayer. That was the primary thrust of the legislation. The honourable member for Werriwa stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It was at that point that the government said that this is an economic and transport activity that can operate according to the rules of the private market.

That is obviously an incorrect statement. If it were correct, we would not now be having this debate. Quite clearly, there are substantial restrictions, such as cross-subsidies, on the operation of the FAC in a private market sense. So the suggestion that we did it all back then is not correct. The honourable member also stated:
. . . there should not be any scaremongering regarding the extent of increased charges—they are spread across the industry and have a marginal impact on airport consumers.

That is basically a statement which implies uniform pricing, which is exactly what we have at the moment. Increased charges will ultimately hit on specific regional airports if we free up the airports from the current cross-subsidy arrangements. To suggest, as the honourable member does—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which honourable member is this? Is this still the honourable member for Werriwa?
—Yes, that is right.
—This is a very big bucket on Werriwa.

—Stop interrupting, I am running out of time. To suggest, as the honourable member for Werriwa does, that the increase in charges would be distributed across all airports is simply not correct, because that would simply replicate the existing situation. The problem is that some airports would have their charges go down while the charges of others would go up. I concede that this problem has been exaggerated by some people in the debate. It may well be that we can make this change without the regional impact being too serious. But, quite clearly, some airports would have their charges go up substantially and others would not.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Werriwa is absolutely right on one fundamental point, which is that we should be using the proceeds of this sale, if it does proceed, to finance other infrastructure. To be effectively spending this money as current expenditure is absolutely wrong in principle and practically. If we decide that we should sell the airports, we should be reinvesting the proceeds of those public assets in other public assets.

There is the question of competition. Largely I agree with the honourable member that predominantly we are dealing with natural monopolies that have prospect for competition in some areas and at some levels. But it is also worth noting that there are other levels of competition in this area. There is obviously competition with other transport modes. It will vary according to which airport one is talking about. Indirect competition is associated with the costs that are built into particular products by the airport charges. So there are broader issues on the competition front.

I note that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has stated recently that the proposal I referred to earlier is contrary to the principles of the Hilmer report. I suggest to him that what is contrary to the principles of the Hilmer report is selling our airports. Once Australian Airlines and Qantas are privatised, we will have a classic model of the `essential facilities' doctrine, which is advanced in the Hilmer report, in place in the air transport industry in this country. Namely, where one is dealing with things like electricity, railways and the like, the natural monopoly components should be in public ownership and the use of those components—the generation and distribution of electricity or the running of trains on railway tracks—can be opened up to private competition. Once we only have private operators in the airline industry, that is precisely what we will have.

The honourable member for Werriwa attacked Professor Bob Walker, whom he described as `Rent-a-result'. I am disappointed in that comment, because it is difficult for Professor Walker to respond. This is a fairly serious charge against him. I have not dealt with Professor Walker before, so I have no idea whether there is any substance in the charge. It is unfortunate that the honourable member chose to attack the author of the report without responding to the substance and putting forward a critique of his conclusions.

The real value of our airports is open to some debate. Obviously, it is an artificial market construct. But the federal government is saying that they are worth $2 billion. It is difficult to precisely identify their true value. It depends on the conditions under which they are sold. But to simply dismiss Professor Walker's analysis by saying, `He would say that anyway' is a bit unfair. It fails to address the issue of whether he is right. He may be `Rent-a-result' for all I know, but the question is whether he is right.

The final area where I have a different view from the honourable member for Werriwa concerns his comments that the Transport Workers Union supports the proposal, `so the main bodies of workers are covered in this proposition'. The main body of workers are not covered in this proposition because the main body of workers who work for the FAC are members of the PSU, or the Public Sector Union, and the AFMEU, or the Automotive, Food, Metals and Engineering Union.

The Transport Workers Union may well support the proposition, because it has interests in those unionists ultimately becoming members of the Transport Workers Union, but certainly the two main unions involved do not. The honourable member for Werriwa referred to the `cosy relationship' between the FAC and those other unions without putting forward any evidence to suggest that there is substance in that statement.
