TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to hear that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), found that the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) was right on at least one point. What a pity he was wrong on all other 200,000 points. I direct my attention in this debate on the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill to clause 15, which deals with the higher education funding condition. I preface my comments by referring to legislation in Western Australia, which is one of the reasons for the insertion of this clause.

PARA.TAB: At the 1993 state election, the Western Australian coalition promised, as part of its education policy, to make membership to student unions voluntary. With its very resounding victory, the Western Australian coalition was given a mandate to introduce its policies, including its policy to provide freedom of association to students at our universities. Section 25A and the proposed section 25B of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 allows the Commonwealth to reimburse student unions for any income lost through the introduction of voluntary student unionism in any state.

Clause 15 of this bill provides that any money paid by the Commonwealth as a result of this will be a debt owed by the relevant state to the Commonwealth. Prior to the Western Australian government introducing this legislation, we had last year the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), in typical Labor thuggery style threaten to fund the student unions with this legislation by penalising the states. I said at the time that it was bullyboy tactics and I must commend the Western Australian government for not backing down on its legislation, despite the federal Labor Party carrying out its blackmailing threats.

I must say that, given the minister's slim margin at the last election and also given the fact that student unions and, in particular, the National Union of Students supported him in his election campaign, I am not surprised that he is using taxpayers' money to bolster the student union coffers, for it is simply a favour he owed them in return for their helping him.

What we have is the federal Labor government reducing state grants, if a state government introduces legislation, which it has a mandate for, and giving that money which should otherwise be going towards roads, schools, hospitals and so forth to more often than not an unrepresentative, politically partisan student union. The government has introduced this clause as a means of protecting the income of one of its prime training grounds—the student unions. There is no disputing that Labor Party members have a vested interest in this legislation; they are using taxpayers' money to ensure they continue to train their future members and so their mates in the ACTU can recruit their future movers and shakers.

As I said earlier, the Western Australian government has introduced legislation which will make membership to student unions voluntary—legislation it had a mandate to introduce. This will give the 40,000 full-time and 17,000 part-time university students in Western Australia the choice of joining the relevant student union. I must ask: why should those who choose not to join a student union be thrown out of university? The legislation of the Western Australian government removes this ridiculous situation of no ticket, no education.

The Western Australian legislation provides basic human rights, freedom of choice and freedom of association. Students should not and must not be compelled to join an association or union if they choose not to. Compulsory membership of a student union or guild should not be a prerequisite to students being able to acquire an education, particularly when you consider the activities of student unions. The Western Australian legislation—similar to legislation in Victoria and the agreement between the Tasmanian government and the University of Tasmania—makes membership of the student associations at those universities voluntary. It forces those student associations to make membership attractive and to be worth joining rather than letting them be complacent under the knowledge that, with compulsory membership, they have a guaranteed income and therefore do not need to represent their membership.

While a few state governments have tried to make student unions attractive, hardworking and representative, this bill ensures that the status quo is maintained, that is, that student unions remain politically partisan, unattractive and unrepresentative by guaranteeing their income, even in the event of voluntary student unionism. The bill is penalising those states which confer freedom of choice upon students. It also penalises the people of each state by passing money on to student unions when it should instead be directed towards schools, roads, hospitals and so on.

This bill could penalise Western Australians to the tune of approximately $5 billion. I must ask: why would most students join their student union when they know that, if they do not, their share will be contributed by the taxpayer and the majority of facilities offered by the unions will still be able to be used? We will see that most students at the majority of universities in Western Australia, Victoria and Tasmania choose not to join their student union, knowing full well that the union fee they should have paid will be paid by the taxpayers of their state. Consequently, the states will lose essential services to the same value because this bill corruptly diverts money from these essential services to the Labor Party's and the union movement's prime training grounds.

This is but another example of the Commonwealth imposing its will on the states when it disagrees with the state policy. It is high time that members of the Labor Party realise that they do not have a mandate to legislate on every single issue facing our community, particularly those issues which are the responsibility of the states. Their underhanded way of trying to maintain compulsory student unionism in all states—which is anathema to the principles of freedom of choice and freedom of association—are to be condemned.

I will conclude by pointing out to my Western Australian colleagues opposite that, if they support this motion, each time when the Western Australia Labor leader Ian Taylor makes one comment about less money being spent on essential services—and if our state has lost money as a result of clause 15, which they support—they must hold up their hands and say, `We are responsible for this funding shortfall. By trying to override state legislation, we have ensured Western Australia got less.' I say again: I oppose clause 15. It is anathema to the principles of freedom of choice, freedom of thought and freedom of association. I reiterate: it is wrong for the federal government to override legislation which the state governments have a mandate to introduce.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up, I would like to thank all honourable members who contributed in the debate. I would like to start on a positive note by pointing out that the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill does give the states considerable benefit with payments linked to not only the CPI as they were formerly but also population growth for the next three years. It also gives states a real chance at looking forward for three years knowing that they can predict fairly accurately and, let me say, with more money than they otherwise would have had, their budgets for the next three years. That is a real positive in this bill.

PARA.TAB: I will say only a few words about what seems to have the opposition in a lather concerning the students. The issue here is very much one of university autonomy. This government considers that it is an important feature of university autonomy that higher education institutions and students should be able to make their own decisions, independent of any government interference, on the provision of services and amenities for the students and the imposition and collection of fees for that purpose.

The Higher Education Funding (Student Organisations) Amendment Bill 1994 and the complementary amendment to the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill currently before the House are direct results of state government interference in this autonomy. For example, the Victorian state government has legislated to control the application of student fees regulating which services can be provided. Student newspapers are currently not provided for and, if added to the approval, the state government will control and censor the material published. This government takes the fundamental view—and we have the confidence—that students can basically look after their own affairs. They are the ones who are paying the money in. Why should a state government step in in a jackboot style and tell them how to spend their money and what they can spend it on? We will not support that.

Opposition members also stated that they support freedom of choice, yet the Victorian government has removed from students the ability to choose for themselves what services and amenities they want to be provided—in actual fact, more of big brother. Student unions cannot be likened to trade unions, and this was brought up in debate. What are sometimes referred to as student unions come from a longstanding tradition of student guilds, which are characterised by students coming together to provide a wide range of non-academic benefits to students. The government will protect the autonomy of the universities in their activities on behalf of the students and ensure that institutions maintain an environment that fosters the necessary cultural atmosphere for students to exchange ideas and hold and express opinions in a free and unimpeded manner.

In conclusion, I point out that the Commonwealth government's position is supported by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, the National Union of Students and the National Tertiary Education Union. These organisations support the views and wishes of institutions and students. Consequently, it is difficult to understand why the coalition opposes clause 15.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with what members of the opposition have said during the second reading debate, the opposition remains opposed to clause 15 of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill. Without rehearsing the argument at great length, clause 15 provides that any amount paid by the Commonwealth to make up lost funding for student organisations as a result of voluntary student unionism is a debt due to the Commonwealth from the state. Therefore the provision of this clause would allow the Commonwealth to deduct from the grants generally made pursuant to the states grants general purposes legislation that amount of money.

PARA.TAB: Placing this matter in a somewhat broader context, we have been lectured in this place in recent days by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), amongst others, about the need for and the desire of individual liberty and freedom but when it comes, in this particular clause in this particular legislation, to the freedom relating to the freedom of association, the government turns a blind eye to this provision. The freedom of association has been stated on a number of occasions in a number of ways. Perhaps it is put most succinctly in the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights in article 20, part 2, which states that no-one may be compelled to belong to an association. When we are given lectures generally about the desirability of freedom and liberty, we say that this particular freedom in this legislation ought to apply to student unions as it does to any other association.

However, what we see in a broader context in this legislation is the prescience of Alfred Deakin, who said in the early years of this federation that whoever controlled the purse strings would in fact hold the balance of power in Australia. Not only is the Commonwealth in this legislation taking a unilateral act in relation to the states, which form part of the federation, but in other legislation which comes before this parliament from time to time there is a desire on the part of the Commonwealth to simply concentrate power into its own hands. It is not worried whether it does that through the implementation of United Nations treaties, which involve some exercise of the sovereignty of the people of Australia by those who do not belong to this country, or whether it does it, as in this legislation, through its control over the purse strings. Whichever way it is done, it is a breach of the principles which underline the federation of the states and the Commonwealth into the Commonwealth of Australia, and it is contrary to the provisions of the constitution itself.

When the states were handing over power to the Commonwealth, they set out in section 51 of the constitution a series of powers which they were handing over. One of the powers which quite clearly remains within the scheme of the states' legislation is that relating to universities and higher education.

One only has to look to the fact that universities in this country are established under laws of each of the states and the territories. It is quite clearly an area which was preserved by the states for themselves upon the federation of this nation. Yet here we have, in relation to this particular clause, the Commonwealth breaching that principle and once again undermining the federation as it was brought into existence at the turn of this century. For those reasons in the broader sense and for the particular reasons outlined by opposition speakers in relation to this clause during the second reading debate, we oppose clause 15 and accordingly we shall vote against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will state the position again: this government believes that the state governments, where they choose to intervene in student organisations, really have no role in doing that. They should not be telling student organisations how to organise themselves and what they can and cannot do. We are standing up, as we see it, for the students.

PARA.TAB: State governments do have a choice. They can choose to go down the path that the Victorian government has taken or they can choose to go down the path taken last year by Western Australia—although I see that Western Australia seems to be backing off somewhat. In the end, we are standing up for students.

It is all right for members of the opposition to stand up here and talk about how things were at the turn of the century. Every time I hear about states rights and every time I hear all the arguments that are trotted out, it seems to me that a lot of members on the opposition benches would be much happier if we were now at the turn of the century. We made a fundamental decision in 1901 to become one country, to become a nation. Implicit in that was the fact that, over time, things would change and that, over time, this government would become more dominant in the lives and affairs of Australians, and that is what has happened. To put up states rights in 1994 and to talk about preserving turn of the century rights really underscores the fact that those opposite have not come very far.
The government is keeping this clause in the bill. We believe in it and we believe we are standing up for students by having it in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill will amend the Student Assistance Act 1973 to give effect to two of the measures announced by the government in the budget relating to the Austudy/Abstudy supplement scheme. The other budget measures will be implemented by amendments to regulations.

PARA.TAB: The Austudy/Abstudy supplement scheme provides voluntary loans to tertiary students. Under the scheme, tertiary students may trade in part or all of their entitlement to Austudy or Abstudy benefits for an interest free loan of twice the amount of benefits traded. Supplement loans are also available to tertiary students who do not qualify for Austudy or Abstudy benefits because of the parental income test where parental income is less than a certain amount—currently $50,000.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Simplification of the rules relating to the repayment of Austudy or Abstudy benefits

PARA.TAB: The first measure is simplification of the rules relating to the repayment of benefits. This will make it easier for a student to repay benefits and, therefore, to maximise the amount of his or her supplement loan. If a student who has received Austudy or Abstudy benefits decides to apply for a supplement loan, the student may repay part or all of the benefits received to maximise the amount of the loan. From 1 January 1995 a student will be able to repay benefits at any time during the year. At present, benefits received during the periods from 1 January to 31 May or from 1 July to 30 September must be repaid before the end of the period. This measure is expected to generate savings to outlays on benefits of about $6 million a year.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Making supplement loans available to certain students not eligible for Austudy or Abstudy benefits because of the spouse income test

PARA.TAB: The second measure is making supplement loans available to students who are not eligible for benefits because of the application of the spouse income test where spouse income is less than a certain amount—$35,000 in 1995. This measure will be effective from 1 January 1995. This measure is expected to cost $0.21 million in 1994-95 and about $0.4 million in subsequent years. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of pleasure this evening that I make a few comments in this adjournment debate in support of the motion that was moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and seconded by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) today, which congratulates all the athletes for representing Australia so well in Victoria, Canada, in the Commonwealth Games.

PARA.TAB: But, in particular, this evening I want to pay tribute to two young teenage girls from my electorate of Lyne: namely, Katie Mitchell and Leigh Marning, who have acquitted themselves extremely well in the rhythmic gymnastics section of the Commonwealth Games. I know that they have probably been in the shadow of Kasumi Takahashi, who won five gold medals in that particular section of the Commonwealth Games, but certainly Katie Mitchell and Leigh Marning have done extremely well. They both won a silver medal in the team's event in the rhythmic gymnastics. Leigh Marning also took out the bronze in the individual event behind Kasumi.

Prior to the departure of the Australian team to Victoria, Canada, for the Commonwealth Games, I had the opportunity to meet with Katie and Leigh at the Australian Institute of Sport here in Canberra where they were in camp for a number of weeks of training prior to their departure. Katie and Leigh took me on a tour of the Australian Institute of Sport and I saw their accommodation and the training facilities.

Both girls are aged 15 and have been involved in gymnastics since early 1989 when, under the stewardship and training of Mrs Doreen Rayward in Taree, they began with the Gymaroos, a gymnastic squad based at the Taree Police Citizens Youth Club. They have progressed and travelled overseas. They have both travelled to the Gymnaestrada in Amsterdam as part of the gymnastics display team. They have also been invited to perform at the next world Gymnaestrada in Berlin.

Both these girls have made some major sacrifices. As I said, they come from the Taree area but because of their commitment to their sport they have located themselves in Sydney. They are away from family and go to school down there. I think they live with grandparents and are probably in more difficult circumstances than they would be if they were at home in their local area. They have made that commitment to their sport and they are going through those hardships, which have paid off in the medals they have won not only for themselves but also for Australia. They have done Australia and the local area in Taree quite proud.

I would like to congratulate in the parliament here tonight both Katie and Leigh for the way they represented Australia at the Commonwealth Games in Victoria, Canada. I congratulate them on the medals they have won and on the way they have conducted themselves as part of the Australian team. I certainly congratulate the entire Australian team.

They are now going to set themselves for the 1996 Olympics. There has been a lot of talk recently about the commitment and support the Commonwealth must offer its athletes in looking forward to the next Olympics, and certainly the Olympics after that to be held in Sydney. A lot of that support is forthcoming from the Commonwealth but it also behoves me here tonight to note the local community support that was evident at the time when the Taree Police Citizens Youth Club was established, which is where these two girls had their start with the local Gymaroos squad in their training as gymnasts. Now they are reaching to those world standards and the levels within their sport where they can become world leaders.

I congratulate the local community in Taree for giving these girls their support over the past five years whilst they have been training and gone from rank amateurs to the level they have reached now where they are winning medals at the Commonwealth Games. I look forward to the ticker tape parade that will be afforded our two Commonwealth Games medallists in Taree this Friday.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech I am about to make is a speech that I know you, Mr Speaker, would have loved to make if it had not have been for Canterbury smashing the Steelers a week ago at Belmore Oval.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I think that is a reflection on the chair if ever I heard one.

—I know in the generosity that you have for good football teams, Mr Speaker, you would join with me in congratulating the Canterbury-Bankstown Rugby League Football Club on its excellent effort in securing the minor premiership and club championship last Saturday. As members may know, both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and I take great pride in being patrons of this club. The club entered the first grade competition in 1935. In all, the Bulldogs, as they are known and loved, have played 12 grand finals, winning half of those.

PARA.TAB: The first grand final win came in 1938, followed four years later in 1942 by another victory. It was to be some 38 years before the Bulldogs were to win another grand final in 1980, and then in quick succession they won in 1984, 1985 and 1988. They have been runners up in the competition in 1940, 1947, 1967, 1974, 1979 and 1986. In the almost 60 years of first grade competition, the Bulldogs, like their following, have changed in composition but not in character. The fans over the years have grown, but they now come from all sorts of different cultural backgrounds. However, one thing that has not changed is the tenacity and fervour of the fans and the team alike.

As members may know, the Canterbury-Bankstown area has one of the largest ethnic populations in Australia—the second highest percentage of people born overseas or with overseas born parents. Despite the Anglo-Celtic beginnings of rugby league, it has thrived in this area where the community has a fond tradition of backing those who aspire and rise to success.

Many thought that the influx of people of non-English speaking background would mean that rugby league in the Canterbury-Bankstown area would die and that soccer would become a more popular code. But that has not happened, and part of the reason for that is the very big effort Canterbury makes to ensure it meets the needs of the community through coaching and competitions with the schools.

It is only by building up that local core of support that the club has been able to continue to be the great club it is. That is why it is with great pride that the community in Canterbury has taken captain Terry Lamb to its heart. As Canterbury wrapped up both the minor premiership and the club championship last Saturday, Terry—or Baa Baa as he is known to his fervent supporters—played his 304th match, the highest ever number of first grade matches to be played by an individual. This was no mean feat for a man who, in the context of this sport, is relatively old at 33 years of age. I have to tell you, Mr Speaker, that he has signed up again for another superb season next year.

In one of the greatest days for the club, Terry capped off this historic occasion with two tries to steer the club to a 40-12 victory over Western Suburbs. As you would have seen, Canterbury picked up at half-time the week before and, with some marvellous work by Lamb, the team got its spirit back. Unfortunately for you, Mr Speaker, we had the choice of either losing the game and putting Brisbane out of the top five or defeating the Steelers. I think there was a fair amount of nostalgia that weekend in that Canterbury may have been playing its last game at Belmore Oval. So there was a tenacity to win that was obvious in the second half.

Terry Lamb has played 304 first grade games for Canterbury and earlier for Wests, scoring 150 tries, 385 goals and totalling a mighty 1,379 points over his career. He represented the city seven times between 1982 and 1990, he represented New South Wales eight times between 1981 and 1989, and he has represented Australia 23 times. Terry Lamb typifies what Canterbury-Bankstown football club is about—tenacity and hard work. I wish Terry and Canterbury well in the grand final this year. I think those people who predict a grand final between Canterbury and Canberra will be right. I think that will be one of the great games in the history of rugby league, and we will win it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In each of our electorates from time to time some of our constituents go through a very difficult, and sometimes traumatic, experience. I refer to compulsory acquisition of property, which can be triggered by Commonwealth, state or local governments. These experiences are unavoidable.

PARA.TAB: South-east Queensland has unprecedented high growth rates which give rise to the necessity for compulsory acquisition of property to provide for infrastructure necessary to cater for that growth. In my electorate a number of property owners have had their lives disrupted as new road corridors are announced. I repeat: I believe that these disruptions are unavoidable.

As local members, we attempt to ensure that property owners are properly and adequately compensated. Whether the compensation is for a residential block, rural residential allotment or maybe a farm that can no longer be a viable concern after the compulsory acquisition, it is a very traumatic experience for those affected. This has been my experience with a number of constituents whose homes, acreage or farms or industrial properties lie in the path of the Yandina bypass. They are all resigned to their fate and are now awaiting notification of compensation.

One such person contacted me and wanted to know, if he received compensation, whether there are any tax implications. I made some inquiries through the office of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear). I must say that I received every cooperation. An officer from his office sent me draft taxation ruling 94/D35, comprising 53 pages, entitled `Capital gains: treatment of compensation receipts'. Surprise, surprise! On page 33, the ruling reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Wally has lived on a 2 hectare property since purchasing it in January 1987 for $300,000. In that time the property has not been used for income producing purposes. One hectare of land is needed by the state government to complete improvements to the highway which runs alongside the property. The relevant State Authority compulsorily acquires the 1 hectare strip from Wally in May 1994 and commences work on the property at that time. The contract is settled in July and the Authority pays $180,000 as compensation for the acquisition of the 1 hectare strip. Wally has engaged the services of an independent qualified valuer who has estimated the value of the 1 hectare strip in 1987 as $120,000.
The bottom line appears in the subsection dealing with the capital gains tax consequences, which says:
. . . subsection 160ZZQ(4) operates to impose capital gains tax . . .

How many honourable members ever thought when they examined the legislation and voted on it that this would be a consequence? I ask the government to object to this ruling, which will become de facto law if the ATO has its way. If this is an example of the intended consequences of the legislation, state and local authorities ought to make sure that compensation packages include an additional payment for possible capital gains tax liability caused by the compulsory acquisition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under Labor there are two things certain in life: one is death and the other is tax amendments. Nothing in Labor's arsenal of avaricious taxes assumes Frankenstein-like proportions as its fringe benefits tax. It is the stated intention to extend the application of the FBT far beyond the original justification offered for the impost in the first place. That is giving great concern to practitioners and employers alike. Although not necessarily ever having subscribed to the policy behind the original FBT law, both the professions and businesses had bowed to the inevitable and had come to accept that pure salary packaging benefits were irrevocably caught up in the FBT net.

PARA.TAB: The government has clearly stated that this particular tax grab will not be limited to benefits which are clearly substitutions for what would otherwise have been taxable income in the hands of employees. Labor's fringe benefits tax is to be imposed more and more on so-called non-package benefits. Expenses of a business nature are to be caught in a net that never were and never could be, in anyone's wildest imagination, construed as substitutes for salaries to individuals or to entire categories of employees. In other words, the FBT is to tax expenditures that are not proper benefits at all.

Moreover, definitions for the so-called benefits to be brought into the FBT net are simply not available. The chances are, once again, that discretion will be given to the Australian Taxation Office to decide the nature of business expenses to be zapped with the proposed extension of the fringe benefits tax. That is hardly a recipe for certainty. It certainly does not allay legitimate fears that Labor's FBT threatens to suffer from an overdose of overdesign and a total absence of certainty amongst the FBT taxpayers and tax practitioners generally.

The truth is that undoubted confusion now clouds the FBT—confusion which mocks compliance with and administration of the extended FBT. The principal purpose of the tax was noble enough in its genesis—that is, to prevent tax avoidance and abuses. It was not, as it has become, to tax business on a broad scale. Let us take the example of business travel. To someone in the desk-bound Australian Taxation Office, domestic or international travel may seem to be something of a perk. Mr Speaker, you and I, and honourable members in this place, know travel is a bit of an ordeal rather than a perk, but you can understand the perspective that people in the ATO might have.

To those who have to endure such travel to further their ability to earn personal or business income that is taxable anyway, it can be something of an irksome ordeal. Even if it is not, who is to say that just because earning a taxable dollar is pleasurable, the cost of it should attract FBT? There is more than a smell of envy about that sort of approach.

Labor has become almost medieval in its approach to taxation and, particularly in this context, reminiscent of the window taxes and Pitt the Younger. As it stands now, companies might be subjected to FBT for providing chairs and desks. That is the way it looks at the moment. That is the way it is capable of being interpreted. That is the sort of stupid inanity that is thrust upon businesses. That is the sort of uncertainty and fear under which businesses have to labour under this present government's regime and its approach to the FBT, which has gone far beyond what it was ever intended to combat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Speaker. What a glowing tribute to you. Today in the House the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) chose to defend, or should I say painfully defend, the job compact and the training wage. As is his wont, the minister pointed his finger at the opposition and chastised it for having no policy for solving unemployment. Just prior to the minister's defence of the white paper, the Minister for Transport and Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) told us of the great leap forward in the area of enterprise bargaining. He chose not to use the term `non-union agreement' when citing a list of respectable companies which had recently been provided with public money to enter into enterprise agreements. It is almost amusing that a party whose leader constantly evokes the memory of Chifley and the struggles of 1891 and trots out such stirring catchcries as `Labor to the bootstraps' can so blithely accept this kind of equivocation.

PARA.TAB: In a euphoric, sentimental moment, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) could be forgiven for describing the aforesaid minister as a fink, which, as we all know, means someone who rats on the party. The PM mistakenly used this term in reference to me one day in this chamber. It only goes to show just how cynical the Prime Minister's use of fabricated Labor history is. The PM, of course, rewrites Labor history almost every time he speaks in this House.

Minister after minister will defend a policy by way of the argument `the opposition has no policy'. The truth is, sex and Aboriginal affairs aside, that the opposition has basically the same policies as the ALP. When it comes to the question of sex, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) and his mates—I presume they are all blokes—in the Lyons Forum start reciting the Bible and blowing their trumpets about Sodom and Gomorrah. If it were not for a few extremists in the coalition ranks, the person in the street would not be able to separate the two parties.

Back to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training: today in the House he actually admonished those who chose not to believe that case management and the training wage were the answer to the problems confronting working people. He did not exactly say that they would solve unemployment; it was more, I think, that they would provide us with a way of handling those who are unemployed, as if they would give us a warm inner glow and show that the government was at least committed to thinking about the problem of unemployment. There would not have been a person in the House who truly believed in it, or was prepared to stake his or her political future on it. But, instead of challenging the logic that it was built on, the coalition chose to construct the myth that the problem of unemployment was due to Joan Kirner's appointment to the chair of ESRA. Why the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) chooses this path absolutely confounds me.

The truth is that on the question of the job compact and training wage the opposition spokesperson for industrial relations, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), does not have too many problems with what Minister Crean has given us. No matter how often the minister tries by sleight of hand to convince himself and this House that training wages do not equal cheap wages, others know otherwise.

How many times is the minister going to tell us that the cheap wage system he is instituting is really a discounted wage for training or that a lack of job readiness is the real problem? It is almost obscene to be arguing that unemployment is a consequence of a lack of skill or that visiting your case manager is akin to a session on the couch with an analyst. The discounted wage aside, a wage the minister admitted proudly had been extended to the adult long-term unemployed, it could very easily end up as a mechanism for depressing wages. That would be depressing, too. In theory, there is nothing in the legislation to guarantee that discounted wages will not threaten award wages or the employment of workers on award wages. Are we to rely on the benevolence of the employers, or are we to rely on the commitment of a government which continues to fall subservient to the market? As we discovered, this is a dangerous practice.

The nature of the debate over the privatisation of airports illustrates yet another crisis of philosophy within the ALP. Tonight during the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill debate, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), to his credit, systematically and comprehensively debunked the argument of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) in favour of airport privatisation. What is unfortunate about the debate is not that there is actually one occurring but, more importantly, that it is incumbent on the Left, and tonight the member for Melbourne, as every public asset comes up for sale, to mobilise a defence based on the logic of the market.

The proponents of the logic of the market crow about efficiency, competition and the maximisation of profit as if this is what really happens in the economy. When it comes to media ownership I do not see the member for Werriwa jumping to his feet to attack an inefficient, slothful media monopoly. Nor do I hear him arguing for a more efficient taxation system to fund a diminishing government outlay. What is really needed, as the member for Melbourne alluded to but the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) does not seem to want to talk about, is a new debate about the responsibility of government to redistribute wealth in a manner which displays at least a modicum of commitment to social justice. At the moment it is non-existent. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: I want to talk this evening about the Perth Dental School, which is a matter of concern to my constituents and to those who have an interest in dental health in Western Australia. The Perth Dental School has a significant number of serious problems. The Perth Dental School is administered by the University of Western Australia. A review was commissioned by the Senate of the university in October 1993 to define the future of the dental school within the University of Western Australia.

At its first meeting the review panel agreed that its priority task should be to `define the issues raised by its terms of reference and to invite comment from appropriate sources specific to these matters'. The issues paper relating to this review canvasses some of the principal issues that the panel will need to consider in order to prepare a report for the Senate. In the concluding questions section of the issues paper, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The preceding brief analysis of issues arising from the review panel's terms of reference can be formulated into a series of questions on which opinion is sought.
7.1Is it reasonable to project that Western Australia need not increase the supply of new dental graduates in order to reach an optimum dentist population ratio of 1:2720 by 2011?

7.2Can the Dental School be a viable unit in terms of an appropriate spread of specialists and required undergraduate/postgraduate mix, with an annual intake of thirty students. If not what growth rate is required to achieve a critical mass for the Dental School?
7.3Can an appropriate relationship between the Dental School and the Dental Hospital be achieved within the present accommodation arrangements?
7.4If not, what alternative arrangements might be put in place and at what cost, for a different location for the Dental School which also brings it closer to the University and the Medical School?
7.5What measures other than increases in staff and student numbers, are required to create a viable postgraduate activity in the School?
7.6Is DEET likely to fund an expansion of the Dental School, and could the State absorb the increase in the supply of dentists which it appears would result?

7.7If the Dental School cannot be viable at its present size, and cannot attract the funds for growth, is rationalisation of the course structure with another Australian University a viable alternative?

These are very important questions. They are particularly important to the students and staff who are working within the present confines of the Perth Dental School. I happened to visit the Perth Dental School on 7 July. From my observations, the conditions that the students and staff have to work under are an absolute disgrace. In fact, I would consider the building and its interior to be an embarrassment as Western Australia's dental school. It is our representation of dental education in the state. I understand that there are students who come from South-East Asia with a view to undertaking courses at that school and I would have thought that it would be extremely embarrassing for the staff to have to show them around this particular building.

PARA.TAB: The tissue culture lab is too cramped. The A.J. Herman lab is too cramped and is an entirely depressing room. I understand that there is a significantly dangerous structural crack in the west wall of that lab. The roof of the A.J. Sutherland lecture theatre, which is the principal lecture theatre, leaks and there are water stains in there. There is a range of substantial accommodation problems in this building that suggest that little to no expenditure has been made on the building for a very long time.

The review is obviously very worrying and undermining for the students and staff of those courses who are not sure whether or not the Perth Dental School will continue in its present form or in any form at all in the future. I urge the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) and the state minister for health to consider very strongly the conditions in which students and staff are forced to work and study in the Perth Dental School.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What aspects of helicopter flight does the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) (a) regulate or (b) monitor (i) above or within 5 kilometres of Sydney Harbour and (ii) between Sydney Harbour and Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.
(2) What are the (a) extent and (b) specifications of air space or air lane R409.
(3) What restrictions does the CAA impose on flight movements complying with air space or air lane R409.

(4) Do CAA instruments or regulations impose an altitude below which no aircraft may overfly a populous area; if so, (a) what instruments or regulations; (b) to which aircraft do they apply and (c) what minimum altitudes and other conditions are applied.

(5) Is Australia a party to an international treaty or agreement which wholly or in part refers to aviation safety or the environmental effects of aviation; if so, what (a) are the details of the treaty or agreement and (b) limits do they impose on the making of CAA or other aviation regulations.
(6) Do the CAA regulations referred to in part (4) comply with the treaties and agreements referred to in part (5).
(7) Are CAA regulations required to comply with any Commonwealth or State (a) environment, (b) planning or (c) land use legislation; if so, what are the details.

(8) Does the CAA give operators of the helicopter flights referred to in part (1) full or partial exemptions from requirements imposed by CAA regulations; if so, (a) which entity within the CAA gives the exemptions, (b) what are the (i) range and (ii) nature of the exemptions given, (c) to which (i) aircraft and (ii) type of aircraft do they apply, (d) do the exemptions involve (i) minimum altitude, (ii) horizontal placement in designated space, (iii) time of flight or (iv) maximum permitted noise levels; if so, what are the details, (e) how many flights operated under an exemption from any CAA requirement in (i) 1991, (ii) 1992, (iii) 1993 and (iv) 1994 and (f) what proportion of flights are operated while under an exemption from any CAA requirement.

(9) Are the flights referred to in part (1) under continuous radar control of Air Traffic Control at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport or any other radar or other continuous air traffic control; if so, what are the details; if not, what control or monitoring of flights occurs.
(10) Does regulation of the behaviour of flights while airborne rely wholly or partly on an honour system or other self-regulatory arrangement; if so, what are the details.

(11) What (a) investigations into or (b) prosecutions of breaches of CAA regulations by pilots, operators or owners making the flights referred to in part (1) has the CAA undertaken or pursued in (i) 1991, (ii) 1992, (iii) 1993 and (iv) 1994.
(12) Have penalties been applied with respect to any case referred to in part (11); if so, (a) what penalty was imposed and (b) upon whom was it imposed.
(13) What is the minimum required size for aircraft registration letters to be affixed to aircraft making the flights referred to in part (1).
(14) Are registration letters of any particular size or minimum size required to be affixed to the base of the aircraft.
(15) Are letters required to be reflective or to contrast with their background.

(16) Are pilots, operators or owners of aircraft used for the flights referred to in part (1) required to hold any kind of public liability insurance in respect of those or other operations; if so, what are the (a) nature and (b) extent of the required insurance.
(17) Does the CAA acknowledge that in the event of malfunction, helicopters are better able to autorotate to safe ground from a higher altitude than a lower altitude.

(18) Did the CAA receive submissions from, have correspondence with or hold discussions with, any government or industry body during (a) 1991, (b) 1992, (c) 1993 or (d) 1994 regarding amendments to R409 or any CAA instrument or regulation affecting minimum altitude, horizontal placement in designated space, time of flight or maximum permitted noise levels; if so, what were the results.
(19) Does the CAA propose to alter the R409 air space or air lane; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) All aspects of helicopter operations are regulated under the Civil Aviation Regulations (CARs). Compliance with all Regulations is a pilot responsibility. However, in that part of the airspace which falls within the Sydney Control Zone (which includes part of the area referred to in the question), air traffic controllers monitor compliance with CAR 100 (compliance with air traffic control clearances and instructions).

The NSW Commission of Inquiry into the Proposed Heliport for the Central Business District of Sydney at Pier 8, Pyrmont recommended that the NSW Environment Protection Authority confer with the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) with a view to investigating the present and future use of R409. The investigation is to include:
methods to regulate and police the use of R409 with a view to ensuring helicopters operate in a manner which does not unduly impact on the amenity of adjacent residential localities;
the need for helicopters to bear distinguishing numbers for ease of identification; and
the provision of a satisfactory complaints mechanism in respect of `offending' helicopters.
The CAA is examining the possibility of monitoring noise levels using its Noise and Flight Path Monitoring System.

(2) Details of Restricted Area R409 are contained in the Designated Airspace Handbook and the Sydney Visual Terminal Chart. An extract from the Handbook and a copy of the Chart have been provided separately to the honourable member
(3) The procedures for operating within R409 are contained in the Enroute Supplement Australia. An extract from the Supplement has been provided separately to the honourable member.

(4) CAR 157 prohibits all aircraft from flying over any city, town or populous area, at a height lower than 1,000 feet. There are, however, a number of exceptions to the minimum height rule that are set out in CAR 157 itself (eg taking-off or landing at aerodromes or specified helicopter landing places, search and rescue, law enforcement, emergency etc).
CAR 156 does not permit aircraft to be flown over public gatherings, without the permission of the Authority.

(5) Australia is a signatory to the Convention on International Civil Aviation (Chicago Convention) and generally adopts the standards and recommended practices of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO). Under Section 11 of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 the Authority is required to perform its functions in a manner consistent with the obligations of Australia under the Chicago Convention relating to the safety of air navigation. The Convention does not impose limitations on the making of Civil Aviation Regulations.

ICAO Annex 16 prescribes standards and recommended practices for aircraft noise and engine emissions. The Government has given effect to the noise standards through the Air Navigation (Aircraft Noise) Regulations. The Department of Transport is currently developing regulations to apply the emissions standards in Australia.
(6) Yes. CAR 157 broadly conforms with ICAO Annex 6.

(7) Under the Civil Aviation Act 1988 the Authority must endeavour to perform its functions, other than its regulatory functions, in a manner that ensures that as far as is practicable, the environment is protected from the effects of, and the effects associated with, the operation and use of aircraft.

Further, the Civil Aviation Act provides that the functions of the Authority include carrying out activities to protect the environment from the effects of, and the effects associated with the operation of Commonwealth jurisdiction aircraft.

The Civil Aviation Act also provides that State laws in respect of land use and environmental consequences do not apply to the Authority, property or transactions of the Authority, or acts or things done by or on behalf of the Authority.
The Authority is reviewing the administration of its environmental responsibilities.

(8) As mentioned in Part 4 (above) CAR 157 itself provides a number of exceptions to the minimum height rule. CAR 157 (3A) provides that the minimum height rule does not apply to a helicopter flying at a designated altitude in a particular access lane (eg access lanes associated with R409). Also CAR 157(4) sets out a number of other exceptions to the minimum height rule and allows the Authority to exempt aircraft from the minimum height rule in particular circumstances.

(a) Exemptions are issued by officers of the Authority who hold a delegation under the relevant CAR. In the case of CAR 157(4)(b) exemptions would normally be issued by the relevant District Office of the Directorate of Aviation Safety Regulation.

(b) (i) and (ii)—Exemptions may be issued against any CAR or Civil Aviation Order where that Regulation or Order makes provision for such exemptions. A delegate would only issue such an exemption if satisfied that it is safe to do so.
(c) Exemptions may be given in relation to a particular aircraft or a specified type or category of aircraft depending upon the provision under which an exemption is issued.
(d) Such exemptions may relate to matters such as:
(i) minimum altitude;
(ii) horizontal placement in designated airspace;
(iii) time of flight;

ANSWER.PARA: but do not cover such things as:

PARA.TAB: (iv) maximum permitted noise levels.

The CAA does not have information readily at hand to identify details of every single exemption within the scope of this question. To provide a full answer to this question would place a considerable burden on the CAA's limited staff resources.
(e) The following number of exemptions were issued by the CAA's Bankstown District Office for helicopter operations as indicated:
(f) The CAA does not have the information necessary to determine the proportion of flights operated under exemption.

(9) Helicopters operating within the Sydney Control Zone are provided with an air traffic control service and continuous radar monitoring. The dimensions of the Sydney Control Zone are shown in the Sydney Visual Terminal Chart which is referred to in the answer to Part 2.
Outside the Sydney Control Zone, helicopters are not under continuous radar monitoring.

Monitoring of aircraft within R409 has not been possible due to limitations of the radar system at Sydney Airport, however an upgraded radar system currently undergoing installation may, in conjunction with the CAA's Noise and Flight Path Monitoring System, provide the capability for environmental monitoring.

(10) All civil aircraft flights are governed by the CARs. Inside controlled airspace air traffic controllers monitor compliance with CAR 100, covering air traffic control clearances and instructions. Flights outside controlled airspace are self regulating.
(11) There have been no matters referred to the CAA in relation to flights referred to in part 1.
(12) Not applicable.

(13) Different size requirements are prescribed for different types of aircraft. These requirements are set out in CAR 18. The minimum height of registration marks for helicopters is 150mm or, if the surface area in the required area is of insufficient size to achieve 150mm, as high as is practicable.
(15) Registration letters do not need to be reflective but do have to be of a colour that contrasts with the background.
(16) The Commonwealth does not impose such a requirement. As the operations in question would normally be intrastate operations, this is a matter for the New South Wales Government to advise on.
(17) In general yes, insofar as the options for a suitable landing are increased.
(18) Yes, the Helicopter Association of Australia (HAA) proposed an alteration to Restricted Area R409 (refer to answer to Part 19).

CAR 157 was amended in 1992 to omit the different minimum height requirements for helicopters and aircraft. Previously the minimum height for helicopters was 1,000 ft and the minimum height for aeroplanes was 1,500 feet. The amendment aligned Australia's requirements more closely to the requirements in other leading aviation countries such as the USA.

These issues were canvassed in the Commission of Inquiry into the Proposed Heliport for the Central Business District of Sydney at Pier 8, Pyrmont, to which the Authority made a submission, as did many industry and other Government bodies.

(19) The HAA has proposed an alteration to Restricted Area R409 involving raising the upper limit east of the Harbour Bridge to 1,000 ft in lieu of 500 feet. This proposal is currently under review by the CAA in association with its development of Parallel Runway Procedures at Sydney Airport.

The HAA has also proposed a southerly extension to the boundary of R409. The CAA will examine the safety, regulatory and environmental implications of this proposal. The Authority will consult with industry and community groups before any decisions are made.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 30 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many national servicemen in total served in each year from 1952 until 1972.
(2) How many national servicemen served in (a) Vietnam from 1965 to 1972,
(b) Korea from 1952 to 1960 and (c) Malaysia from 1965 to 1970.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) It is not possible to accurately provide the information in the format requested without extensive use of limited manpower resources for manual research of military records. However, during the period May 1951 to November 1959, 227 021 national servicemen served in the Defence Force. Of this number 6 967 served in the Royal Australian Navy, 197 787 served in the Australian Regular Army and 22 267 served in the Royal Australian Air Force. From December 1959 to May 1965 no national servicemen served in the Defence Force. From June 1965 to December 1972, 63 790 national servicemen served in the Australian Regular Army.
(2)(a) During the period 1965 to 1972, 15 542 national servicemen served in Vietnam.

(b) With regard to service in Korea and Malaysia, under the provisions of the National Service Act 1951 national servicemen could not be sent overseas unless they signed an undertaking to do so. In the event that such an undertaking was signed by an individual, that conscript's category would be changed to Permanent Military Force. Consequently, no national servicemen served in Korea or Malaysia as a national serviceman. In 1954 some national servicemen were assigned to HMAS Vengeance which was used primarily as a training ship. HMAS Vengeance sailed for Japan on 27 October 1954 and returned on 3 December 1954. Although HMAS Vengeance did not sail within 100 nautical miles of the Korean coast it was deemed to have been allotted for service in the operational area because of the duties it had performed. It is not possible to provide information on other RAN ships that served in Korean or Malaysian waters without physically checking the individual records of all naval personnel employed during the periods in question as well as ships' ledgers which are held by the Australian Archives. This task would involve substantial manpower resources with associated costs, the expenditure of which cannot be justified.
